PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he agrees with the view expressed yesterday by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Fraser, that it is impossible for interest rate reductions to produce a big cut in inflation under the present wages policy. Does he agree that fundamental reform of the Government's wages policy is necessary if inflation is to be significantly reduced and on a sustainable basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody else and I are aware of the Governor's view expressed in a speech last night. Let me say at the beginning that his views cannot, of course, be interpreted as the views of the Government or as having Government endorsement. I make the point that, in relation to the incomes accord, to date the Government has negotiated four wage-tax trade-offs with the trade union movement, most recently earlier this year when accord mark 6 was negotiated. The Government does not believe that it would be appropriate to renegotiate accord mark 6 at present or to consider a possible subsequent wage-tax trade-off at this time. The accord already provides for a substantial wage-tax trade-off. That was negotiated with an eye to preserving a substantial Budget surplus to assist with the transition to a more manageable current account.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short well knows that Australia has a serious savings problem. The maintenance of substantial public savings is quite central to the Government's efforts to redress that savings imbalance. The Government is determined to protect, as far as possible, that surplus.

As it has always been fashionable in this chamber to draw analogies with other countries, it might be appropriate for me to draw an analogy with a country with which for five years-between 1983 and about 1987-those opposite burdened us. I refer of course to the analogy with Great Britain. The comparative outcome with Great Britain is that, while inflation is falling here, in Britain it is increasing quite sharply. At present it is around 10.5 to 11 per cent. It is too early to be speculating on what elements should be contained in Australia's next wages system. All these things have to be done with the right timing, and the Government does not believe that the timing is now.

There are a number of things in the Governor's speech which, I might say, are interesting views but which are not views accepted by the Government. I might say that the Governor's speech stands in sharp contrast, of course, to the views of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition has frequently stated that fiscal policy should be tightened. The Governor of the Reserve Bank is arguing for a relaxation of fiscal policy at the same time as loosening monetary policy. Of course, everything the Governor has advocated is in the context of the Government's accord with the trade union movement. The Opposition has strenuously opposed that accord over a long period of time and has no mechanism for putting any incomes policy in this country into place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response. Do I interpret the Minister's remarks correctly as meaning that he disagrees with the view implicit in the Governor's speech that, far from providing any solution to Australia's economic problems, Labor's accord with the trade unions has placed an unacceptably high floor under inflation which has rendered Australia increasingly uncompetitive as a trading nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor's speech was quite wide ranging and Senator Short can draw any implications he likes from various sections of the speech. It is rather like Michael Porter's book The Competitive Advantage of Nations. All sorts of conclusions can be drawn from a book like that which serve to illustrate all sorts of points.

ANSWER.PARA: What I am saying by way of answer to Senator Short's question is that the Government's policy framework, set in place at the time of the Budget, will remain. There will always be people who are critical of that, and that does not matter. The Government has the responsibility of setting those policy frameworks in place and that is what we have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That question might provide the appropriate time for me to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the United Kingdom led by the Rt Hon. Alf Morris, QSO, MP. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade please comment on yesterday's announcement that the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize has been awarded to President Gorbachev?
—How many votes did you get, Gareth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can wait my turn. The Australian Government very warmly welcomes the award of the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize to President Gorbachev. Prime Minister Hawke will, of course, be writing to him to convey Australia's congratulations on the award of the Peace Prize. It is a very fitting recognition of President Gorbachev's quite invaluable contributions to bringing to an end the Cold War, which, as we all know, cast a pervasive shadow over international relations for more than 40 years.

ANSWER.PARA: I think we ought also to specifically acknowledge the particular role that President Gorbachev and his policies have played in bringing a much more cooperative atmosphere to bear in our own Asia-Pacific region. While not all regional problems have been resolved, the much more constructive Soviet policies that have been evident in respect of Cambodia, Afghanistan, China and the Korean Peninsular have unquestionably contributed to an easing of tensions in our own region.

Along with President Gorbachev's efforts in helping to build a new international order, it needs also to be said that his period in office has witnessed far-reaching changes domestically under the banners of perestroika and glasnost. I think it is fair to say that the Nobel Prize marks not only his contributions to creating a more peaceful environment internationally, but also his creation of a much greater openness and respect for human rights at home, which in turn has contributed much to the promotion of international trust. The Soviet Union today-I think even honourable senators opposite will be obliged to acknowledge-is a vastly different society from what it was just five years ago. Clearly, the changes that have been wrought-albeit not without a price-are, in very large part, due to Mr Gorbachev's vision of a more just and humane society.

Finally, let me simply say that the Soviet people can be justly proud of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Gorbachev, which is a very fitting recognition of their country's positive contributions to creating a more secure and stable community of nations.

—No, I was not aware, when Senator Macdonald asked me a question last week, that an interim report had been received. I think he had been asking about the real report, which is still to be received. —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade able to confirm the accuracy of widespread reports of abuses of human rights occurring in Kuwait at the hands of the Iraqi military and security forces, including accounts of murder, rape and torture? Has the Australian Government formed a view as to an appropriate response? Has the Australian Government had consultations with other nations, including our friends and allies, on this issue? Does the Australian Government believe that a coordinated initiative should be taken at the level of the United Nations, perhaps through the creation of an international criminal tribunal, in order to bring the perpetrators of such barbarities to justice? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the potential for appropriate international action to be taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was itself, as we all know, a grave and flagrant breach of international law. Similarly, Iraq's actions in holding foreign nationals, including Australians, as hostages continues to be a grave violation of the international law of both peace and war. The now well-documented-and it is well-documented- behaviour of the Iraqi forces in expelling the Kuwaitis from their country and systematically pillaging or destroying the country's assets and in raping, torturing and murdering Kuwait citizens unquestionably constitutes crimes of the kind that cry out for condemnation and punishment.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia, in common with the rest of the civilised world, has made very clear through repeated public statements and bilateral demarches to the Iraqi authorities how much we deplore and condemn Iraq's behaviour. We have called repeatedly on Iraq to halt its present policies and practices, to withdraw from Kuwait, and to free all foreign nationals. We have strongly supported throughout the actions of the United Nations Security Council in condemning the invasion and the treatment of foreign nationals, and in putting in place an effective sanctions regime to secure these objectives.

The time may now well be ripe for further action in the Security Council to address quite specifically the international accountability of the Iraqi authorities for their actions in relation to the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, including the question of reparations. An important element in any such accountability should in principle be the bringing to justice of those individuals responsible for war crimes or other grave breaches of international norms of behaviour. Just how this objective might be best advanced will need to be the subject of a good deal of international consultation. Difficult and sensitive questions are involved, and it is important that nothing be done which would prejudice the achievement of a speedy end to the present crisis.

I know from my own conversations of the last few days in New York and Washington that that consultation is occurring and Australia will continue to be part of it. Might I say, finally, that Australia will fully support any appropriate action that emerges from that consultative process. It is crucial that not just the Iraqi leadership but all those under it who are guilty of barbaric behaviour understand that they must expect to be held accountable for their individual actions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I remind the Minister of his answer to a question on 6= December 1989 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: On production costs alone for ethanol to be competitive, so that there would be no extra costs, the price of oil would have to be $US40 a barrel. I ask the Minister: What is the present international price of oil? Before he answers, I would like to remind him of his answer on 10 October 1990, when he said:
Ethanol has been tried as a fuel in only two countries in the world-the United States and Brazil.
I ask whether the Minister is aware of the Autumn 1988 issue of the journal Ecos, where it is reported:
Low percentage alcohol blends now flow from bowsers in the United States, Canada, Japan and most major countries of Europe.

Is the Minister aware that ethanol is also produced in Argentina, Fiji, South Africa, Malawi and Zimbabwe? The Minister's answer of 10 October also included the statement that sugar based ethanol could cost about $1 a litre. Is the Minister aware of the work of Professor Peter Rogers of the University of New South Wales and his report, which projects an ethanol production cost of 38c a litre?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a whole series of questions--
—There are only three.

—There is a whole series of questions and prognostications, opinions and suggestions included in that long running proposal. The first part, as I understand it, was: could I say what the price of oil is at the moment. The answer to that question is no, I cannot say that. But I can tell the honourable senator in rough order of range what the spot market says is the price of oil in the United States, in the Gulf areas and out of the North Sea. The last time I looked-which was not today-that was ranging somewhere between $34 and $37 a barrel. It went up to $40; it came down again. The price on the spot market is extraordinarily volatile reflecting any rumour that sweeps speculators in oil commodities about the possibility of conflict in the Middle East. It does not necessarily bear any relationship to what long term contract prices might be.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Bell that we have based the year long average of prices in this Budget on $23 a barrel. We think that the short range volatility is by no means any indication of what the year run average will be. They are my observations as best I can to answer the first question. To go beyond that seems to me to suggest that I should enter a debate with the honourable senator about the economics of ethanol. I am quite happy to do that but I am not sure that Question Time is the right venue, and I am sure that the honourable senator would lose the debate because ethanol is universally regarded as uneconomic. Those countries that have got into ethanol production have massive subsidies imposed as costs on all taxpayers and not just on consumers of motor fuel, and as well they have incurred-Brazil being an example-massive environmental damage as areas of forest are cleared to make way for the necessary plantations to grow the cane to provide the ethanol base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's comments that there is a volatility in the international oil market, will the Minister consider making some sort of government commitment to ethanol production as a way of removing ourselves from the volatility of international oil production?

—I am the Minister representing here a Minister in another place and Senator Bell is asking me to make a commitment. However, I think I can say to the invitation to make a commitment: no, we will not.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. I recently wrote to you drawing your attention to the fact that senators who take an oath at the time of their swearing-in receive a Bible to be signed by the Governor-General but senators making an affirmation receive only a certificate. What is your response to my suggestion that senators who make an affirmation receive a copy of the Australian Constitution?

—Senator Crowley wrote to me on 7 September suggesting that a leather bound copy of the Constitution be presented to all senators who take the affirmation at their swearing-in in place of the Bible provided to senators who make an oath. Senator Crowley had raised this suggestion with me previously and I am happy to advise that, following consideration of the matter, I have agreed to the suggestion. Henceforth all honourable senators making the affirmation will be provided with a leather bound copy of the Constitution as a memento of the occasion. It will not be possible for honourable senators to substitute another book.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Minister's remarks on ABC Radio yesterday in which he said that the Opposition's proposal to raise the preservation age for superannuation entitlements was `certainly something worth looking at' and, `I wouldn't rule out doing that, in the longer term anyway'. I congratulate the Minister on his rare outburst of economic rationalism which has also been supported by many responsible commentators including Julian Disney on behalf of the Australian Council of Social Service. Is the Minister disappointed that the Treasurer is currently against this very sensible proposal on the grounds that it would be `difficult politically and industrially'-pure code which is easily translated as `Bill Kelty is against it.'? What efforts will the Minister make to demonstrate to his colleague the error of his ways and help him to get back on the economic cart?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. On many occasions in this chamber those opposite have taken points of order against Ministers commenting on Opposition policy. I was very surprised that no Senator jumped to his or her feet to object to Senator Alston's question.
—I call the Minister for Social Security.

—I am not disappointed in the Treasurer at all. I said yesterday that Senator Alston's suggestion on preservation `had some merit'. Those were the words I used. I do not rule out suggestions that I believe have some merit. The Treasurer, having looked at it for a lot longer than I have, does rule it out. I also said in the course of the same discussion that in any event what Senator Alston said was not at the heart of the debate. At the heart of the debate is the question of lump sums. The difficulty for any government in trying to move on that is the resolute opposition of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employers. I do not know that that means that over the longer term it ought not be tackled. That is the real heart of the debate, if we are concerned about double dipping. I have no problem whatsoever with the remarks of the Treasurer.

—I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Recently, a $4.75m Customs fraud case against Midford Paramount Pty Ltd and others collapsed. In his judgment, Magistrate Paul Falzon of the Sydney Local Court criticised senior officers of the Minister's Department saying that a cover-up permeated through the Department. Can the Minister confirm that the total cost to the taxpayer of the failed prosecution was over $1m? Does the Minister stand by his statement at the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee A last Friday in which he said that he did not know of the existence of the 1977 agreement between the Australian and Malaysian governments which caused the case to collapse until he read about it in an article in the SunHerald on 7 October 1990? In so doing, does the Minister deny that he received any brief or briefing on the matter at the time of a report which appeared in the Australian newspaper on 4 July 1989, which reported the agreement and the possible prosecution of two of his Customs officers? If he did not receive such a briefing, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question has all the qualities of a `Have you stopped beating your husband?' type of question. Of course Senator Bishop is aware, as I am, of the reports of the so-called $4.75m fraud case and the prosecution of Midford Paramount. Senator Bishop and I are peculiarly aware of it because we talked about it in Estimates committees for about four hours.
—It seemed like that to you.
—It certainly did, Senator Bishop. Even at the end of that time I do not think anything had been established. So let me have another go at it.
—Please do.

—Yes. I am quite aware that a magistrate in Sydney criticised a senior officer-at least one senior officer-of my Department. No doubt the senior officer of my Department will take note of those criticisms. But, having said that, I do not know where that particularly takes us, if I might put it in those terms. I think the cost to the taxpayers of the litigation was established in the Estimates Committee. I cannot recall the precise figure, but we will have an opportunity to establish the cost anyway, because we undertook to provide the honourable senator with answers to questions of that kind during the Estimates Committee hearing.

ANSWER.PARA: The burden of the failure of the case brought against Midford Paramount by the Australian Customs Service was that the Customs Service clearly did not know, in instructing the Director of Public Prosecutions, that there had been a secret agreement entered into between the Government and Malaysia relating to quotas on textiles and so on. I do not need to go to the substance of the agreement.

As the honourable senator full well knows, the agreement was negotiated in 1977 by the Fraser Government. It was not much good usually in negotiating agreements, but it was pretty clever in negotiating this one because right from the beginning it was said to be a secret agreement, as I understand it, and it was secret. It was secret from me; it was secret from a whole range of people in the Department and in other departments. If a prosecution fails because there was a secret agreement negotiated by a government, I would have thought that was a very legitimate reason for a prosecution failing in the circumstances in which this one did.

Senator Bishop asked me whether I knew of the secret agreement and the answer is no. As I have said, I did not know of a secret agreement. It really worked. It really was a secret agreement. Of all the things I might say about the spiritual heirs in this place of honourable senators opposite in those days when they were in government, one thing I must say about them is that they clearly had a skill which I did not recognise until quite recently, that is, a capacity to negotiate secret agreements. I have not given them credit for all of that in the past.

Apparently Senator Bishop says that the agreement was referred to in the Australian newspaper, I think in 1989. I have no knowledge of that, Senator. I received notes at various times about Midford Paramount's alleged breaches of Customs regulations, but I did not receive any briefing about the secret agreement at that time because, as the honourable senator full well understands from her listening at the Estimates committee, officers of the Department were not aware of it either.

TALK.START.PARA: —The magistrate did not believe that.

—I am not concerned to conduct a retrial of Sydney magistrates' proceedings here in the Senate. That is not our function here. If people want to appeal from the magistrate's decision, I would advise them to do it anywhere but in the Senate with Senator Bishop as prosecutor.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask: In the light of the Government's Budget commitment to increased funding for family services, can he tell the Senate what steps the Government is taking to assist in the development of parenting skills as a preventive measure in marriage and family breakdowns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 March 1990, as part of the child and family services initiative, the Prime Minister announced an increase of about $15m over the next three years to assist agencies to extend marriage counselling, marriage education and family mediation programs to unserviced and underserviced districts, with particular emphasis on services to disadvantaged families.

ANSWER.PARA: To complement the strengthening of these existing programs, my Department will also be implementing a pilot preventive program called family skills training, which will focus on developing parenting skills. The Government is aware that there are very few sources of sound advice on parenting.

This contributes to the difficulty parents experience in dealing with children and perpetuates the cycle of disadvantage when these children in turn become parents. Family skills training will attempt to address the isolation, sense of failure and loss of self-esteem that some parents experience in raising children.

The program will commence in January 1991 with a limited number of services in some States, and a total expenditure of $213,000 in 1990-91. It is anticipated that the program will be expanded to other States in later years.

I remind the Senate that on 11 September the Minister said that departmental advice would be going to him within a week or two and that he would make his decision after that. Has he now done so and what are those decisions?
—I am still considering the matter, Mr President, and I assure you that when I have made a decision, Senator Teague will be the last to know.

—I address my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister will be aware of the deteriorating industrial situation in the four-week-old oil dispute in Victoria, despite the intervention of the Prime Minister's so-called talks with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. As stability in this industry is so vital to the economic stability of Australia, and financially troubled Victoria in particular, does the Government have any plans to step into the dispute, in a manner similar to that adopted 14 months ago at the commencement of the pilots dispute? If so, what form is the Commonwealth's involvement likely to take and when will it commence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an historic question. We have passed 26 hours of Question Time since the election and this is the first hostile question on industrial relations from the Opposition in all of that time. I think that must reflect the innate recognition by the Opposition that we handle industrial relations best and that the Opposition has nothing to contribute on the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, answer the question.

—Thank you, Mr President. The first part of the question relates to whether we have any plans to intervene in the oil dispute. To answer that question I should report to the Senate that last night there were negotiations between the unions and the companies involved. As a result of those negotiations, it is my understanding, confirmed today, that unions are putting proposals to their memberships. On that basis it seems to me to be inappropriate for the Government to take action because it seems, reasonably, that a process which could lead to a settlement is under way.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not say by those remarks that I make a judgment about the likely outcome of that process. But I do say that it is a sign that the normal negotiating processes are coming to a conclusion. On that basis we do not have a plan to take particular action. That is not in any way to be read as meaning that we are not concerned about the problems created for ordinary motorists, industry, and others who rely upon the oil industry. We are certainly concerned about that.

The best illustration of our concern was the involvement by the Prime Minister over the weekend in this matter. However, it is always a matter of quite delicate judgment as to the role of a government in an industrial dispute. In view of my report to the Senate, it is our judgment that we should wait for that process of reporting to meetings of members of unions to conclude before we say anything else on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to the report on the Australian labour market by Professor Richard Blandy in the most recent issue of the Australian Bulletin of Labour? Does this report contain criticisms of the terms of the Government-Australian Council of Trade Unions accord and suggest that the Budget forecast for inflation, unemployment and wages growth will be significantly overshot? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether Professor Blandy's criticisms are soundly based?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Adelaide Advertiser of 3 October reported on page 3 under the heading `Pay accord threatens disaster'. Because of the report I noted that the latest Bulletin of Labour of the National Institute of Labour Studies Inc., based at Flinders University and headed by Professor Richard Blandy, contains an article by the professor forecasting that we will overshoot our predictions in this Budget on inflation, unemployment and labour costs and do so quite significantly.

ANSWER.PARA: I checked the actual bulletin for fear that maybe Professor Blandy was not being reported as accurately as possible. I must say that the report in the Adelaide Advertiser is a fair representation of the opinions Professor Blandy expressed in the bulletin. I might also say that in the bulletin Professor Blandy goes further and offers advice to employers to do things which bear a remarkable similarity to advice that the shadow spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, offered employers the other day: to conduct direct negotiations and effectively to bypass the arbitration system.

Professor Blandy is regarded by many as a national expert in labour economics. He has been for some time the head of a prestigious institute. He is frequently sought out for public comment. People in that situation can sometimes find themselves in the difficult situation of commenting as an academic, talking about matters based on study and scholarship. They can also be regarded as political players in the field and political commentators. In this case it is a risk that Professor Blandy ran and he has fallen into the second category.

The opinions he offers in his article are in no way related to events in the Gulf and do not affect the fundamental calculations in the Budget because of any issues arising from the Gulf. The trouble with what Professor Blandy has said is that his calculations contain a significant technical error, an error which, if committed by an undergraduate in economics, would result in that undergraduate failing. Because it is a technical error involving a long technical discussion, I table an explanation of that error. In colloquial terms it can be described as a statistical mistake in which the Government forecasts in the Budget are worked out on year average figures but Professor Blandy's forecasts are worked out on over the year figures, which means that his forecast is inflated by between 3 1/2 per cent and 4 per cent in the relevant places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Because he has used the wrong calculation, in essence, and he has committed a statistical error.
—On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is referring to Professor Blandy, which is going far beyond answering the question that was put to him.
—It is a long answer. The Minister has said that he will table a document.

—I conclude the answer by saying that this is not the first time that the Bulletin or the Institute have been wrong in their forecasts on the economy. They have a tendency to dramatise and inflate their forecasts. They constantly ignore the record of the accord in delivering on the forecasts of wages growth; in fact, on this occasion they ignore the fact that last year wages growth was, in fact, half a per cent under what was forecast in the Budget. Sadly, it must be said, therefore, that the Institute and, indeed, Professor Blandy in this case, are not reliable economic witnesses or reliable in terms of their academic work on matters of this sort. I table the technical explanation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In view of recommendation 20 of the drugs in sport report that recommended that the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation should be funded, how does the Government justify funding the Australian Powerlifting Federation the sum of $20,000, which organisation was discredited in the report?

—I will seek from the Australian Sports Commission, which is the actual body charged with the responsibility of allocating government funds, the reasons for its doing so. The Australian Sports Commission is a body that I support very strongly. It has an absolute anti-drugs policy. I am sure that the Powerlifting Federation would have had to satisfy the Commission if, indeed, the Commission has given it a grant. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask: Is the Minister aware of the editorial in the Returned Services League (RSL) National Newsletter of September 1990 suggesting that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has sent letters to all its pensioners regarding tax file numbers which pre-empt legislation being passed by the Parliament? Is this accusation correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this article and of the statement made by the National President of the RSL. I regret to inform the Senate that I am informed that the article is inaccurate and misleading and, no doubt, has caused quite a deal of distress to many veterans throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The President of the RSL neglected to do what other ex-service and widows' organisations have done-they have contacted the Department to clarify the issue-and, I am sure, had he done so the article would never have been written.

He would have found out that there are two distinct initiatives concerning tax file numbers which have an impact on pensioners. The first of these is the need to supply tax file numbers to banks and other financial institutions. This initiative affects every member of the community and is being administered by the Australian Taxation Office. The legislation that authorises these provisions was passed by the Parliament in 1988 and became effective in 1989.

An extensive advertising campaign to inform the general public was undertaken by the Australian Taxation Office. Because the legislation exempts recipients of certain Department of Veterans' Affairs pensions, the Tax Office has sought separately to advise those pensioners of their status.

A special booklet was prepared for veterans by the Australian Taxation Office, and this was sent by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to all its pensioners accompanied by a letter specifying whether or not the individual was exempt. The letter and pamphlet also emphasised the requirement for those who are exempt to advise their bank or financial institution of their exempt status. Failure to advise of exemption could result in tax being deducted from their interest at the maximum marginal rate.

That is quite distinct from the second initiative which was announced in the 1990 Budget. This was to extend to all the recipients of benefits from the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and the recipients of payments under the first home owners scheme by the Department of Community Services and Health, the requirement to supply a tax file number to those departments. The legislation to enable this initiative to proceed in veterans affairs is still before the Parliament.

Because the letter in the booklet to veterans about the first initiative was being sent after the Budget announcement, a paragraph was added to the letter explaining that the requirement to supply tax file numbers to financial institutions had no connection with the recent Budget announcement. Reference to the second initiative in this letter was to reinforce the fact that the Department of Veterans' Affairs did not want pensioners to advise it of their tax file number at this time. It stated that the Department of Veterans' Affairs would contact pensioners when their tax file number was required by that Department. This will not happen prior to Parliament passing appropriate legislation.

Mr President, I agree that this is a rather long and complex answer but it is necessary in order to try to make it clear to the National President of the RSL what the real situation is. I believe that he has confused two initiatives. As a result of his confusion, he has written an article for publication which will cause unwarranted stress and confusion in the veteran community.

The answer read as follows-

The Wet Tropics of Queensland was inscribed on the World Heritage List in December 1988, following its nomination on 11 December 1987. In April 1988 the Commonwealth Government announced a three year $75.3 million package of adjustment assistance measures for adversely affected businesses and individuals. This package sought to minimise the socioeconomic impact of the cessation of commercial forestry operations within the Wet Tropics on the North Queensland timber industry and its former employees. The elements of the package include:
- provision of compensation to substantially and directly affected timber and closely related businesses;

- provision of labour adjustment assistance for eligible retrenched timber industry workers, including dislocation allowances, retraining, relocation, wage subsidy and early retirement components; and

- provision of employment for eligible retrenched timber industry workers in the areas of reforestation, management of the World Heritage Area, public works to develop regional infrastructure and by providing seed funding for private and community initiatives.

To date, 97 businesses closely associated with the sawmill industry have applied for compensation and 70 have received compensation offers. Payments have been made to 60 businesses. There have been 27 rejections and the remaining applications are currently being assessed. Compensation offers are based on commercial assessments of the value of the business made by an independent firm of accountants.
The package demonstrated the Commonwealth was ready with the jobs and money to honour its commitment that the listing would not disadvantage the people of North Queensland.

The Government's decision to assist the APS sawmill at Ravenshoe was based on the Government's commitment to minimise the impact of World Heritage Listing by retaining the sawmill as the major employer in Ravenshoe.
The APS sawmill is owned by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd division of National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd (NAP) trading under the name Timbertech.

APS operated a veneer and sawn timber mill in Ravenshoe (population 2079), where it has been the principal employer. By its payments of wages and employment of contractors the sawmill contributed about $3m annually to the local economy.
Until World Heritage listing the sawmill had an entitlement to about 12.5% of the Crown rainforest timber quota in North Queensland. A small volume of logs from private sources was also processed.

Before negotiations began to provide assistance to APS, ACIL Australia Pty Ltd and Price Waterhouse and Co. were commissioned to evaluate probable impacts of World Heritage nomination on APS and to recommend appropriate compensation or alternative measures which might allow the company to continue to operate.
Two options were available:

a- to allow the company to close down and provide compensation to the owners on the same terms as the other timber companies; and additionally, provide alternative employment for up to three years for redundant APS employees;

b- to provide financial assistance to the company to enable it to shift to processing a mature plantation timber resource which was available from the Atherton Tableland region, and retain as many jobs as possible for employees who would have been made redundant by closure of the sawmill.

The provision of assistance depended on successful negotiations with the Queensland Government for 16,000 cubic metres of pine timber per annum to be made available to APS during the next 20 years. Moreover, the decision to make the resource available had to be made speedily so that the Ravenshoe mill could be readied to handle the plantation softwood as soon as existing hardwood log stocks were exhausted in mid-1988.

The Government decided to provide financial assistance to enable the sawmill at Ravenshoe to continue its operations because this was the most effective way to help secure the future of the town of Ravenshoe-assistance which the former Queensland Government was completely remiss in not providing in 1986 when it made a significant cut in the rainforest timber quota.

The conifer plantation resource on the Atherton Tablelands consists primarily of hoop pine and Caribbea (correct) pine, together with minor quantities of bunya, kauri, loblolly, patula and slash pines.
Veneer, mouldings and structural timber were to be produced by the company.
The assistance package was to benefit not only the sawmill but the Ravenshoe community and all North Queenslanders.
The assistance agreement between the Commonwealth and Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd for the sawmill comprised;
(a) an interest free loan of $4.5 million repayable over 10 years; and
(b) an annual subsidy totalling $2,125,000 in each year to be paid in each of the years 1989, 1990, 1991 and 1992.
Under the terms of the agreement the amounts of the loan and subsidy were to be used to:

(a) continue its operations at the mill except where reasonably prevented from so doing by events beyond its control, which events shall, without limiting the generality of that expression, include strikes, equipment failures and cyclones;
(b) maintain a work force of at least forty persons;
(c) carry out its operations at the mill in accordance with good mill practice;
(d) carry out its timber extraction operations so as to minimise environmental impacts;
(e) make good operating losses;
(f) equip the mill to enable it to operate with respect to timber, other than timber obtained from within the World Heritage region; and
(g) pay any stamp duty under any law of Australia on this Agreement and the charge.
It was recognised at the time that the company would have to meet whatever taxation liabilities were incurred in relation to the agreements.

Senator O'Chee has raised the question of whether negative covenants should have been included in the agreement drawn up between the Commonwealth and the company. In essence the agreement was a list of the things that the money provided by the Commonwealth could be spent on-it did not canvass the possible things that the money should not be spent on. I am advised that such an agreement is not unusual and that the company in negotiating this agreement was fully aware that the list was meant to be limiting and that expenditure beyond that list were not acceptable under the terms of the agreement.

Under the agreement the company was required to deliver to the Secretary of DASETT a copy of its audited balance sheet and annual report each year as soon as they were completed. The company was not required to provide the quarterly reports Senator O'Chee has suggested. The provision of these would not be normal commercial practice and not normally expected over a ten year loan.

At the time the Commonwealth began negotiating with Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd on an assistance agreement, that company's assets were already subject to two charges, the first given to Westpac, the second to Placer Pacific Ltd.

Before negotiations began, the Government had decided that the assistance would be by way of a non-repayable subsidy of $8 million, (net present value). In the course of negotiation the concept became changed to a loan repayable over 10 years and four annual subsidy payments. (With a net present value of $7.6 million).

Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd was required to grant the Commonwealth a security, for repayment of the loan, and repayment of any portions of the subsidy which could become repayable in the event of breach of the assistance agreement.

Both Westpac and Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd insisted that the existing priority of the Westpac charge and Placer Pacific Ltd charge should not be changed as a result of the agreement with the Commonwealth; that is, any security the Commonwealth took would rank third. This was judged to be the best security in all the circumstances if the assistance agreement were to go ahead.

The Commonwealth therefore took a charge on the assets of Plywood and Plastic, which ranked third after Westpac's and Placer Pacific charges. As noted above the agreement would not have gone ahead unless existing charges were recognised.

In the event the charge held by Placer Pacific was finalised in late 1988 and the Commonwealth then ranked second. The granting of further securities by Plywood and Plastic was prohibited without the Commonwealth's consent. This is consistent with normal commercial practice. The only other feasible alternative was not to provide any assistance at all.

Price Waterhouse was requested to advise on a fair and reasonable valuation of timber processing activities at APS Ravenshoe based on company records of two years trading prior to January 1988. The financial report from Price Waterhouse showed the company had been trading profitably and was in a sound financial position at that time.

The first audited financial report from the holding company, Plywood and Plastic was received by the Commonwealth in June 1989. On the 30 June 1988 the operating profit of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, which owned and operated the APS sawmill at Ravenshoe, according to its audited and publicly available financial report for the financial year 1987-88 after tax was $861,980. At 30 June 1988 it owed $2,335,719 to related companies in the Timbertech Group and in turn it was owed $752,957.

Like any good business manager the Commonwealth did not let its loan go unwatched. Officers of the Department regularly telephoned the manager of the mill to seek information on progress with the retooling. The mill was visited by representatives on several occasions. The Department's financial advisers on this issue, Price Waterhouse also monitored the operations of the mill.

In accordance with the agreement, the Commonwealth sought from the company a copy of its audited financial reports for the financial year 1988-89 in December 1989 and again early in 1990. There was no indication at this time that there was any financial difficulty in the mill or the holding company.

Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd's draft set of financial accounts for the financial year 1988-89 reported a profit of $368,083. These financial statements show the company was solvent as the equity of shareholders was $2,328,474 after taking all liabilities, including its debt of $4.2 million to the Commonwealth, into account. Related companies in the Timbertech Group owed Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd $1,235,266, an increase of $482,309.

Advice from our accounting advisers suggests that the APS sawmill at Ravenshoe was operating at an overall profit during the entire period of the Commonwealth Government's assistance agreement from 1 July 1988 until the Timbertech Group, including Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, went into receivership.

Nevertheless, the Department (as part of a mid-term evaluation of the implementation of the Wet Tropics Structural Adjustment Package) wrote to the company earlier this year, before the company advised the Government that it was seeking a buyer and before receivers were appointed to the company, to tell them that the Department's accounting advisers would be conducting a review of holding company's expenditure on the APS sawmill. However, before the review could be completed, the holding company was placed in the hands of the Receiver/Manager.

The Department was advised that the Receivers/Managers were appointed by Westpac Bank, the major creditors of the holding company on 20 April 1990. When the Commonwealth met the Receiver/Managers later in April 1990, the Receiver/Managers advised the Commonwealth that they intended to keep the APS sawmill operating for the foreseeable future while they attempted to sell the mill as a going concern. This included maintaining a workforce at the sawmill of at least 40 employees.
The financial difficulties were not discovered earlier because:
- the re-tooling took longer and cost more than was forecast when the financial assistance agreement was developed;
- the sawmill workforce has remained above forty all the time and expanded during 1990;
- the first loan re-payment was made on time; and
- the first financial report by the holding company did not reveal any financial difficulties.

On 4 July 1990 the Acting Minister wrote to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd formally terminating the original 1988 agreement as of 20 April 1990 because the company had failed to meet its obligations and had gone into receivership.Pursuant to the June 1988 loan security given by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd to the Commonwealth Government, the Commonwealth Government required immediate repayment of the loan.
It is understood that Westpac Bank which holds the first charge over the company's assets will not receive full repayment of its outstanding loans even if all assets of group companies are sold.

Local businesses in Ravenshoe claim they are owed $500,000 in unsecured debts. I understand the core debt to unsecured creditors in Ravenshoe is in fact somewhere between $122,000 to $150,000. These debts occurred because of the commercial failure by the holding company and are not due to the World Heritage listing. They are a matter for resolution between the Receivers/Managers and the unsecured creditors.

On 25 June 1990 the Minister advised unsecured creditors who made representations to her that they were unlikely to receive their funds until Westpac had recovered its debts. She also said that the Government's first priority was to try to assist to keep the sawmill operating.

In addition approximately $1.2 million has been paid in compensation to Ravenshoe businesses that have been directly and substantially affected by the World Heritage listing. At least twenty retrenched timber industry workers in Ravenshoe have received assistance from the Commonwealth Government under the Wet Tropics Structural Adjustment Package.

As I have indicated, the Government decided that the best prospect for the future of Ravenshoe was to provide temporary assistance to keep the sawmill operating pending its sale as a going concern. Temporary assistance was offered for this purpose on 9 October 1990 subject to a satisfactory agreement with the Receiver/Managers, and Westpac Bank being reached. The Government is awaiting a response from the Receiver/Manager on whether this offer is acceptable.
Expenditure of moneys paid by the Commonwealth to Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd under the previous agreement has yet to be satisfactorily resolved.

The report to the Commonwealth by the Receivers/Managers on the 25 September 1990 indicate that there is some question about whether the loan and subsidy assistance have been applied in accordance with the agreement.

The Minister is referring the matter to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to investigate whether the Commonwealth can take legal action with respect to the moneys unaccounted for. It is not possible to release that report now, for two reasons: firstly, it is commercial-in-confidence and, secondly, possible Commonwealth legal actions should not be prejudiced.
It is therefore twisted logic to blame the Government as Mike Seccombe did today in the Sydney Morning Herald ``for the mismanagement of the compensation and restructuring package.''
It is not the Federal Government that has done the wrong thing.
We have delivered our promises to the people of Ravenshoe. We provided the money in good faith and with the appropriate controls to re-tool the mill.
The National Party at the time was screaming for adequate financing for Ravenshoe and other towns. By any standards the amount we provided was adequate.
It is great 20/20 hindsight by the Nationals who are trying to stay relevant. At the time all they said was``give them the money''.
In summary I note that:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Bishop proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to responsibly oversee the administration of his portfolio and the abject failure of his industry policy to achieve real economic benefits for Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance which is brought before the Senate today addresses two parts of the administration of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce; namely, the part concerning the administration by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in a responsible way of his own Department and, secondly, the manner in which his Department or ministry has failed, in the eight years over which he has presided, to produce industry policy which has benefited Australia. I think it is timely to present an overview of the failure of the portfolio and the Minister in his responsibility in that over the last seven years there has been a systematic failure of Senator Button's industry policy to bring about any revitalisation of Australian industry. Whether it be through sectoral plans, the bounty and grants schemes, procurement and offsets policies, partnerships for development, which began life as a different creature, the management and investment company scheme, or the performance of the Australian Customs Service and Austrade, the Minister's Department has failed to bring about any tangible benefits for Australian manufacturers, exporters or consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a veritable mountain of documentation in the form of government and industry reports, press articles and transcripts of public statements by many an industry which demonstrate the failure of the Minister's approach. We have seen introduced several famous plans, for cars, steel and for other industry. Let us begin by looking at the car plan. The Button car plan has been a dismal failure. The Minister on various occasions in Estimates and other committees has claimed that it has been a success, but in 1984 we were told that they were bold promises; that there would be three carmakers producing no more than six models at cheaper real prices at the end of the plan. Instead, there are still five makers operating in four manufacturing groups, making eight models at greatly increased real prices. Productivity remains poor, so that it takes longer to build a car in Australia than in virtually any other country. The only export growth that has been achieved is the result of substantial subsidies to manufacturers rather than any underlying improvement in efficiency. Consumers are subsidising the industry to the tune of $1.6 billion, or $25,000 for every worker employed in the auto industry.

The textile, clothing and footwear industry is a sunset industry under the Button plan. We are subsidising each job in the footwear industry to the tune of a massive $70,000 a year. Effective rates of protection exceed 200 per cent in some parts of the industry, and this means that ordinary Australians pay an average of 67 per cent more for clothes, 63 per cent more for shoes and 25 per cent more for textiles than they would if there were no barriers to imports. Protection for the industry is costing $1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Senator Button?

—That is a very good question. I will tell Senator Teague where Senator Button is; he is away preparing for the statement that he intends to make after the matter of public importance, concerning the plight of the textile, clothing and footwear industry. He will tell the Senate in his own words, in a dressed up manner, that somehow it is all the industry's fault that it has not taken the great benefits of his plan and produced a thriving and healthy industry. That is why he is not now in the chamber, Senator Teague. Nonetheless, protectionism for the industry is costing $1 billion a year, which translates into a consumption tax equivalent of about 40 per cent for consumers. Despite this massive protection, the industry appears in terminal decline.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We all appreciate the difficulty that Senator Bishop has with this subject matter, but would you please advise her that under standing order 187 she is not allowed to read her speech?
—Thank you, Senator Evans. I shall keep a close watch on Senator Bishop's speech.

—That is extraordinarily kind of the Minister. I think I can manage without reading a speech. I think I have in the past; I think I will in the future. However, it will be necessary to refer to a lot of documentation that will simply deal with transcripts, affidavits and so on when we come to a different part, addressing specific indications of the way in which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has simply not been in command of his own Department. Subsequent to the failure of his own Department, he finally decided to move some of the officers of whose advice he has previously taken note and indeed depended upon; they have finally been removed. It took a court case of some magnitude and a waste of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money in order to see this accomplished. The organisation, discipline and responsible oversighting of the Department in no way came from the Minister himself. It was foisted upon him by events outside his control. We will look at those, and I will indeed read from affidavits on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I have dealt with the textile, clothing and footwear plan and wanted to say a few things about the steel plan, which is in the same parlous state as the other two. One could say that all we have seen as a result of the steel plan is a massive subsidy paid across over a period when there were other factors at work which caused the steel industry to see some improvement. Indeed, the late Mr Holmes a'Court could perhaps take some credit for that.

Let us look at some of the very specific examples. The first one I mention relates to one that I raised in Question Time dealing with the Midford Paramount case brought by Customs. Honourable senators would note that the answer given by the Minister at Question Time, to put it mildly, was a very cavalier answer not addressing the specific questions asked. It is important to outline just what the Minister refused to answer. The basis of this question and this case is simply this: if a Minister were exercising responsible control over his department, there is no way that a prosecution could have been laid against a company and associates alleging $4.75m worth of fraud against the Commonwealth when the fatal flaw in that case was the fact that there was in existence an agreement between the Australian Government and the Malaysian Government and that agreement was relied upon in the way in which that company conducted its business.

The Minister, in the Estimates Committee C hearings, tried in a rather pathetic way to have evidence brought forward. The head of Customs, Mr Kelly, sat there for the best part of an hour and, in answer to every question asked, simply said: `I do not know; I cannot remember; I have not got the information with me; I will get it for you, Senator'. Yet this very case had been reported in the press the previous Sunday and the Minister had been sufficiently concerned, on my information, to summon Mr Kelly to see him and to brief him on the case.

When I asked Mr Kelly whether he was aware that this matter would be raised in the Estimates hearing, he answered, `Yes'. I asked him whether he had done any preparation. He said `Yes'. I said, `Please tell me what area in which you have done that in order that I can try to find a question to ask you'. He thought that might be a fishing expedition. I thought it might be very small pond in which to fish because, quite clearly, we were conducting an exercise in obfuscation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was out of his depth.

—He surely was. I think it is most interesting to go through the dates and through the chronology of this particular case. Then we might look at the recommendation from the Law Council of Australia concerning the behaviour of the Australian Customs Service, and then we look at the way in which the Minister has simply shown that he has no interest, no concern, not even a glimmer of regret that he has seen his Department simply mishandle a particular case. There are others in the pipeline as well, but the history of this one will suffice.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977 an agreement was entered into between the Australian Government and Malaysia granting concessions to members of the Association of South East Asian Nations. In October 1987 Midford offices were raided in relation to a fraud investigation undertaken by Customs agents concerning documents which led to a new investigation. On 4 January 1988, Customs asked the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to consider prosecution. On 6 January 1988 search warrants were executed against Cramb Tariff Services (NSW) Pty Ltd and the proprietor of that firm. In an affidavit provided by the DPP, it was said that she met with representatives of Customs and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) in the months leading up to the trial in 1988 to discuss available evidence.

On 17 January 1988 a raid was conducted on the offices and home of Mr Rodger and documents were removed. On 7 March, Midford Paramount was advised that investigations by a prosecution solicitor were under way. Between that time and the beginning of a prosecution, employees of Mr Rodger were rung up by members of Customs and were told that he would be going to gaol and that a prosecution was being brought. They were generally harassed and he lost staff.

In April 1988 DITAC, in the person of one Dr Fitzpatrick, a First Assistant Secretary upon whose advice and information the Minister has relied and whom the Minister has defended over a number of years in various hearings, was asked to present a brief concerning the background of the way in which these quotas were exercised. Indeed, there is sufficient evidence to say that the DPP decided to bring the prosecution based on that brief prepared by Dr Fitzpatrick.

Dr Fitzpatrick, in that particular brief, and in his own affidavit, having outlined the history of the way in which quotas were granted in various categories to people who were manufacturing offshore, asserted that for quotas that were granted, first, via the anomalies register and, second, by a scheme that replaced it in 1982, it was necessary for the garments that were being imported to be manufactured in a company controlled by the person who held the quota. On page 7 of his own affidavit, he stated:
Once Midford (Malaysia) ceased manufacturing on behalf of Midford, Midford would no longer have met the criteria for offshore quota.
This is in a document where he begins by saying:
I am aware that if I sign this statement, and any part of this statement is untrue to my knowledge, I may be liable for punishment.
He further states:
It is DITAC's invariable practise to advise the Australian Customs Service to withdraw quota once it has been advised of circumstances which altered an importer's eligibility for quota.

In cross-examination, Dr Fitzpatrick had to admit that there was no such precedent, that he did not know of any such quota which had been withdrawn in this way, and that he had only been aware of a quota which had been handed back. He admitted that that was not part of the responsibility of his Department within DITAC, but merely the responsibility of Customs. This was a document which was relied upon by the DPP to bring this particular prosecution, which reliable investigation will show has cost the taxpayer anything up to $1m, and yet the magistrate said of Dr Fitzpatrick and Mr Petering:

The two principal witnesses, Mr Fitzpatrick and Petering at least the principal witnesses at this stage were called to prove the conditions. I have no doubt whatsoever that they were never in a position to prove the conditions and it is an inescapable conclusion and one that I find without hesitation but either these two gentlemen misled the prosecution or the department officers selectively provided information to their superiors on the basis of these conditions.

As was disclosed from the Cabinet papers and other confidential papers-I might say that those Cabinet papers were subpoenaed by Midford-the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Cabinet Office sought to have those records kept off the public record and if it had been successful, then the prosecution would have proceeded and possibly conceded to a successful conclusion by the prosecution.

The magistrate had the good sense to overrule the intervention by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and said, quite frankly, that DITAC had misled the prosecution, that the prosecution had been badly prepared and that the proper evidence was not prepared. His final conclusions about the evidence presented was that DITAC was totally discredited. He stated:

It is my strong opinion that there was a duty cast upon those whose responsibility it was to prepare the statements for the prosecution, to have done so objectively and with no other motive than to disclose facts which were a fair representation of those facts. In my opinion, this was not done.

The Minister seems to think that it is quite satisfactory for him to stand aside and to say that it is not his problem. Under our system of government, when this sort of thing has been going on for over a 12-month period, for the Minister to say that he was not aware of any of this impropriety, nor of the agreement itself until he read about it in an article by Bruce Jones in the Sun-Herald the Sunday before last, is simply not acceptable. There were articles that were published in 1988 that were clearly leaked by Customs, and there were articles published in 1989, and still the Minister did not bother. This is only one example.

Let us look again at the way in which the offsets and partnerships in development schemes have been administered. We are asked by the Minister time and time again to trust the statements that he makes which say that partnership in development agreements are being honoured and that we are all benefiting from them. To disclose the particulars would mean very simply that he would be disclosing commercial-in-confidence material and he could not possibly do that.

This is only one example. We should look again at the way in which the offsets and partnerships in development schemes have been administered. We are told by the Minister time and again that we have to trust the statements that he makes that partnerships in development agreements are being honoured and that we are all benefiting from them. To disclose the particulars would mean very simply that he would be disclosing commercial in confidence material and he could not possibly do that.

But that did not prevent him back in 1989 from publishing a press release which said that nine of these wonderful people who are in partnerships in development had been performing well. The only trouble was that a minute from one of his departmental advisers-one Mr Constable, who works for Dr Fitzpatrick who has been moved-advised the Minister that if he couched his press release in particular terms he would camouflage the fact that three of those partnerships in development were not meeting their targets.

One of those partnerships was Hewlett-Packard. And guess what? The Minister is now threatening at this stage to cancel the agreement with Hewlett-Packard because it is not meeting its targets. This has been known for over 12 months. Yet, there was in effect an attempt to cover that up too. Now we see that several members of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce are about to go off to the United States of America and have a quick chat with Hewlett-Packard to see whether anything can be done about it.

I must say that 20 minutes is a very short time in which to go through the sorts of things where opportunity has been wasted. Senator Button has garnered for himself a reputation as a Minister, it has been said, who is prepared to speak the truth. Indeed, he has meddled in other people's departments, much to the chagrin of the Treasurer, who has put his thoughts on the record.

But the point is this: if this country is to get out of its malaise, if we are to see an improvement in our manufacturing sector, we have to have policy developed in a sensible way in which we see the implementation of the Garnaut report and the phasing out of protection. We do not want the sort of statement that appears in today's Sydney Morning Herald where the Minister says, `What we need is a more sophisticated debate on protectionism that neither Garnaut nor the Pappas-Carter report has offered in terms of a final solution'. That will not do either. But fundamentally we have to have a Minister who is in control of his own department.

The Minister said in answer to a question today that we had spent four hours on the Midford case. It was 2 1/2 hours. But three quarters of an hour was spent just trying to elicit some information. I suggest that if the Minister could take four hours out and spend it in his Department getting on top of the way things are administered, perhaps we would not have to spend so long trying to get the answers to questions.
Because the Minister is not here, we are going to hear from Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh will no doubt tell us in his own inimitable way that this is an unwarranted attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Principally, it is a waste of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say in opening that I had assumed that the Opposition was keen to see this debate advance, but I am disgusted with the sorts of tactics that we have just experienced.
