—To debate the issue would have been an excellent idea.

—I can see that Senator Baume is keen to continue the tactics of the last few moments. The matter before us is one with which in some respects we can certainly agree: there has been an abject failure on the part of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in relation to the achievement of his policies and the achievement of real economic benefits. But we must point out that we have great difficulty in separating the patterns of Senator Button's progress from those of the Government of which he is a member. Quite clearly, both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating in that triumvirate of a disaster have a great deal to share in relation to the consequences which Australia now bears.

SPEECH.PARA: Our foreign debt has grown to some $8,000 per person-man, woman and child-higher than it has ever been; our interest rates are still high and remain high; contrary to the figures which Senator Walsh used a few moments ago, there is at present growing unemployment; and the degree of foreign ownership is growing apace and this Government and indeed the Opposition seem little concerned as to either the degree or the nature of that foreign ownership.

We have seen as a direct consequence of government policy, a deregulatory policy, that in just the last few weeks some $6 billion has been lost by the Bond and Elliott group of companies, adding very significantly to our foreign debt. I draw attention to the fact that those losses resulted substantially in the loss of assets which had been owned by Australians for well over 100 years. I refer to the breweries. As a consequence of those losses, which again relate to the deregulatory, laissez faire policies of this Government, those assets have substantially passed into foreign hands.

The basic assumptions on which the Government is operating, and on which the Opposition would operate if it were the Government, are deeply flawed. We in the Australian Democrats find little difference, except in the frills and trimmings around the edges, between the basic attitudes of the Government and the Opposition. They are in favour of a deregulated market system and leaving it to the market to get the economic job done. It is manifestly obvious that that process will not get the job done, either in the important social environment sense, of which I will speak later, or even in the conventional economic sense, and I have mentioned that a number of the indices of economic welfare have indicated how poorly this Government has performed.

As I have said previously in this chamber, it should be quite obvious to anybody who thinks for a moment that the market system will not serve the interests of a society. It surprised me that for so long the idea of Adam Smith's invisible hand guiding the operation of competitive greed towards the serving of the the common good should have received even a modicum of attention and respectability, yet it appears in most textbooks in economics and clearly lies behind the attitudes to market systems of the Government and particularly the Opposition, which we hear from more often to the effect that the market system will serve the common good. There is, of course, no a priori reason whatsoever why the operation of competitive greed should serve the common good. A moment's reflection would indicate that that is a self-evident truth.

It is also quite clear that the market which is so vaunted by the Government and the Opposition depends absolutely on perfect and instantaneous knowledge of the factors which go into that market being available universally. That, clearly, is a condition which is not met and cannot be met in any normal human society.

It is also possible to model the market system mathematically. When one does that one can show quite explicitly that the so-called perfect market is indeed at its most unstable when it operates in that ideal form, and that it will quite rapidly hunt towards a monopoly situation. In practice, markets hunt vary rapidly towards monopoly situations. When one looks at the operation of market systems in Australia, that is precisely what one observes. As the Government has deregulated and left things more to the market, we have seen the paper shufflers move in and obtain monopoly positions in so many markets, with disastrous consequences for this country.

I stress that, while we agree with the basic proposition which the Opposition is putting, we do not find it any better than the Government and we believe that it may be a great deal worse than the Government. There are still a few remnant restraining forces in the Government that prevent the complete collapse of responsibility towards the operation of a laissez faire market system.

Market systems, of course, do efficiently allocate resources, but that is not to say that they do it equitably. One need only consider for a moment the provision of useful goods and services to the poor and useless goods and services to the rich. The operation of the market will always allocate resources to the provision of those useless goods and services to the rich, because they can afford to pay for them. So, while the market system is efficient, it is not equitable-a point which seems to have been overlooked by both the Government and the Opposition.

Moreover, there is no mechanism from within the market itself by which the optimal size of any particular market can be judged. Markets have a tendency to grow, and growth, as I have pointed out on many other occasions, is itself a very damaging phenomenon when markets grow beyond the optimum size, beyond the size required by society or beyond the size which is sustainable by the environment which must necessarily supply the basic resources which go into the provision of those goods and services and must absorb the pollution which flows from the production of those goods and services. So there are obvious and provable deficiencies in the market system which seem to have been overlooked entirely by the Government and by the Opposition.

If one looks to the economy in the way in which we are this afternoon, reflecting on the efficiency or otherwise with which Senator Button has administered his portfolio, one must have some perception of the sort of future we will inevitably move into 15 or 20 years down the track or what sort of society we would like to create 15 or 20 years down the track. I am one who believes that, rather than simply letting the future happen, one should attempt to design the future that one wants and then move industry, move legislation, move societies and move the economic parameters towards that optimal view.

There are, of course, a number of approaches that one can take. One can take the utopian approach: invent a future and make it happen willy-nilly. That, of course, is precisely what we have seen attempted to be imposed throughout eastern Europe. It was thought that one could impose a pattern from on high and that somehow by that process one could make it happen. We have seen exactly what happens in those circumstances-utopians very rapidly descend into bloody revolution and the suppression of individual freedom.

One can use the pragmatic approach. This is precisely the approach which is used by the Government and which would be used by the Opposition; that is, look at the system as it is, turn whatever seems to be advantageous in the short term to advantage, and then to hell with the long term consequences. There is no conception whatsoever of the sort of society in which we would like to live 20, 30 or 40 years down the track.

We may, of course, also adopt a problem-solving approach to the future, one which takes a pragmatic view but attempts, using some criterion of social benefit, to sort out the discontinuities as they arise, or one may take the approach which the Democrats would strongly recommend; that is, a comprehensive approach which seeks to take all the best advice from all sources and out of that design a future.

This Government, however, has made it impossible to use that latter approach because it has surrounded itself quite clearly by a group of sycophantic, philosophical clones of itself. Those are the sorts of people from whom it is getting the advice. Needless to say, that advice reflects its own prejudices and it is caught in a spiral from which it is incapable of escaping.

What are the determinants of the world of tomorrow if the Minister is really going to address his portfolio responsibilities with an eye to the world in which we would like to live? The most fundamental change which needs to be made is a change in the attitude which we bear in our relationship to our environment; the environment which supplies the resources on which industry itself is based. It has become quite clear, and I think even the Government is now dimly aware through its publication of a sustainable economy draft paper, that we do need to change the attitude which we have to the environment. It is the environment after all which makes available resources on which industry is ultimately based and without which industry could not function at all.

When we look at the way in which industry in recent years has used the environment, we find such problems as massive ozone depletion. This situation has arisen because we thought that we could use these new chemicals-chlorofluorocarbons-in the 1930s; we continued to expand their use throughout the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s without thinking for a moment what happens to the environment as a consequence of their release. We now know that we have locked ourselves into a situation-Montreal protocol notwithstanding and the very best intentions in the world-where ozone depletion will continue to grow throughout probably most of the years of the next century, with quite unknown but probably quite disastrous consequences on a whole range of industries.

The Government itself has recognised that greenhouse is the most important environment problem of our time, and yet we find that Senator Button, who controls a lot of industry which has to do with greenhouse emitting industries, has studiously avoided intruding any consideration of greenhouse in such things as the much vaunted Button car plan. Indeed, just last week when I asked Senator Button a question specifically on this, he seemed to have difficulty in seeing the connection between motor vehicle efficiency in terms of fuel efficiency, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and economic efficiency in terms of the benefits which would flow to Australia by going down the greater efficiency road. Moreover, he went on and pointed out that it really was not his responsibility to do anything about carbon dioxide emissions by motor vehicles and that this was really a State responsibility. Without having any further time, Mr Acting Deputy President, I point out that this is just one indication on the inefficiency of this Minister.

He advocates at least stabilising the level of production, if not reducing it over a period of time. What that means is that for each and every Australian there will be less of the cake to go around.

It means that for the next generation of Australians there will be fewer of the advantages of life; there will be fewer of the comforts; and there will be fewer of the things that we take for granted. What it will mean-if we follow Senator Coulter down the rosy path that he so frequently advocates here in this chamber-is selling short the next generation of Australians, selling short some of the people who sit in this gallery today, and saying to them, `No, you cannot have a job', because Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats do not believe we should allow the productive capacity of this country to expand beyond what they consider to be an optimal size.

TALK.START.PARA: —The environment is saying it.

—Finally Senator Coulter has chipped in with the words `the environment dictates it'. Well fine, let us talk about the mining industry and let us talk about the environment. Frankly, I have been sitting in this chamber now since May listening to what Senator Coulter has said, and finally I get the opportunity to address some of the claptrap that he has been talking about in all that period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to talk about the mining industry and the environment, let us just get one fact straight, that is, the total area of Australia's land mass which is disturbed by the mining industry is half of the area that is covered by Australia's national highway. If one thinks about that four- or five-metre strip of bitumen that runs along the coast, one thinks what a tiny insignificant area of the Australian landscape that is, and if one then takes half of that, that is the area of Australia's land mass that Senator Coulter says dictates that the next generation of Australians should be without jobs because it suits his idea about optimal production.

I am afraid that the next generation of Australians does not agree with Senator Coulter, and more than that, the generation after it and the generation after it do not agree either, because ultimately my generation and those which follow me will have to pay the bill for the failed policies that Senator Coulter advocated here, if he ever gets the chance to put them into effect. I am pleased to say that the people of Australia will hopefully have the good sense not to let Senator Coulter put his plans into effect.

But unfortunately, the people of Australia have given Senator Button seven years to attempt to put a policy together. What we have failed to see from Senator Button in all of his seven years is any responsible administration of his portfolio, and what we have failed to see is one benefit from an industry policy from the Minister, who is so conspicuously absent from the chamber this afternoon when we are discussing his performance over the last seven years. We are reviewing the last seven years of his supposed performance, and he does not even have the good grace or the courtesy to be present in the chamber for at least the slightest period of time. That shows the degree of regard that Senator Button has for the criticisms that come from this chamber.

I have got to remark on some of the things that Senator Walsh said. Most of it was vitriol and I do not intend to deign Senator Walsh's vitriol with comment, but he did bring up a couple of points. The one point that he did manage to make was that in the period from 1983 until now, steel capacity production has increased from 175 tonnes per worker to 350 tonnes per worker. But if that is the case, we still fall well short of the level of production that exists in Taiwan, where steel workers every year produce on average in excess of 500 tonnes of steel production. So, I do not think that Senator Button can exactly write home about the enormous success of his steel plan.

Even if we assume that there has been an improvement in the level of steel production in this country, I do not believe that it is fair for the Senate to say that Senator Button or his policies were responsible for that increase in steel production. In fact, the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) found quite the opposite. It said, in a review of the steel plan in 1989, that the $117m of bounty payments made to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in that year had, `little effect', on the recovery of the steel industry. The BIE went on to conclude that rather than the plan, the improved industry performance was due much more to a recovery in world steel markets and a depreciation of the Australian dollar. I do not think Senator Button, for all of the miracles that that side of the chamber may vest in him-and goodness gracious, the Government has to find one Minister on that side of the chamber who has the tiniest bit of credibility-in spite of all the miraculous powers that may be claimed for Senator Button, I do not think it could be claimed that he is responsible for the recovery in world steel markets.

The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) also says that the steel industry's recovery was a result of the depreciation of the dollar and strong growth in world economies rather than the steel plan. In all the 20 minutes that Senator Walsh had, he came up with only one area where he thought that Senator Button might be responsible for some improvement in Australia's economic performance-and goodness gracious, we have found that that is false as well. That does not bode terribly well for the case that that side of the chamber is going to make out today.

The real problem that the Government has was so ably exemplified by Senator Walsh because he took us back, as Senator Button would do, to the Fraser years. I would like to take the opportunity of pointing out to Senator Walsh and Senator Button-hopefully he will read Hansard tomorrow-and to everybody else in this chamber, that I was in primary school during the Fraser years and the mindset that afflicts that side of the chamber, this perpetual harping back to the Fraser years, this desire to blame everything including the current high interest rates on the Fraser years, is the problem which is afflicting this country. What the Government is failing to do eight years on from the Fraser period is to start to address the problems that this country has.

In this respect I agree with Senator Coulter that the high interest rate policy that that side of the chamber has inflicted upon the Australian people for the last two years has been the reason why we have seen an enormous growth in Australia's foreign debt, why we have seen so many manufacturing industries go down the chute, and why we have seen so many cheap imports come flooding into this country. Finally, we may be seeing some sort of improvement in interest rates. But no matter how far the Government has brought the interest rates back in the 10 months of this year-and let us not be deceived-there is still a long way to go.

In Estimates Committee A, as Senator Childs well knows, we heard from the officials in the Treasury Department that interest rates in Australia remain 8, 9 or 10 per cent above comparable interest rates in the United States. If we are going to talk about economic efficiency, if we are going to be talking about the efficiency of the manufacturing sector, we have to look at the cost of funding and it is very clear that Australian companies cannot compete with American companies when it costs an Australian company 9 or 10 per cent more every year to run its overdraft. That is really the reason why the manufacturing sector has declined under this Government and under this Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

Let us go through the much vaunted Button car plan. First perhaps we ought to talk about Senator Button's scuffle with Minister Kelly. Senator Button said quite recently that he was hoping profoundly that, `We are hanging on to the best, but there will be some good ones'- he was talking about businesses-`that will disappear. There is no doubt about that, and that concerns me'. Thank goodness for that. If it did not concern Senator Button, I would be even more worried. Minister Kelly came back to him and said, in tones rather reminiscent of Senator Coulter:
I think there may have been reasons why projects have been stalled at the moment. A lot has to do with economic factors rather than environmental factors.

Senator Button on that side tried to bring in some industry leaders to blame the failure of his industry policy on Minister Kelly. This is great teamwork, is it not? He tried to blame it on Minister Kelly. In fact, Minister Kelly came back and gave him a big slap across the face. It is interesting to note that the Garnaut report said that Australia should have a natural competitive advantage in so much as resources are very cheap, but that high transport costs, unreliability of supplies, poor quality, and a lack of marketing effort mean ultimately that Australia has very high production costs and ultimately that Australia is uncompetitive.

Let us move on to the car plan; let us move on to some of the things that Senator Button is supposed to have given this country in the last couple of years; let us talk about the production of cars in this country. Does the Senate realise that in this country it takes on average 40 hours of labour to build a car? In Japan in 1989 they turned out car after car after car not at 40 hours per car, not at 30 hours per car, not at 20 hours per car, but at 17 hours per car. It is believed that this year the Japanese will be able to turn out cars at the rate of 11 labour hours per car.

Is it any wonder, therefore, that Australia is uncompetitive in international terms? Is it any wonder that the price of cars in this country between 1985 and 1989 rose by 50 per cent when the consumer price index rose by only 36 per cent and when the average wage rose by only 31 per cent? That is why it takes more weeks of our labour, of our effort to buy a car now than it did in 1983. That is how the Minister has swindled us, that is how the Minister has diddled the Australian population, and that is why the much vaunted Button car plan is an abject failure, a total and utter failure, as is the case with so many aspects of the Minister's portfolio.

The Senate has gone through Estimates, it has seen so many of the absurdities of this Minister's portfolio. For example, there was the idea that consultants be paid in excess of $38,635 to produce a strategy against fraud. I asked, `Has the Department been victim to fraud before?' and the answer was, `No.' I asked, `Why did you commission the survey?' and the answer was that they wanted to prevent fraud. I said, `Okay, what have you done? I said:
What do we actually have? Do we actually have any changed procedures yet in place?

The answer was no, that they were looking at it but that they have not done anything about it yet. Senator Button has had seven years to look at the economic and industrial malaise of this country, and the fact that he has failed to produce any substantial improvement is the result of his term card and that is why his ministry has been an abject failure.

I remember very well that it was Senator Button who cajoled Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. (BHP) and the steel unions to change the structure in this country. The structure in BHP-for example, in Wollongong-has changed qualitatively and dramatically. It is a different world from the one that existed in the Fraser years. That is just one plan and, seeing as Senator O'Chee wants to mention it, it is an example of how this Government has achieved change. Indeed the plan has finished now. It has achieved its purpose of modernising the steel industry and allowing the people in that industry to have a different, better and more productive relationship in the future. That is the ans- wer to Senator O'Chee when he criticises that particular plan, because it will be there forever as an epitaph to the work of Senator John Button as the Minister.

The debate very quickly became one where the comparison had to be made between our Government and the previous Government. I thought we were going to have a pretty heavy program so I brought a lot of material into the chamber. But the only point that Senator Bishop raised was an article in the Sun-Herald of last Sunday week. We were told in that article that there was a secret deal made by the previous Liberal Party Leader heading the previous Government. He made a secret trade deal in 1979 in which that particular issue that Senator Bishop is so concerned about arose.

I thought that was like leading with one's chin because basically this issue arises because of the way the LiberalNational Party ran government in the past. Those parties did not have an effective industry policy. They had fixes and deals-in this case a deal made with hidden concessions to members of the Association of South East Asian Nations. It is no wonder the Government, when it had the choice of revealing this, according to Senator Bishop, was hesitant to divulge to other countries the way in which Australian governments have behaved in the past. This is at a time when we are trying worldwide to prevent the protectionism that envelops the world and trying to persuade people at the Uruguay rounds that in that world context we should have a better world where trade will be more free.

It is on that basis that we find the comparison is made. I would have thought that the last basis on which we should have a comparison in this country was when the Liberal Party was trying to bury its past, the memory of the Fraser Government and the fact that the Fraser Government did not have a cohesive policy. Whoever got to the Minister for industry or the Prime Minister last, because often they were in conflict, was the person who would get the policy. There was no vision, no plan, no national perspective. If there is one person in industry who since 1983 has been associated with a perspective of change for industry, it is Senator John Button.

I notice that the staffing ratio of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is leaner and is coming down. I looked at the figures for the Department and found that actual staffing is down from 1,175 people in August 1987 to 849 people at present. There has also been a scaling down in the portfolio generally from 16,648 people to 15,801. It is a more efficient, leaner department, and I believe it does not deserve the unfounded criticism that Senator Bishop is continually making.

In terms of the overall issue, Senator Bishop and Senator O'Chee have simply thrown in a couple of sections for discussion. Senator Bishop in her own obsessional way continues to burrow away hoping that she will find something in some obscure issue such as this mistake of the Fraser Government. That, of course, has been exposed in a court case but it is not significant in the overall position that the Australian industry faces today. I want to point out to Senator O'Chee, who said that there were no benefits from Senator Button's ministry, the many benefits and to make a comparison with the situation under the coalition Government. While Senator O'Chee pleads youth, he has got to learn. I am sure that he is concerned with history.

This is what any examination shows us: under the coalition Government from 1976-77 to 1982-83, real annual average growth in manufacturing output was one per cent and this compares 3.4 per cent under the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Government from 1983-84 to 1989-90. Similarly, the annual employment growth in manufacturing has gone from minus 1.2 per cent under the Liberal-National Party Government to more than 0.8 per cent under the present Government with John Button as the Minister.

Comparing the number of jobs created or destroyed in manufacturing in the first year compared with seven years in office, in the period of the Fraser Government the figure was minus 122,000 and more than 65,000 in the period of the Hawke Government. The real annual average growth of manufacturing investment was 4.6 per cent in the Liberal period. It is now 8.2 per cent. The real annual average growth of manufacturing exports has doubled from 3.2 per cent to 7.6 per cent. I am sure that if one individual is responsible for that it is Senator John Button who has constantly gone around this country, talking with people and encouraging people to increase manufacturing exports.

Exports, as a percentage of manufacturing output-as an average over the period-was 14 per cent under the Liberal Government and 17 per cent under the Labor Government. The growth of manufacturing output prices was 10.7 per cent under the Fraser Government and 6.2 per cent under the Labor Government. The number and percentage of manufacturing work force unemployed, at the end of seven years in office, was 131,300 in February 1983, or 11.5 per cent, and 51,800, or 4.2 per cent, in December 1989.

Research and development in manufacturing as a percentage of manufacturing value added was 0.8 per cent under the Fraser Government. It is now 1.3 per cent. Industrial disputes in manufacturing; working days lost per 1,000 employees-perhaps the most critical and dramatic comparison between the two governments-on an annual calendar year average over the seven-year period, in mixed manufacturing was 915 under the Liberal Government and 262 under the Labor Government. In metals engineering it has come down from 1,297 to 341 under the Labor Government.

You cannot have it any other way. Senator O'Chee lays the challenge to us. What I am saying is that on all that criteria Senator John Button is a successful Minister. He has those achievements as his primary responsibility and there is great credit to him for the work he has done in that area.

Senator Bishop, in dealing with the company in Malaysia, felt that she should have more information, as she has on a number of occasions. Mr Kelly, the senior officer in the Australian Customs Service, did not give her the answers that she wanted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't give any answers.

—He was the officer in overall charge, but the important point I want to make about this case-and I do not think that it is worth going into the great detail that Senator Bishop, with her obsessional interest, is inclined to give the matter-is that the Australian Customs Service had carriage of the case until it put the matter to the Director of Public Prosecutions. I think that it is best summed up in the transcript of the proceedings of Estimates Committee A in a simple statement made by the Minister, Senator Button. This comment came after Senator Button was asked continual questions, and indeed the same question in a number of different ways:

SPEECH.PARA: As you have already pointed out, Customs conducted an investigation into this matter and the Director of Public Prosecutions instituted the proceedings.
I think that Senator Bishop's attack on the Customs Service is misplaced, because it is the Director of Public Prosecutions who has carriage of the legal issues involved.

Of course, cases are lost. The Commonwealth is continually taking cases which in various degrees are right or wrong. A percentage of them might sometimes be unfair, but I think that it is wrong to say that Customs has persecuted somebody. I believe in the integrity of the Attorney-General's Department and the Director of Public Prosecutions and believe that they would examine every case that came before them. I believe that they act only when they have carefully sifted the information and brought it to the appropriate tribunal. Therefore, it is quite wrong for Senator Bishop to read into that any impropriety when she has not established anything as being untoward or wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on the record that they did not do the work properly.

—Senator Bishop is interjecting, but I am saying that if it were to be a criticism of Senator Button, then Senator Bishop has failed. If the word `failure' in terms of this debate can be applied to anybody, Senator Bishop has singularly failed to dent the excellent reputation of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and she will have to try again and seek to be more substantial in any challenge she makes than she has been on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, as the Deputy President said earlier, has ranged far and wide, but Government speakers have yet to provide any concrete evidence to rebut our proposition that Senator Button has failed to responsibly oversee the administration of his portfolio. They have failed to provide any evidence that his industry policy has achieved any real economic benefits for Australia. I will go on to describe why that is the case a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for everyone to understand that if one has an industry policy or indeed a policy in any area of government, one should have some objectives. Indeed, if the objectives of this Government and of Senator John Button's industry policy are clear to someone else, they are certainly not clear to me. If I were looking at industry policy, I would be looking firstly to broaden our manufacturing and industrial base; to establish-to use one of the Minister's favourite cliches-an export culture; to reduce reliance on government, that is, to reduce featherbedding; and basically to make industry more self-reliant. Obviously, as well, I would seek import substitution so that Australian manufacturers produce things that we can consume within our own borders and therefore help our trade balance problems, and, on the human scale, where it really counts, to increase employment opportunities and, furthermore, employment options in order to broaden the places where young Australians can be employed. I think those are a fairly good set of broad objectives. I am not sure what the Government's industry policy objectives are, and perhaps the next Government speaker will enlighten us.

One would then look to the modus operandi by which one would achieve those sorts of objectives. I would have thought that an important way of going about that is to have a coherent and consistent policy-and of course that is one thing that this Government has not achieved. Indeed, if one looks through the reams and reams of media commentary on this Government's industry policy, one sees that consistency is certainly one thing that will not be found. Every day in the newspapers one sees article after article trying to figure out what tariff policy will be, what protection policy we are to have, what interest rate policy there will be, which industry is to be bailed out next-will it be Kodak or someone else? The question is also asked whether the car companies are to be given another billion dollars next month. Certainly consistency and coherency are not part of this Government's policy and of its modus operandi in achieving those national objectives.

Senator Childs said earlier that Senator Button was a respected Minister and had a great national perspective. But I would like the next Government speaker to say what that national perspective is. If Senator Button does have a national perspective, his achievement of that national perspective or national vision has certainly not been made evident. As I have said, I shall get on to that a little later. Senator Childs-and I thank him for doing so-has at least given some statistical evidence of what has happened in the past seven years, and I shall refer to those statistics later.
The other modus operandi that I would suggest as a good idea is to have a fair policy and a policy that does not pick winners. As the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said in this morning's Australian:
I've never been in the winner-picking business. I don't think governments are good at it.
I think that he is quite right. Certainly the winners that he has been trying to pick have been coming home at the back of the field.

TALK.START.PARA: —Collingwood got up.
—Yes, that was a good shot. That certainly is part of the policy that should be applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of picking winners, the Government has picked the car industry and given it a lot of support. We are still debating what that support level will be after 1992, and no doubt in November we will probably have some indication of that. My colleague Senator O'Chee has already gone through the failure of the car plan. It has failed to achieve all the objectives that Senator Button set out for it in 1984 in terms of price, quality and affordability. I notice that neither Senator Walsh nor Senator Childs referred to that. They both referred to the steel plan and a few other things. Perhaps the next Government speaker will wish to discuss what he sees as the success of the car plan.

The car plan does have some successes because it gave another photo opportunity for Senator Button. If there is one thing that he is very successful at achieving, it is photo opportunities. None of us will forget his appearing with models. I imagine he will be appearing with rock and roll stars now as they send off their albums to the Soviet Union. We remember Senator Button sitting in a Capri car without his seat belt on. Whenever an Australian product actually gets through the mire of government red tape and regulation, environmental inquiries, taxation matters and everything else that poor Australian manufacturers have to get through to get their product out and down to the wharf and, if they are lucky, off the wharf and out through the harbour mouth, there is one thing one can be assured of: there will be one person down at the wharf to say goodbye to the product, be it a Ford Capri, a dress or a record, and it will be Senator Button. He is very good at turning up when a product actually gets through that forest of government- imposed impediments to exporting. He will always be down there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called marketing.

—He does it well. That is the great achievement of the Button industry policy. He would have the public believe-not even the Treasurer, Mr Keating, believes it is true-that he has been successful and that he is a respected Minister. The facts belie the achievement. That is the whole reason we are debating this matter today.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing we would have is a micro- and macro-economic policy that complemented the industry plan. Anyone who follows industry policy will realise that those people involved in manufacturing, in Australian industry, continue to decry this Government's promises on micro-economic reform. The Government's last term in government was supposed to be the era of micro-economic reform. We are now promised that this one will be. We will not hold our breath. The other part is macro-economic policy. It is hard to reduce tariffs, it is hard to reduce protection, when we have high interest rates, a high dollar and all the impediments in the transport sector, the waterfront and all the other areas which make it difficult to be competitive in Australia.

The achievements we have heard of to date are in the steel plan. My colleague Senator O'Chee has effectively debunked any success that the Government can claim in steel exports. The Executive General Manager of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd was reported in this morning's paper-I think it was the Australian-as criticising Government policy. He is reported as saying:
Stop-start policies have had the impact of moving resources in search of speculative rewards and away from competitive pressures associated with the opening up of the economy.

He was quite pessimistic about the outlook for steel production and said that the productivity gains in the steel industry, which Senator Walsh referred to, do not match international competitive pressures. It is an important point to make that, in so many of the measures to which Senator Walsh and Senator Childs referred, we have marginal gains, tiny gains-in most cases less than one per cent-be it in productivity or competitiveness, but that the field is moving and that we are competing against a world that is racing ahead of us. David Kearns, Chairman of the Xerox Corporation, has said:
We realise we are in a race without a finish line. As we improve, so does our competition. Five years ago, we would have found that disheartening. Today we find it invigorating . . .

It is good to find someone who is invigorated about this race. For example, whereas we have found productivity gains of less than one per cent across manufacturing industry, our competitors in Europe achieve gains of 3 per cent and 3.8 per cent per annum and our competitors in Japan and South East Asia are achieving productivity gains of 5.8 per cent. Every year we are falling behind 3 per cent or 4 per cent.

If the Government wants to claim that as an achievement of Senator Button's industry ministry and as economic benefits for Australia, that is fine. I guess that we are creeping ahead, but it is similar to rowing flat out up the middle of a river in the tide and making headway of one inch every couple of hours while one's competitor is rowing alongside the river bank where there is no tide and racing ahead. Within a few short years that competitor will be 10 miles ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have lost the race.

—That is what has happened in Australia. As Senator Patterson has just said, Australia is losing the race. If our criteria of achievement in productivity and competitiveness are to be measured against the figure of zero per cent, we are achieving: we are getting figures of about one per cent productivity and a little competitiveness here and a bit there. Meanwhile, all of the economic commentators are saying that we are going backwards. The Business Council Bulletin refers to a report by the Australian Manufacturing Council which, without going through the statistics and to quickly summarise the article, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia performs poorly as a manufacturing country on all four criteria measured. It has the lowest value added per employee; the worst export/import ratio; the lowest contributor to GDP; the second greatest decline in competitiveness.
That is what the Australian Manufacturing Council found in the survey that it provided as late as November last year. There are some criteria.

I have already referred to growth in exports. Senator Childs claimed that there had been growth in exports, but again that must be measured against our growth in imports and must be measured against our trade deficit across the whole economy. The figures of the blow-out in our international indebtedness would certainly show that manufacturing is not pulling its share.

The final point I want to make relates to the overall achievements of the Button ministry. Our contention is that his policy has failed to deliver real economic benefits to Australia. It has been a failed policy for eight years. Honourable senators can look back and compare it with the Fraser years, if they want; but it would be better to compare it with the policies that the coalition now offers. The Government has had eight years to make achievements. Those achievements have been less than marginal; those achievements have been a dismal failure, on any comparison on a world basis-and we are looking at international competitiveness as the only true measure. I am suggesting that Senator Button and the Government, nearly eight years from when they started fiddling with industry, must figure out where they have gone wrong.

There has been much speculation about Senator Button's future in this place. That speculation includes suitors to his portfolio and suitors to his leadership in the Senate. There would be no shortage of people wanting to take his seat. Over the Christmas period, if he lasts that long, Senator Button will have to think seriously about whether he wants to seriously reappraise the lack of achievement over the last eight years and re-jig the entire policy, or whether he gives the game away and goes into private industry or into retirement and hands over the reins to Simon Crean, perhaps.

The important point is that we have had eight years of failure. The Government has a couple of short years in which to try to fix things up. Rather than stand on its record, which has been shattered and which is a dismal record by any world comparison, we need to ensure that that reappraisal takes place. I will not rebut any of the innuendo and the vitriol from Senator Walsh. I have already discussed the points made by Senator Childs. I will conclude by saying that no real economic benefits have been delivered to Australia by the Government's industry policy, and certainly the Minister has been irresponsible in overseeing the administration of his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some pretty scratchy matters of public importance put up for discussion in my 3 1/2 years in the Senate, but this one comes very close to taking the cake as being of utter inconsequence. It seems to have come about because, as I understand it, Senator Bishop, who tries to prove herself the terror of the Estimates committees, could not get some answers. Having listened to some of the debate from the Opposition-unfortunately, a standing committee commitment meant that I could not hear all of the debate-I have heard absolutely nothing to justify the terms of the reference of this matter of public importance.
—What committee was that?

—I was chairing a private hearing of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for over two hours. For Senator Patterson's information, we were having a briefing from Chris Lamb, the ministerial counsellor in the Australian Embassy in Washington who is in charge of congressional liaison. It was much more worth while listening to that in the past hour than listening to any Opposition senators, because Mr Lamb actually gave practical examples of what diplomats such as himself are doing to improve Australia's trade performance in the United States markets.

SPEECH.PARA: The position was created by this present Government. It has the support of some members of the Liberal Party of Australia. Senator David MacGibbon has been a strong supporter of the position. I found listening to Mr Lamb's remarks much more useful than hearing the remarks of the previous speaker, who spoke with all the charisma or passion of a cow pat in trying to explain why Senator Button had not delivered the goods in his portfolio.

I am happy to speak very positively in defence of Senator Button. No Minister for business and industry in Australia's history has done as much and as consistently. Senator Button has worked hard to get the culture of this country in manufacturing and industry turned away from being insular and introverted to being an export oriented sector of our economy. Let us compare the record of the mob opposite when they were in government for 30 of the last 40 years with the 10 years that we have had in government, particularly the last seven years. The figures are quite startling. I suspect that some of these figures were cited previously by speakers from the Government side in this debate, but I would like to emphasise them. Real average growth in manufacturing output in the Fraser years was one per cent; in the Labor years it was 3.4 per cent. Annual average employment growth in manufacturing in the Fraser years was minus 1.2 per cent; in the Labor years it was plus 0.8 per cent. In the Fraser years 122,000 jobs were destroyed in manufacturing; in the Labor years, 65,000 jobs were created-and so it goes on. In every indicator the present Government is superior to the Fraser Government.

If honourable senators want to go back and talk about tariff cuts and reductions, they should remember that after 23 years of a coalition government the first government in Australia's history to reduce tariffs was the Whitlam Government with a 25 per cent across-the-board cut in tariffs without a tackle and nothing being taken on by the previous coalition government during the Menzies, Holt, Gorton and McMahon years. It took the Whitlam Government to do it. There is no doubt that it created stress in the community. It cost the Australian Labor Party many votes and probably helped in the short term to put us out of government in 1975, but it was a breakthrough in economic thinking that we could actually reduce tariffs in Australia and not put them up as the way to overcome economic problems. I do not think it is necessary for us to listen to the bleatings from the Opposition that John Button and the Labor Government have failed in the administration of this important area of activity in the economy.

I want to deal with four areas in particular where I think the record of John Button is exemplary. I will deal, firstly, with the steel industry. Senator Campbell made some mention in his remarks about the steel industry. I will quote two paragraphs from a press release put out by BHP Steel dated 18 September 1990. In refuting some of the critiques made of BHP Steel it states:

Productivity at BHP Steel had risen from 175 tonnes per employee per year in 1983 to about 350 tonnes per employee per year currently, a 100% increase. BHP Steel is on track to meet a target of 500 tonnes per employee per year at its Port Kembla works by 1991 and a year later at its other steelmaking centres at Whyalla and Newcastle.

BHP Steel in the last financial year maintained its position as the third most profitable steel producer in the world, behind only the Government-owned China Steel Corporation of Taiwan and the speciality producer Nisshin of Japan. Its profit performance in the last two financial years had been the highest on record. The 1988-1989 profit result for the Steel Group had more than doubled the previous year.
BHP Steel has been nominated for an Austrade export award last week and was currently exporting at least 22% of total steel despatched tonnes. It is a committed, long-term exporter.

The statement from BHP Steel absolutely proves that the steel plan introduced in 1983 stopped the steel industry from going bankrupt and disappearing in Australia, got it reinvigorated, and now it is able to stand on its own two feet as one of the world's major competitive and efficient steel producers.

People do not realise that today more people are employed in shipbuilding in Australia than were employed 10 years ago. Though, unfortunately, the major shipbuilding industry in Whyalla, my own State, may have closed, still more people are employed in shipbuilding because we have gone out and sought markets where we can provide our skills in special areas of shipbuilding. This newly developed Australian shipbuilding industry has grown to such an extent that vessels under construction and on order exceeded $600m as at 30 June 1989 and more than half of the vessels were intended for export markets.

The industry has successfully entered a number of niche markets for luxury motor yachts, specialised fishing vessels and high speed catamarans. Ten years ago under the former Government the shipbuilding industry disappeared in this country, but we now have a shipbuilding industry that is delivering the goods, particularly in export markets.

I come from a State which has played a significant role in producing cars. In 1982-83 under the Fraser Government, the car industry in South Australia was basically on its uppers. It was destitute, it was all but bankrupt, it had no future and no optimism, but the car industry plan of the present Government under John Button's leadership turned all that around. Who would have thought 10 years ago that a car industry, even in my State, would be exporting car components to Japan and that the Australian car industry would be exporting cars to the United States? They are export earners.

Only last week Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd in South Australia announced that it would be increasing the export of its components to Japan and in doing so would enhance its ability to produce a new model Magna car, which will further consolidate Mitsubishi's place as a major car producer in Australia. This has meant that people have secure jobs in the car industry in South Australia and they have better jobs which provide better productivity and more satisfaction. A visit to a car factory in South Australia today compared with a visit 15 years ago is like comparing the latter part of the twentieth century with nineteenth century work practices.

The area I wish to conclude on, which I think offers a great opportunity- Senator Button has been involved in this-is the development of telecommunications policy. The other day I came across some information which said that in the first 100 years-or just over 100 years-of the availability of telephone services 400 million telephones had been connected around the world. It is estimated that in the next 15 years in Asia alone another 400 million telephones will be connected. In the next 15 years in one region of the world, the region closest to us, the number of telephones in the world will have doubled the number for the previous 100 years. This offers Australia enormous opportunities to expand its telecommunications industry in providing services, management and equipment to this most rapidly growing area. The decisions that the Government and the Labor Party took over the last month regarding telecommunications policy give us the best opportunity to get in and get a part of that market.

This is probably not well known in Australia because we often get criticised when we cannot compete with countries such as Taiwan, but Exicom, one of Australia's major telephone manufacturing companies, makes a million telephones a year under licence for Telecom Australia and is actually exporting that telephone very profitably to Taiwan. Why? The phone that it is providing to Taiwan is highly engineered. It is an excellent phone and does not break when dropped, kicked, or when the kids knock it off the table; it lasts well. As a result, there is a market for that sort of phone in the region where we are told that we cannot compete against manufactured goods from countries such as Taiwan.

Exicom made it quite clear in private discussions that I had with it that it sees itself in the future expanding its export market. Alcatel, another telecommunications company, also provides telephones under licence to Telecom Australia. This company has recently completed the construction of a $120m factory at Botany in Sydney at which it manufactures optic fibre trans-ocean cables. It will earn hundreds of millions of dollars over the next decade by manufacturing in this country, using the highest technology, cables which will be supplied competitively to the world. The company will employ people who will work in decent and interesting jobs. But, above all else, it will provide us with a base from which to expand our telecommunications exports.

Senator Button has argued throughout the telecommunications reform process of this Government that industry policy in telecommunications is absolutely paramount. We must not allow the opportunities of telecommunications reform to pass by and ignore the industry consequences. We should take decisions which will allow both public and private industry in Australia-particularly the private sector-to take a view that they have a role to play in providing telecommunications equipment, services and management and exporting them to the countries of our region. The decisions that we took in creating the biggest public enterprise in Australia by way of the merger of Telecom and OTC Ltd will give us the platform from which to go into the Asia region and be very successful in seeking markets.

The record of the previous Government indicates that all Opposition senators can put to us is a lot of hot air. I believe that the performance of Senator John Button is an outstanding highlight of the term of this Government. He is the first Minister responsible for business and industry who has had the energy and taken the effort to go out and try to change manufacturing culture in this country from being introverted and insular to being export oriented and extroverted as well as, to use the phrase, making us a clever country-a clever country that is able to export.
