DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to report No. 1 of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on Illegal Immigrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to say at the outset that I welcome the Government's response to the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I welcome its content. As Senator McKiernan would acknowledge, in many respects it coincides very closely with the dissenting report that my colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Ruddock, and I submitted. Senator McKiernan also put down a position that was very firm and steadfast. I am pleased to acknowledge the Government response to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the recommendations that have now been adopted by the Government can be described simply as sensible. As the Government response and the dissenting report that I supported stated, it is untenable that illegal immigrants should receive the prize of being allowed to live in Australia by breaking the law. It is loud and clear that we are not the lucky country for illegals and it is not before time that we sent that message to the rest of the world. Clearly, the response of the Government in this instance is the right one.

At last count we had well over 100,000 illegal immigrants; some believe as many as 150,000. I am gratified that the Government has not bowed to the exceptional, heavy pressure of the minority groups who were demanding the untenable absorption principle of `Stay five years. Pop up your head with some character references, and you can stay on'. That would have been untenable.

There is some middle ground in this regard, and that is the British model that accepts the principle that deportation is the first option for an illegal immigrant, but states that there are exceptions to the rules. However, in giving consideration to this subject, the Committee was not prepared, at the outset, to state that fundamental principle prior to putting down the exceptions to the rule. For that reason, my colleague Mr Ruddock and I submitted the dissenting report. I could not support the across-the-board absorption principle applying after a five year residency period.

I was dismayed that some sections of the Joint Standing Committee were swayed by this idea of segmenting illegals into `worthy' and `bad'. This was the main reason for the dissenting report. The Government rightly acknowledges that a number of dissenting reports relate to this first report. In a moment I will refer to the circumstances in which so many dissenting reports were part of that first report.

There cannot be good and bad illegals; they are law-breakers who show no respect for the rules of the country they profess to be their own. For us to accept that principle would be a slap in the face to many thousands of people throughout the world who are going through the long, slow and proper procedures to make Australia their home-they are the people who deserve adequate consideration in a matter such as this.

As a member of the Committee, I have heard many arguments over the Government's handling of the broader immigration issues. However, I also believe in giving credit where credit is due. The Government's response indicates that commonsense and compassion have been used in equal proportions to reach its latest changes to migration regulations. The commonsense is seen in there being no let-up in our determination to ensure that our immigration policies work properly and that families enter Australia through the proper channels. The commonsense is also there in handing out harsher penalties for those who harbour or employ illegals.

Part of the press release of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) dated yesterday-I assume it was released either late last night or early this morning-indicates a firmness in that approach. I welcome and encourage that. I hope that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, in its enforcement section, applies that principle in the future. The only way that we will get a clear, unambiguous, concise message to the community at large, not only to those who are here illegally but also to those who are harbouring illegals, is to indicate that we intend to treat them as people who have broken the law; and they ought to be treated as such. With more than 100,000 illegals in the country, clearly many people are deliberately harbouring and employing them. It is surely time to show that we mean what our regulations say; it is time to back them up in practice as well as preach that policy direction.

But compassion is there in the Government understanding and accepting that there is indeed a small group of people who are innocent illegals. In hearings of the Committee we heard many harrowing stories of such innocents. In a speech delivered to this chamber, I referred to several instances of young people innocently being caught; they are innocent illegals. These people were deserving of some compassion and consideration. I am pleased that a mechanism is to be put in place to give some discretionary powers to the Minister to take account of them. They deserve and should have all the help we can give them. Through no fault of their own, they, as individuals, are innocent illegals.

As well, compassion is to the fore when we come to the Minister's discretion. When dealing with people's lives, there will always be cases of exceptional circumstances. This means that the rules are meant to be bent, to take account of those circumstances that we, as legislators, simply cannot embody in any legislation or regulations. That is why a Minister's discretion is important in an area where we are dealing with people's lives.

However, I am wary of totally embracing that concept, no matter how compassionate. I know the pressure of lobbying on issues such as these. We have seen a number of cases-one notable case in recent weeks-in which ministerial discretion has been applied. I would hope that such decisions would in no way be political. It is important that they not be, as I believe the decision of several weeks ago was; that no Minister so entrusted would be swayed by the strength of any party or ministerial representation, but that any ministerial discretion employed or put in place would be based on the merit of the case and the argument put to the Minister. They are the bouquets to the Government for its response to our first report.

The rush with which the new immigration regulations were forced into operation, and continue to be pushed along, makes it all but impossible to work the issues through to ensure people's lives are treated with the awareness that they deserve. We are dealing with real people, not facts and figures. The December 1989 deadline means that we are now in a constant bandaid situation. That is a most undesirable set of circumstances that the Committee is faced with.

The rush on illegals for 31 October meant that the Committee's report was rushed and, as a result, ill considered in parts. That means that the Committee did not have the time to do its job properly, as it would have liked to have done. It meant many dissenting reports, which, in turn, must lead to some view of lack of credibility of the main report. Had more time been available, the Committee may have been able to come to a near-unanimous view, or at least a majority view without the number of dissenting reports. If my memory serves me correctly, there were five dissenting reports in this first report of the Joint Standing Committee. That is not a desirable circumstance for a report of a joint standing committee of this Parliament. A number of people put in a dissenting report simply because we were rushed as we had to meet these deadlines; we did not have an opportunity to analyse thoroughly and consider the merits of individual cases as we would have liked. We were not able to debate the issues to get an approach that was acceptable to the majority on the Committee.

I hope that more time and more resources will be available to that Committee when it looks at other areas such as humanitarian grounds and change of status-a number of areas will be before it in the ensuing months-so that it can undertake its task and report to the Parliament, having been able to analyse, very carefully and thoroughly, all the circumstances, all the evidence, that it could muster. By doing its job more efficiently, effectively and properly, it will be not only doing a service to the Committee but also serving the interests of this Parliament.

A committee report such as the one we have with dissenting reports leads, as the Minister noted in the comments that he made, to a lack of credibility on the part of the Committee. I am not saying that there was a lack of credibility as far as the Committee is concerned. What I am saying is that it leads to a perception of that as a result of those dissenting reports.

I certainly know that I speak for a number of my colleagues on the Committee when I say that we are determined to ensure that sensible, easily understood and firm but fair migration regulations are put in place. It may be a long haul, but there is no doubt in my mind that the good intention of all members of the Committee is to meet that particular objective. I can but hope that this response by the Government is an indication that many of us on all sides of politics share similar views and are working, and can work, together for the same objective.

The Minister's media release indicates a number of directions that I would like to comment on. Firstly, he is going to reduce the appeal system mechanism so that there is but one avenue of appeal in certain instances, that is, people go directly to second tier-instead of first tier and then second tier-which hopefully will have the beneficial effect of reducing the timeframe in which people have submissions before the Department for consideration, so that they will not use that timeframe to defer or prolong the day of decision as to whether they can stay in Australia.

The position as it relates to innocent illegals and employing ministerial discretion is, as I have said, an important step forward. We cannot legislate for all sets of circumstances in an area such as this. Therefore, for the unintended consequences of the legislation, the regulation, through using ministerial discretion, will enable the Government to make decisions that take into account those exceptional cases that were put before the Committee.

As the Minister rightly points out in his press release, there has been ample time-and there will be, through to December 1993-for people to present their cases and for innocent illegals to regularise their stay. The situation in which the majority of illegals have broken the law is well and truly past, according to the statement. That is the message that I think ought to be communicated clearly and concisely to the community. I might add that Senator McKiernan did that with a force and a conviction, not only at the committee hearings but certainly publicly. As a result, he received widespread publicity for a policy position that by and large I agree with, containing the exceptions to the rule which are now embodied in the Government's response to this first committee report.

I welcome this response from the Government. I think it shows commonsense. I think it shows compassion. I think it is an adequate, appropriate and effective response to the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I trust and hope that some of the concerns that I have expressed as they relate to the workload timeframe that the Committee has had to operate under in the past can be given adequate consideration in the future to ensure that we have adequate time and adequate resources to do the job thoroughly, effectively and properly, as I know each and every member of the Committee wants to undertake that task in that manner. That will serve the interests of the Parliament in a very appropriate way, a proper way and a way in which we ought to be servicing the needs of this Parliament. Therefore, I endorse the statement presented to the House today by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not welcome the response of the Government to report No. 1 of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations with the same degree of enthusiasm as Senator Olsen has just announced that he does, although at the same time I do not condemn the response. I am somewhat disappointed that the views which I put forward in my minority report were not, in total, taken up by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). I assert that my views were very well considered, were in the interests of Australia and were in the interests of those individuals from all over the world who want to come to this wonderful country. Indeed, as Senator Olsen mentioned, I got a reasonable amount of publicity because of the expressions of my views. I also got a considerable amount of public support from individuals who, in some instances, telephoned long distance to let me know that they supported the view that I put forward in my minority report. I welcome people when they express views in that manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we are debating a very important issue-Australia's immigration program. It is not simply a question of dealing with illegals because, whatever we do or whatever government does, this particular issue will have an impact on the total migration program. It is a program which is receiving its fair amount of publicity at the moment. The driving force behind the views that I expounded in the minority report-some of which, I might add, have been addressed by the Government in its response-was the integrity of the immigration program. I have a vested interest in that program because, as all honourable senators will know, I am myself a migrant. Indeed, people from different backgrounds make up a considerable proportion of the population of this country.

In expressing some disappointment at the Government's response, I do at the same time welcome it. I also accept that the Minister and, indeed, the Cabinet and the Government had a very difficult job, as Senator Olsen has said, to come forward with a view. As has been previously indicated, while it was a majority report, minority views came from four members of the Committee. There were actually five dissenting reports. There are many times when people make jokes known as Irish jokes. I suggest that this is a good one for me to keep in the files to use as a response. It is not an Irish joke, but perhaps it is a bit of a parliamentary joke. That is not in any way seeking to reflect on either House of Parliament.

It is a difficult report which the Minister had to address his mind to and those in the Department had to address their minds to. I think, on a very quick reading of the response that has just recently been tabled, that they have done a reasonable job of it. I am not totally endorsing all that is contained in it at the moment because I have not had the time to digest it and consider it in the depth that is necessary.

I will pick up one point that Senator Olsen started with about good and bad illegals. There are actually good and bad illegals, and I would assert that the good illegals are those who are illegal but who do not know that they are illegal. That was the matter upon which the Committee undertook its inquiry-innocent illegals, people who found themselves in that category but who had not gone into the category willingly: it was something that they were caught up with. I believe the Government has addressed that question and that those people, when they are found out-perhaps the right expression is `when they find they are in an illegal capacity'-will now have the ability to redress that situation and attempt to put themselves into a legal capacity in this country.

That was one of the major concerns that the Committee had in commencing the inquiry. Unfortunately, it was subsumed in a broader question of what we do with illegals totally. I think this is part of the problem of the time constraints that Senator Olsen has mentioned; and I agree with the comments that he put on the record here this afternoon. We were faced with almost impossible deadlines. I read the second draft of the final report on an aircraft coming over here on a Sunday night and had to attend a meeting early the next morning to go through that draft report, chapter and verse, to try to bring it into some order. It required two separate meetings on that date to do it.

The deadlines that we set ourselves or were in some way imposed upon us were almost impossible to meet. I am on the record of the Committee as indicating that I will not attempt to meet such deadlines in the future, because I do not believe that in the report we presented to this Parliament we did justice to the question that we were examining. I think the evidence of that is the fact that there were five separate dissenting reports to the majority report.

Speaking for myself, the views that I expressed in my dissenting report were views that I had consistently expressed from the beginning of the inquiry, and I doubt that, even given an extension of time, I would have been able to convince the majority of the Committee to go along with those views. But that is the way of committee work, and that is how we did work. In fact, as a committee we are working very well together. In saying that, I am not, as Senator Olsen was doing a short while ago, seeking in any way to intimate to the Senate that I am speaking on behalf of all of my colleagues on the Committee.

There is one other matter concerning the Minister's statement and the Government response that I want to address. One recommendation that I am particularly pleased has not been accepted is that concerning the principle of absorption. As I indicated earlier, probably eight of the 10 members of the Committee were in agreement with some form of the absorption principle. The majority report recommended a term of some five years, although I may be doing the Committee some injustice in that a couple of members expressed the view that a period of eight years in Australia might be more acceptable.

I oppose completely the principle of absorption. I think it is a reward for people who can prove over a sustained period that they are capable of breaching Australia's migration laws, and in doing so holding Australia's immigration system in contempt. The Minister and the Government have rejected the majority recommendation of the Committee, that a five-year absorption rule ought to apply, and I put it on the record that I am particularly pleased that that has happened. Inevitably, if it had been accepted by the Government we would have had people coming into this country, hiding for five years-hiding quite openly-and then making an application to stay.

I hope that when this response is reported in the media-and it deserves to be widely reported-those illegals and their supporters will take note of the fact that the Government is firm and committed to dealing with the problem. It is an immense problem, as is indicated on the first page of the response, where it is stated:
The increased number of illegal entrants, from 65,500 as at 19 December 1989 to some 90,000 as at 30 April 1990, is a serious development which must be met with firm and resolute action.

I hope that the Government will maintain its resoluteness in this matter, as it did in a recent episode at a market garden just north of Perth where 16 illegals were apprehended. I think that action of apprehending 16 individuals would have a far greater impact than on just those 16 people, because it proves to the community, both legal and illegal, that the Government is firm and resolute in dealing with the problem.

Finally, I wish to make one appeal to the various ethnic communities around Australia. Now is the time that they have to accept that the Government is firm in dealing with this problem. They in turn have a responsibility to advise people that they are aware are here in an illegal capacity that the best thing those individuals can do is either to depart Australia voluntarily or to make application under the further concessions that are now available to them to regularise their status. There is no point in their remaining hidden forever and living what must be for those people an appalling lifestyle. I thank the Senate and commend the Government's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the previous speakers in their expressions of qualified support for the Government's response to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I am perhaps not on all fours with all the comments they have made, and I will proceed to detail some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that ministerial discretion has been widened and preserved and that in particular attention will be given to a reform of the bail conditions which are available to illegal entrants in Australia. It was a blot on our judicial system that these were found wanting in the past, and I welcome the reform.

I am not so pleased that the Immigration Review Tribunal was not and is not to be given the task of assessing the status of illegal entrants. It seemed to the Committee-and I supported the majority view-that that Tribunal was eminently suited to that task, much more so than the of necessity lengthy process which these people have to go through when they take the bureaucratic route through the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, which has not always been even-handed in its treatment on the evidence of migrants, intending or illegal. That they have then to rely only on ministerial discretion seems to me to narrow the process and seems also to bear the seeds of long and weary delays.

Perhaps the most important qualification that I would wish to address is the rejection of the absorption principle. I certainly cannot agree with Senator McKiernan or Senator Olsen, nor can I agree with the way in which the recommendations of the Committee were represented in the Government's response. On page 2 of the Government's response it is quite clear that the Government is conjuring up the furphy that such a provision would offer the prospect to future illegal entrants of becoming absorbed, whereas it is quite clear from the recommendations of the Committee that the majority view favoured a qualification based on past presence in Australia of five years or more and a record of achievement and behaviour during that time which has made the people in question worthwhile citizens.

There is no suggestion in the recommendations of the Committee that this absorption principle is to be used as a guiding light for future decisions. It was quite clearly put forward in an attempt to deal with the existing situation, where we are faced with at least 90,000 and possibly 150,000 illegal entrants, and recognising that some of them are here illegally through no fault of their own. In fact, one could argue that this Government and past governments have been accessories to their behaviour, because the compliance provisions that we have had in place so far might as well not have been there. They certainly were not enforced.

People were almost led to believe that if they behaved themselves, if they worked, if they did not become involved in criminal activities, if they paid the tax, and if they founded a family, educated the children and generally did their job as citizens in our community, which contributed to the well-being of our community, then they would not be hounded to leave this country. I do not condone the breaking of our laws, and I agree that from now on we should use the tough measures of compliance which have been foreshadowed by the Government and which the majority view of the Committee has put forward and which it endorses. But I think that there is a sound case for people who, through their behaviour in the past and through circumstances, have become absorbed in the community. We should not tear them out of that context and break their family, professional and social ties in a community when we might be sending them to a country which to all intents and purposes has now become a country that no longer offers them a base for existence and with which they might have no further ties.

I must express some personal disappointment that this particular recommendation was not accepted in the spirit in which it was offered, and I reject the constructions that have been put on it which I believe are not warranted. Having said that, I do recognise though the balance of compassion and control that the Government has attempted to achieve. On that basis, in broad terms, I offer my support to the Government's response and to the measures foreshadowed.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission report on Issues in Fiscal Equalisation tabled earlier today is a very complex and in some ways arcane sounding report, but it is in fact a very important report. It is a report that has been prepared by the members of the Commonwealth Grants Commission and I congratulate the Chairman of the Commission, Mr Dick Rye, and his fellow commission members on this report. It is a report that was requested of the Commission by the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, on 4 September 1989, when he conveyed to the Commission terms of reference for a review of certain issues associated with the methodology used by the Grants Commission in its 1988 report on the relativities to be applied to the distribution of general revenue grants amongst the States.

As the Senate will be aware, the Commonwealth Grants Commission is responsible for determining the relativities for the distribution of general revenue grants among the States. It does not have direct responsibility for specific purpose payments, and of course it does not have any responsibility for the borrowings of other States. But the general revenue grants by the Commonwealth to the States is, of course, a major part of Commonwealth funding for the States and it is not as much relatively as it should be. I will come back to that if time permits.

The report on Issues in Fiscal Equalisation is very detailed. It is very technical, very complex and in the time available to us today it is impossible to get to grips with all of it. It does deserve very considerable further study. I am sure it will be given that, particularly by the State governments that will be affected by the recommendations here if the Grants Commission does go ahead with some of the proposals it has in this report when it comes to the next review of how the general revenue payments are to be distributed amongst the States, that next general review being due in 1993.

What this report does today is put forward the Commission's proposals as to how it will tackle the 1993 review. It has major implications for Federal-State financial relationships and particularly the distribution between the States. For example, just picking up one point from the executive summary and the overview in the report, the Grants Commission at the moment takes into account what are called location-specific disabilities that particular States have in terms of their own revenue raising capacity. I must stress that the Grants Commission is not recommending that these location-specific disabilities no longer be taken into account, but if they were no longer taken into account they would have a detrimental effect of some $650m on the smaller States, and would therefore result in a greater revenue flow towards the larger States of New South Wales and Victoria.

There are many important points made in the report. The one that I want particularly to refer to is the view expressed by the Grants Commission that in looking at the whole question of the most equitable method of fiscal equalisation between the States, the inclusion of most special purpose payments is the most appropriate method to adopt. At the moment not all special purpose payments are taken into account in any formal way in the allocation of the general purpose payments. The Grants Commission has proposed that the special purpose payments ought to be taken into account in the same way as the general revenue payments, and that indeed many of them ought to be absorbed into the general revenue pool rather than continue to be treated as special purpose payments. That is a recommendation of major importance. It would give the States much greater responsibility for determining how they spend the funds granted to them by the Commonwealth and, to a great extent, it would take the Commonwealth off their backs, which would be, in my view, highly desirable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Few industries in Australia have been subject to such constant and widespread criticism as the textile, clothing and footwear industries. It is interesting to note that very little of that criticism seems to be directed to such efficiency considerations as output per employee, or per employee hour, or week. Nor is any consideration given to the ethics of the costs or the prices of some of those imported products.

We often hear about the problems of rainforests and the tragedies for the world as a result of logging in tropical rainforest areas and other problems, but seldom do we hear from those people who are so anxious to get the cheapest possible imported clothing and textile products that they are blind about the ethical composition of some of those costs behind the prices of imported goods that are put onto the Australian market. I refer perhaps to the misery in some of the overseas `sweated' workshops and the distortions in the purchase of raw material products.

Despite that criticism, the Australian textile, clothing and footwear industries still form an important part of Australia's economic and social structure. In fact, they added 7 per cent of value added of Australian manufacturing industry during the year 1987-88. It seems strange that, despite our abundance of natural raw materials including wool, cotton, cattle hides and sheep skins, our industries have been unsuccessful in adding significant value to those raw materials in Australia. I suppose the most poignant criticism of the industries has been their failure to orientate their production significantly towards an export market.

I am pleased to say that `the industries are looking positively to the challenges of the future because the Authority considers that a properly structured industry can make a solid contribution to the Australian economy without ongoing reliance on community support in the form of higher tariffs or large subsidies'. To achieve that, it has to be recognised that restructuring and time are required.

Quite often we are not aware of the efficiencies and the changes in the technology that is being applied in the textile industry because it is generally characterised by its high degree of capital intensity and automation of processing. Technological developments in spinning have mainly focused on the improvements to machine efficiencies, higher speeds and more uniform quality. Labour costs have been progressively reduced to a bare minimum. For example also, in weaving, tufting and knitting technical developments have focused on higher machine speeds and, in combination with electronic monitoring and computer programming, developments have allowed greater flexibility in pattern selection with variations and control of machine functions. I believe that short resume gives the Senate some idea of the textile industry's application of high technology to its future development.

In the last few minutes, I will come back to the issue that I raised earlier in my contribution. Unfortunately, the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority report does draw attention-and I think this is an important contribution of the report-to the fact that government intervention in the international textile fibre market has significant cost implications for the world's textile industry. These ramifications affect Australia and Australian production. Some governments in fibre producing countries allow preferential fibre buying rates for their indigenous textile industry, thereby distorting the cost structures of these textile industries. These distortions can then flow on to apparel industries. Other pricing and market support policies also affect the prices the textile industry pays for raw material, thereby affecting the industry's competitive position. I believe these factors should be taken into account when we assess the comparative advantage of textile production in Australia vis-a-vis imports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present, on behalf of the President, the report of the Independent Auditor on an Efficiency Audit of the Australian National Audit Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Mr Deputy President, the report of the Independent Auditor on an Efficiency Audit of the Australian National Audit Office is an important document because the role of the Australian National Audit Office is, of course, central to the verification of the actions of government, both in terms of its financial actions and the efficiency with which government departments carry out their responsibilities. The Audit Amendment Act of 1979 amended the Audit Act of 1901 to provide for the appointment of an independent auditor to carry out audits in relation to the Australian National Audit Office.

Mr Michael Sharpe was appointed Independent Auditor in June 1988 for a period of three years. In the report before the Senate today, Mr Sharpe points out that that appointment has now been extended for a further two-year period. The functions of the Independent Auditor are set out in subsection 48k (2) of the Audit Act and include responsibility to carry out efficiency audits of the Australian National Audit Office. The manner in which efficiency audits are conducted, including their frequency and scope, is subject to the provisions of the Act at the discretion of the Independent Auditor. This is the second efficiency audit report that has been issued by Mr Sharpe. The last one-that being the first-was issued in September 1989. In this report, the second report, Mr Sharpe says that he intends to issue one further report during his new two-year term. The overall objective of Mr Sharpe's examination was, in his words:
to form an opinion on whether the manner in which the ANAO sought to achieve its aims and objectives was economical, efficient and effective.

The report will bear careful study, and in the time available to the Senate today that has not been possible, but I would like to offer some reactions to the report as I have been able to glean in the time available. My first reaction on reading the report is to say that I agree with much of its content. An independent report such as this is obviously a valuable exercise in ensuring that the Audit Office achieves its aims and objectives. The Australian National Audit Office, in its role as Auditor for the Commonwealth, by definition has to be a pacesetter on monitoring and making suggestions which allow these objectives of economical, efficient and effective delivery of government services to occur.

Because of its important role in setting the pace for other departments, this puts more importance on what the Audit Office itself is doing. I note, for example, that the Audit Office is the key organisation responsible within the Department of Finance for establishing the ground rules and the monitoring of asset registers. That is a subject that has been debated and discussed at length in recent hearings of Estimates committees. Personally, I have not been entirely satisfied during those hearings that the Audit Office has the establishment and maintenance of assets registers by all departments sufficiently high on its own agenda.

This matter was discussed a couple of weeks ago in the most recent Estimates hearings and, although the Audit Office spoke of the importance of the assets register within departments, it gave answers to questions asked which left one in some doubt as to how comprehensively government departments were pursuing the approach of compiling their own assets registers, although work is well advanced on it in many areas. That is an example of one of the very important areas of work, I believe, that the Audit Office has to pursue.

I also note that in recent Senate Estimates hearings officers from the Audit Office have said that if the Audit Office were a statutory body, there would be certain considerable advantages and particular advantages attaching to such a change in status. That relates particularly, in their view, to the scope that it would give the Audit Office, however so named if it were a statutory body, to compete with equivalent organisations in the private sector in terms of setting the terms and conditions of employment for staff. Also, perhaps more importantly from the Commonwealth's point of view, the point that has been emphasised strongly in discussions on this matter is the question of the independence of the Auditor-General. I believe that is a very important issue. It is one that I would like to see advanced to finality with a decision taken. Senator McMullan who, I note, is in the chamber now, advised Senate Estimates Committee A on 25 September, just two or three weeks ago, that this issue was actually in front of the Minister and a decision hopefully would be made on that particular aspect before too long.

It is a matter though that has, as I think Senator Watson was saying, been dragging on for a long time. I do ask the Government-hopefully Senator McMullan will take it up again, as he is here at present-to make sure that the decision gets off the desk of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) rather than lingers on in the bottom drawer as can so often happen with papers on Treasurers' desks, particularly this Treasurer's desk.

There are a few recommendations in the report on which I would like to comment briefly, but specifically. The area of fees and productivity is the first one. I welcome the report's suggestion that the Audit Office should charge all auditees a fee for all financial audits and that the Audit Office should be required to justify this fee and any overruns to the audit committee. DEBATE.TITLE: MOTOR VEHICLE STANDARDS (EMISSION QUOTAS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to the amend the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1990.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

It is generally recognised that the greatest global environmental threat is posed by rapid change in the composition of the atmosphere. Ice core sampling has provided us with a profile of both global temperature and atmospheric composition for almost the last 200,000 years. Analysis of these samples shows that the amount of CO2 in the global atmosphere varied between about 190ppm and 270ppm. Since the start of the industrial age when the level of CO2 was about 270ppm the amount of carbon dioxide has steadily increased until today it approaches 350ppm. It is now increasing at about 0.5% per year. Because of the inertia in both atmospheric physical processes and in the industrial and economic structures of human civilisation it is suggested that, even with the most vigorous attack on the causes of emissions, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere will continue to rise to about 400ppm when it may be possible to stabilise it at that level. The precise consequences of this increase are unknown.

The ice core samples show a strong association between amount of CO2 in the atmosphere and global temperature. When the level of CO2 has been high so has temperature, when the level of CO2 has been low so also has the temperature. Scientific consensus is that the present rise of CO2 as a consequence of industrial uses of fossil fuels will be accompanied by a greenhouse warming. It is thought that this will result in significant sea level rise, shifts of climate patterns, disruption to agriculture and massive loss of species trapped by changing ecologies in isolated parks and remnants of older natural ecosystems. These consequences are serious and have led the Scientific Committee of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change to recommend that CO2 emissions be cut by 60-80% as quickly as possible. This is a far more stringent requirement than the 20% suggested by the Toronto target but is also more soundly based. The latter was a political decision, the former is the decision of some 300 climate scientists from over 20 countries.

The Hawke Government appears to have accepted the seriousness of changes to the composition of the global atmosphere for which greenhouse has become the shorthand term. Mr Hawke's environment statement stated its importance. The present Federal government has also stated a commitment to developing an economy based on sustainable development. An economy which continually and exponentially increases the greenhouse gas content of the atmosphere is not sustainable! Given the inertia mentioned above, especially the lag time between planning new industrial patterns and processes and their widespread appearance in the community, it is important to begin the move toward greater fuel efficiency and lessened CO2 emissions as soon as possible. Given also the dependence of the Australian economy on the operation of market mechanisms it is important that the task of CO2 emission reduction be accomplished, as far as possible within a market system.

The Montreal Protocol provides a model for CO2 reductions from motor vehicles. The Protocol mandates CFC reductions by set amounts but leaves industry free to determine how best to meet those reductions (with the exception of CFC use in pressure packs which were banned altogether).

This present Bill sets a limit to the CO2 emissions from each fleet of motor vehicles sold by a manufacturer or importer. This limit will relate to the total emissions from all motor vehicles sold by an importer or manufacturer in 1991 and will be based on the number, type, and fuel efficiency of the vehicles sold in that year. In each succeeding year this quota of total CO2 emissions will be reduced by 5%. Each manufacturer or importer will be free to determine how best to satisfy that reduction. They may decide to sell less vehicles overall, or sell less of their less fuel efficient cars and more of their more fuel efficient models, or make more efficient vehicles. A car using LPG emits about 18% less CO2 than one running on petrol. Selling cars which have been converted to gas would achieve four years of the required reduction. Quotas would be tradeable so that one importer or manufacturer could buy or sell quota to another who was better able to use the quota. In brief, another factor would be placed in the operation of the market to bend the market toward greater fuel efficiency and lessened greenhouse gas emissions.

This legislation would have other beneficial consequences. The recent price rises in fuel resulting from the Gulf crisis has illustrated how vulnerable to events beyond our control our economy has become. Increased fuel efficiency reduces this vulnerability. Continued inefficiency will exacerbate this vulnerability as our indigenous supplies of liquid fuel are consumed. Improving our fuel efficiency also increases the life of our indigenous supplies. To the extent that we develop patterns of industrialisation which are more fuel efficient we shall be in a better position to help other countries to follow down the same road. Thus we turn an imperative to advantage.

Australia has been placed between third and fifth worst greenhouse polluting country in the world on a per capita basis. Many other countries are much more fuel efficient across a wide variety of industrial and social practices. We are in real danger of being left behind if we do not start the process of improving fuel efficiency. Our motor transport contributes significantly to our total greenhouse gas emissions. By world standards our emission of greenhouse gases from motor transport, on a per capita basis, is among the worst in the world. In relation to cars there are already prototype Volvos and Peugeots which have achieved fuel efficiencies greater than 100 mpg on the old scale. Legislation of this sort will introduce the right signals in the market for these prototypes to become tomorrow's normal car.

It should be noted that the reduction of 5% each year is based on the quota for the previous year. Thus the absolute reduction in each year steadily declines. This is to take into account that significant early improvements are easier to obtain than improvements further down the track when one is starting from a more efficient base. For example, after five years the total reduction will be 22.6% and not 25% and between the fifth and the sixth year the reduction will be 3.8% and not 5% as it would be if this Bill required 5% absolute each year. Thus as the improvements become harder to achieve the degree of improvement required is adjusted to match this difficulty.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That new regulation 129 contained in amending regulation 26, and new regulation 142B contained in amending regulation 28 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 237 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.

This motion relates to the disallowance of Migration Regulations 129 and 142b, which, in brief, entitle the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to issue residential permits very specifically to pilots whose previous permits are under challenge in the Federal Court of Australia. The whole situation must be viewed against the backdrop of the pilots strike. We are all familiar with the history of that. In what I have to say about this particular issue of disallowance, I do not intend to review the merits or demerits of the pilots strike and of the actions taken by the various parties, and whether they were justified.

The issues here are perhaps twofold. The main issue is whether it is right and proper for Executive Government to intervene in the judicial process by legislation when it looks as though the Executive Government is loosing a particular case. Secondly, there is an issue of substantive consideration as to whether we should facilitate the entry of qualified personnel from overseas when hundreds of people in Australia with similar excellent qualifications to fill whatever vacancies occur are currently without a job.

I return chronologically to the first action in this particular case when the Government facilitated the entry of foreign pilots and arranged for them to be given residential permits under the employer nomination scheme. This action by the Government was challenged by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and it succeeded in the Federal Court of Australia in obtaining an interlocutory injunction. Mr Justice Keely of the Federal Court granted the injunction which would prevent the granting of any visa-entry visa or entry permit-to non-citizen pilots under the employer nomination scheme who were not physically present in Australia at 31 May 1990.

The order preserved the status quo inasmuch as those pilots who had already been given entry permits were not affected by this particular order. However, the order issued by the court included Mr Justice Keely's finding that there was a serious question to be tried as to whether the decisions were authorised by the Migration Act.

This is really the kernel of the question that we are currently dealing with because at that point the Government decided that it did not want to run the risk of a court case proceeding which might invalidate the permits that were to be issued for the remaining pilots. Following the injunction of 31 May 1990, on 12 July the Government inserted certain provisions in the Migration Regulations allowing foreign pilots to apply for a change of status which had previously been prohibited under the terms of the injunction. As I said before, a new regulation 129 was inserted in the Migration Regulations which allows the granting of an extended eligibility pilot entry permit.

As well, a new regulation 142b was inserted in the Migration Regulations to enable the granting of a permanent entry permit to pilots who were already in Australia and who met the requirements of at least one of the paragraphs of section 47 of the Migration Act. Regulations 129 and 142b commenced operation on 12 July 1990 when they were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I believe that we are now faced with the question of Executive Government intervening in the judicial process of this country and that this is the central question which supports the disallowance of these regulations. In discussing this matter with the Opposition parties, I was asked to supply evidence that disallowance of these regulations would actually have a substantive effect apart from satisfying the principle, which I still believe is the overriding principle. The claim was made that pilots who had applications running would not be affected if these regulations were disallowed. We sought legal opinion and it was confirmed that the status of the pilots who had obtained residential permits-and therefore the process was completed-under these two new regulations would not be affected, but that once these regulations were disallowed the pilots who were still in the application process were really thrown back on the original position of relying on the provisions of the Migration Act.

Further, it was quite obvious that at least 300 to 400 pilots were still in that particular position. This emerged in the court case when it became clear and was stated by counsel for the Commonwealth that the process of getting these pilots through the system under the new regulations would take up to four months, and this number was mentioned as an estimate.

I therefore believe that there are two legs of this particular argument which have been satisfied: firstly, the issue of principle, which surely must receive priority by this chamber. We are the guardians of the democratic parliamentary process. If we are prepared to sit idly by and allow Executive Government to intervene in the judicial process when it feels that the judgment might go against it on a substantive issue, then surely we are not doing our job of protecting the democratic process in Australia. Secondly, it has been shown that disallowance of these regulations will have a substantive effect and will enable Australian pilots to be given work ahead of pilots from overseas who have similar qualifications. I therefore believe that both major parties should support this disallowance.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (RATES AND PROVISIONAL TAX) BILL 1990MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990, and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990 before us tonight, let me make it perfectly clear on behalf of the Opposition that we totally abhor this practice, which has been introduced tonight, of income tax being determined by regulation. It is an abhorrent principle of the first order. We would also prefer taxation affecting the so-called uplift factor to be determined annually by the passage of Bills through both Houses of Parliament because it is only by this procedure that we see the authority of the Parliament over the Executive. So the Parliament makes the decisions, not the Executive.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate of the age-long political slogan-no taxation without representation. Further, the coalition deplores the disrespect that the Government has for the rule of law, particularly in income tax legislation. Taxpayers' rights are at risk right across the land. This is a familiar theme that I keep repeating in the chamber.

The priorities of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for reform on simplification go back to 1985, but they are still in the too hard basket. If we look at legislation to be introduced tomorrow, we find foreign income legislation which has elements of reverse onus of proof, retrospectivity and incontestability-all going to the core of the problem of taxpayers' rights.

Finally, we put the Government on notice that the Australian taxpaying community is becoming increasingly restive-perhaps I should say fed up-with this Labor Government's unnecessary building of complexity on complexity and making tax laws unintelligent to ordinary, honest Australian citizens.

This Government seems to have a blinkered enthusiasm to catch the last cent of every dollar of revenue and to deny the last cent of any outgoing. The Government must lift its preoccupation veil of anti-avoidance and recognise the dignity of ordinary honest Australians. Without such a change in attitude, the Australian Taxation Office will be subjected to community perceptions similar to those prevailing in Old Testament and New Testament times. Honourable senators will recall that the tax gatherers in those times collected more than their due entitlement in situations not befitting a democratic civilised society.

Our laws must ensure that officials of the Australian Taxation Office can operate as a professional group upholding at all times the highest ethical standards. I believe that that is what they want. This is what the Government must deliver.

I wish to discuss what I regard as a most important part of the Bills that are before us. For example, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990 contains a clause which takes out of this Parliament the right to debate a proposed increase in tax-an uplift factor. This Bill proposes to allow by regulation the rate of the uplift factor to be applied when assessing provisional tax. The uplift factor is the extra percentage added to the previous years income so that in times of rising income the estimated tax payable in the present year is as accurate as possible. This has occurred with provisional tax assessments since 1976 in order to achieve reasonable consistency in incomes between the treatment of pay as you earn (PAYE) and provisional taxpayers.

Currently, it has been suggested that this uplift factor be 10 per cent. The uplift factor to date has annually been set by Parliament. The Bill now before us is an attempt to diminish Parliament's prerogative role. Fundamental to the lawgiving processes of this country is the concept of the rule of law that I mentioned earlier. This concept limits the executive arm of government. The actions of government are limited to those specified in regular law determined by Parliament as the representative of the people.

This Bill proposes to circumvent the practice of parliamentary scrutiny and parliamentary sanction and pass it to an outside body or group which has the power to determine the uplift factor. In other words, it is to become a discretionary power given to the Executive. The rule of law is seriously impaired by the use of discretionary powers. We have too many of them and their use has greatly increased in the past few years under this Labor Government. We now have literally hundreds and hundreds of discretions in the taxation area all given to one person-the Taxation Commissioner.

Discretions inevitably lead to arbitrariness and inconsistencies in the application of law. They also lead to difficulties for taxpayers in terms of knowing what the law actually is. They fit uneasily with this new concept of self-assessment in respect of which there has to be absolute certainty before the law. But that is not possible with many discretionary powers.

I would like to take this opportunity to give a bouquet to the new Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for his desire to try to make more open the taxation debate and to make himself accessible to as many groups as possible. I believe that this is refreshing; it is certainly a move that I welcome.

The uplift factor is to be determined by regulations. So, the Parliament will no longer be involved, except in the case of special parliamentary intervention. The system has worked quite well in the past. I sympathise with the Government in respect of situations such as that which the Treasurer led us into last year before the election. At that time the Treasurer was not prepared to take out of a Bill non-contentious provisions which related to provisional tax. The Bill contained some elements which at the time we found objectionable. So the Bill, which contained provisions relating to the uplift factor and the imposition of provisional tax, was not passed before the Parliament rose for the election.

Consequently, the Taxation Office was placed in a very difficult position of having to determine what it should do in relation to provisional tax. The regrettable result was that the Taxation Commissioner had to go out and reissue all of his provisional tax notices. Clearly, that is not a good practice. He did the best that he could, relying on precedents and the available provisions within the Act at the time. We did not challenge this action because we believed that under the circumstances he did what was humanely possible according to the tools that were available to him and the provisions of the legislation. But this sort of thing is clearly unsatisfactory.

We have spoken to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and expressed our wish to participate in meaningful dialogue with him and, maybe, the Treasurer, the Treasury officials and the Tax Office to try to find a mechanism that avoids the application of regulations and, if possible, avoids putting these sorts of things on a permanent basis.

One of the problems, of course, is that at present we have taxation by regulation. There are proposals for the uplift factor to be permanently enshrined in legislation. One of the figures currently being quoted is 10 per cent. We are in economic recessionary conditions at present. To apply a 10 per cent factor in these sorts of conditions again puts the onus back on to the taxpayer who has to lodge a variation for provisional tax. If the taxpayer is wrong, he will be subject to all sorts of penalties. I say that there is room for a much more reasonable figure, given the economic circumstances of the time.

We have no quarrel with a relevant uplift factor. But we do have a serious problem with a measure that gives the Government the discretion to lift the uplift factor in the ensuing years to 12 per cent from the 10 per cent that will apply this year. Such a device will further enshrine the practice of bypassing parliament and obviating the duty for it to deliberate on all measures which are intended to raise revenue by taxation. It is a fundamental responsibility of the Parliament which we must not let go.

If a parliament agrees to allow the executive government to increase any tax without first having the opportunity to debate it, it will just be allowing another nail to be put in the coffin of our own irrelevance as both individual representatives and a parliament. The Parliament has already allowed automatic twice yearly increases in excise on petrol, alcohol, tobacco and like products. So I would like to think that we have at least learnt a lesson from our mistakes.

In that case, I suppose that the excise hikes have the virtue of being at least calculated in accordance with the consumer price index (CPI). The uplift factor is well in excess of the consumer price index. It is well in excess of the Budget calculation for inflation. So, 10 per cent is just too high.

The Treasurer's Budget estimate is for a 6.5 per cent rise in the consumer price index. In the ensuing years it is intended that the uplift be between 10 and 12 per cent. The Government just does not seem to be giving us much hope for the state of the economy in the future. This is certainly a pessimism that is shared by many. Consequently, the Opposition proposes to present to this chamber during the committee stage of this Bill an amendment to keep the determination of the uplift factor by the Parliament and not through regulation. All honourable senators have that amendment before them this evening.

However, there are other aspects of the proposed arrangements for provisional tax that need discussing. In February this year the Treasurer announced that a review of the present income tax legislation was to occur. I do not have to remind the chamber of the complexity of the extra 18,000 pages of legislation, court decisions, interpretation and explanatory memoranda, et cetera, that have been brought forward since 1 July 1985.

The Green Paper on simplification was promised in the Budget. It was then postponed until the end of September. We are now in the middle of October, and we are still waiting. During the Estimates no-one seemed to be able to give me a date as to when we could expect the simplification package, except Senator McMullan, who offered a tentative date of 30 September. Unfortunately, the Treasurer is not helping Senator McMullan in the important work that he is doing.

In the Budget the Treasurer announced further changes to the provisional tax arrangements. So, far from honouring its promise to simplify the income tax system, the Government has, yet again, increased the complexity of the provisional tax system. This time, we find that selected individuals, including company directors and higher paid persons with more than one job, are to be subject to an extension of the provisional tax regime. The new rules will levy a provisional tax liability when PAYE collections in the preceding year fall $3,000 or more short of the taxpayer's actual liability on personal exertion income. The new rules have strewn even more obstacles in the taxpayer's path.

In all my dealings, both in the past as a tax agent and a company director, and now as a senator, I have constantly heard complaints from my constituents and others that the most annoying and disturbing factor that they face in income tax is provisional tax. Here is one avenue where the Government can make it a lot simpler than it is at present.

The recent Budget estimated that the Government would raise an extra $370m annually from this procedure. A number of questions and concerns surround this large additional amount of $370m. It has come to my knowledge that a number of accounting firms whose clients include people likely to be affected by the change are sceptical that the potential revenue to be gained from the changes will be anywhere near the projected amount.

Let us look at some of these people who pay provisional tax. Farmers, small business people, individual investors and retirees, as a result of the present economic climate, could expect to see a downward movement in their income and consequently in their income tax and also their provisional tax bill. Rather than paying the uplift factor, they would have justification for putting in a variation to their provisional tax. But why force them to do that by having an unnecessarily high uplift factor? In his Budget Speech, Mr Keating said that to keep the tax system fair, provisional tax arrangements will be extended to remove scope for high income earners deferring tax payments on wage and salary income at the expense of ordinary taxpayers. He said that this practice has been particularly prevalent in relation to directors' fees, commissions and bonuses and short term contract employees.

The Government has cited this group as its predominant reason for the change. I find this rather surprising. All these sorts of people referred to should have been liable for the ordinary PAYE deductions for many years; that is, such payments are integrally linked with our PAYE system, which requires the payer to make tax instalment deductions before paying the recipient. Therefore, how can these measures raise $370m? One explanation given to us is that the Taxation Office is unable to enforce the existing law. I will not accept that. The sum of $370m is a high price to pay for what I refer to as `lax tax administration'. We found that the Taxation Office was not adequately enforcing the existing law, but I contend that 70 per cent should have been caught with the existing PAYE provisions. That aspect of the law has not been adequately policed and enforced. We are being asked to accept more complexity simply because of lack of enforcement of the PAYE system.

If there is such a high number of defaulting employers, the imposition of provisional tax on employees lets the non-complying employers off the hook. The PAYE provisions contain substantial penalties for defaulting employers, but the Taxation Office has not extracted its pound of flesh where it should have. To do justice to complying employers, the Taxation Office has an obligation to pursue those employers who do not do the right thing. The Budget Speech and Papers are silent on what will happen to those employers and why the situation has been let go for so long. That is the tragedy. I will allow honourable senators to ponder the aforementioned questions because they are serious.

Before us tonight we have the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990, in addition to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, which we have so far discussed. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Amendment Bill also cover the new personal income tax rates for this year and next. As part of Mr Keating's February economic statement, taxpayers were promised tax cuts as a result of a restructuring of the tax scales. Two of these Bills here tonight-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Amendment Bill-implement these changes. As from 1 January 1991 we will have new tax rates. I commend the Government for that.

However, the savings and the actual restructuring of the tax scales are not large, and are not large enough. Let me give honourable senators just one example; I have several, but I have a time problem. If, in 1989-90, someone earned $30,000, he or she will have paid tax of $7,157; in 1990-91 he or she will pay $6,953; while in 1991-92 he or she will pay $6,633. The savings are $204 for 1990-91 and $524 for the year 1991-92 respectively. I have other figures for different income levels, but that will suffice to show that the savings are not large; they barely cover the inflation rate. But do they? No; I am wrong. They come nowhere near covering the inflation rate. According to the parliamentary research service monthly indicators, inflation for the last financial year was 8.2 per cent.

Let us examine the figures for an income of $30,000 a year. To maintain our lifestyle, considering inflation of 8.2 per cent, we need an extra $2,460. The tax cuts for the year are nowhere near enough; they amount to only a few hundred dollars. I know that many workers have received productivity increases of 3 per cent in the last year, and this has done something to help; but with the increases plus the savings in tax, we still come nowhere near covering the inflation rate. This problem will mean extra costs at the grocery store and reduced savings.

It is good to note that the tax free threshold has increased from $5,100 to $5,400. However, again if we consider the inflation rate, the price increases, the reduced standard of living and the impacts of bracket creep, this is still not enough. This increase is not big enough. Fundamentally, the restructuring of the tax scales do not seriously take into account the problems of bracket creep.

Bracket creep is that insidious dark horse which eats away at our hard-earned earnings by putting average wage and salary earners into a tax scale bracket never originally designed for an average income tax worker. That is the problem. This year, yet again, bracket creep will push an increasing number of PAYE taxpayers into higher tax brackets and increase the real tax burdens, despite the cuts. The new system will refund only half the additional revenue to be gained by the Government through bracket creep this year.

On the credit side, the bulk of the cuts will go to the lower income taxpayers with taxable incomes below $25,000. That is reasonable enough. Again, it does not go far enough, but we welcome it. Do not get me wrong: this is good, but the ordinary middle income worker on an average wage of, say, $25,000 gets very little benefit from tax cuts nowadays. It will be the increased taxes on these workers which will go to finance the large Budget surplus.

With declining living standards through bracket creep, higher prices and high interest rates, the ordinary worker with a family is in a dilemma. The amount of income tax paid is a source of much personal dissatisfaction amongst taxpayers in this country. Over the years, personal income tax has jumped dramatically as a share of total revenue. It now represents 53 per cent of average Government revenue, despite the new fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and extensions to the wholesale sales tax, which have been pretty dramatic. Income tax revenue was only 31 per cent 30 years ago; it is now 53 per cent. A greater share has been taken out from the personal taxation system. Much more effort should be made by this Government to adjust the tax scales to make sure there is an equitable taxation burden. That is the last point I would like to make in this area.

As a direct consequence of bracket creep, inflation has meant that more and more people are now in the top, or towards the top, tax brackets. Savings are down because half of all taxpayers pay more than 40 per cent tax on any interest, additional income or marginal income they receive. The same applies for any overtime done or any rewards received from working harder or more effectively. Working extra hours in a factory or coalmine is sometimes hard because one finds that almost half the money earned disappears in tax, and this is not really a great incentive.

One of Australia's biggest problems, both internally and externally, is debt; and it can only be solved by greater savings. The tax scales can be cut either by government cutting government expenditure or through a change in the tax mix. I think it is time that the Government looked very carefully at the suggestion put by the Opposition of a broad based goods and services tax.

As the Government is well aware, in this year's pre-Budget submissions the main accounting bodies-the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, finance companies, construction contractors, the life insurance industry and the Australian Council of Professions- all advocated a form of broad-based goods and services tax as a means of redressing just some of the fundamental structural problems of the economy. Lest I be misunderstood, it is but one in a mosaic of reforms that are necessary to overcome this country's ills. But we must at least make a start.

Australia is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) that does not have a form of consumption tax, either at wholesale or at retail level. According to Professor Cedric Sandford, the former consultant to the OECD on value-added tax systems, the Government's aversion to this form of tax was more likely to be, unfortunately, from political concerns rather than principled objections to changing the focus of the taxation burden. Unfortunately, just too much that this Government does has a political focus. However, I commend the Government on its reductions in the tax scales and the increase in the tax-free threshold, but I think that there is a need for much greater reduction.

Further, I would like to remind the Senate of earlier arguments concerning the uplift factor. I commend to the chamber the need and, certainly, the urgency for the coalition's proposed amendments that I will move during the committee stage of this debate. The Parliament should be the determiner of the taxes in this country. Rule by regulation leads to loss of parliamentary power and sovereignty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are looking at a package of Bills which are essentially part of the enabling legislation for the Government's Budget strategy. While the substance of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990 may seem routine, as they are, in effect, building on the previous initiatives of the Government they are particularly important. It is also important that we take the time to consider the effect of this legislation on ordinary working people.

SPEECH.PARA: The first piece of legislation that I wish to speak to is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1990-91 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for the 1991-92 financial years. The basic rate will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income, which has been the rate since 1 December 1986. The Bill will also increase the low income thresholds below which people are not required to pay any levy.

Universal coverage and equity have been the dominant themes of the health care policy of this Labor Government. This Bill allows the continuation of these two themes. When this Government came to power there were almost two million Australians who were not covered by medical and hospital provisions, and they faced a very serious situation. Two million people-many thousands of Australian families-were in very dire straits when this Government came to power. For those who could not afford private health cover the grim reality that they faced was how to meet the costs of health care for themselves and their families. It was a basic tenet of this Government's social justice program that that fear and anxiety should be taken away from people in this country.

The lack of cover was a barrier to the use of health services. In 1982 a study of 90 low income families by the Australian Council of Social Service found that over half of the families were forced to go without the treatment of often major health needs that were required. In contrast, a study of 56 low income families by the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence in 1985-86 found that families reported that they could use doctors and hospitals when they needed to. That was the contrast in a few short years, based on the Government's program.

Medicare has enshrined an important principle: that health is funded by all according to their means and available to all according to their needs. This also means that health care is affordable. Fewer people now have to pay medical bills with the number of services bulk billed increasing from 35 per cent to 55 per cent of all services since the introduction of Medicare. It is a significant move of people who do not have to worry now about bills towards a 55 per cent target.

We can be sure, by supporting this piece of legislation, that our action is going to be supported by the vast majority of Australians. A recent survey commissioned by the Health Insurance Commission showed that a very high seven in 10 Australians are currently in favour of Medicare. The key finding of this survey is that support for Medicare is not only very high among those with Medicare cover; it is also high among those who have private health insurance. Almost three-quarters of all Australians favour Medicare because they see it as affordable and good value for money and because it is a system of universal coverage which also offers assistance to those financially not so well off. The principles of Medicare and the main features of the program have extremely solid support from a wide range of the Australian community. Bearing in mind this contrast between the Government's record and that of the Opposition, it is a bit surprising to see in the Sydney Morning Herald just a week ago an article headed `New call for tax bonus to people with health cover'. It is worth while reading the article. It points out:

Internal controversy over the Opposition's health policy took a new turn yesterday when another Liberal called for taxpayers who insure privately for basic medical and hospital care to be allowed to opt out of paying some tax.

South Australian Liberal backbencher Mr Ian Wilson, a former Fraser Government minister, has circulated a paper to his Coalition colleagues which he describes as the `philosophical extension' of the policy put forward by the previous Opposition health spokesman, Mr Peter Shack.
Mr Shack surprised his colleagues last month by publicly advocating his policy in a public speech.

That article highlights the division in the Opposition as significant sections of the Opposition cling to the discredited policies of Peter Shack, a policy that is not supported by over 70 per cent of the Australian people. The Sydney Morning Herald article went on to describe the policy, far better than I could, as follows:

The Opposition was forced to abandon his policy in an embarrassing political fiasco just before the March election after Mr Shack admitted he could not fulfil previous promises that the policy would be revenue neutral and not leave anybody worse off financially.

Of course, that is what it is all about. The people within the Opposition are still seeking to allow people to be given an advantage because they join private medical funds. The obvious danger in this is that there would clearly be pressure on people to force them into private funds because Mr Wilson's approach will lead people into being disadvantaged if they stay with the Medicare system, should the Opposition be foolish enough to repeat the Shack mistake and follow such a policy.
I again quote the Sydney Morning Herald to emphasise the danger as far as the Australian people are concerned of the Opposition following this policy:
But Mr Wilson says they should not have to contribute through their taxes to the health cost of those who do not purchase private cover but could afford to buy it.
