Mr Wilson told the Herald he believed Medicare should be retained for those who could not afford to pay for private insurance and those who chose not to insure privately, but could afford to, would face a higher Medicare levy.

That is the threat from Mr Wilson. That is a very serious situation. Having said that, I am pleased to see that the next day, on Wednesday of last week, the Sydney Morning Herald, under the heading, `Collins joins Opposition health policy debate', stated:

The NSW Minister for Health, Mr Collins, yesterday fuelled growing divisions within the Federal Opposition over its health policy by calling on them to `do their homework' and `get it right next time'.

Mr Collins said the Opposition had `botched' its health policy during the last election and said he was amazed that the former health spokesman in charge of that policy, Mr Peter Shack, was now campaigning to have his policy accepted again.

In an interview on Sydney radio station 2UE, Mr Collins said: `They're trying to jump the gun with far too little information and for Peter Shack to try to revive the health policy that he lost on, I think, is inexplicable'.

So the Opposition-or at least sections of it-has a policy that is inexplicable in its attempt to move away from Medicare. I raise this matter because people have the opportunity at this moment to contrast the security of Medicare with the confusion of the Opposition. That is something that has to be taken into consideration when people consider the run-up to the next election.

I now turn to two Bills which introduce the rates of tax for the period 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990 and for later years-the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990 and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990. The changes to personal tax rates proposed by this legislation were foreshadowed in the February 1990 economic statement and are an integral part of the agreement reached between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) under the accord for the 1990-91 financial year. This agreement provides for increases in disposable income and living conditions through a continuation of wage increases, tax reductions and improvement in the social wage.

The agreement also provides for an aggregate wage target of 7 per cent for 1990-91 with support for the following increases on the basis that award restructuring is continuing and successfully moving from award to award: a first increase to maintain the real value of wages following the September quarter 1990 consumer price index, which, of course, is being discussed currently; and a further increase of $12 per week six months later.

These increases are to be paid from a common date where the relevant unions remain committed to progressing award restructuring, which is part of the understanding. Included as part of the agreement is a modification of the no extra claims commitment applying to minimum rates awards to allow scope for additional negotiations for increases based on achieved increases in productivity and profitability. Outcomes of the process are to be limited and within the 7 per cent adequate wage target to which I have referred. Discussion may proceed between unions and employer bodies on how this element of the accord is to be implemented.

The third component of this agreement is an additional 3 per cent superannuation phased-in aggregate over three years. I believe that this is a very important aspect of the Government's policy. Yesterday a press release put out by the Treasurer, Mr Keating-I think this is significant as it relates to the first figures that have come out on the impact of superannuation-stated:
The Federal Government's superannuation reforms were now pumping $19 billion a year into Australia's savings pool . . .

The changes since Labor won office not only meant Australia would be able to look after the growing numbers of people retiring into the 21st century, but that they would enjoy better living standards.
The press release pointed out:
. . . the first Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey of superannuation assets today, which showed that funds invested rose 21 per cent to $109.7 billion in the 12 months to March this year.
It continued-and it is worth while drawing attention to this because it is an exciting possibility at a time when there is a great demand for investment in Australia-to point out:

. . . 21 per cent growth rate in the 12 months to March was worth $19 billion, more than double fund assets when Labor came to power in 1983, while an extra $5 billion has been invested in Australian shares over the past year.

`It is, of course, a remarkable achievement and it goes to show that superannuation is now a substantial part of the savings and asset picture of the nation which of course it wasn't in 1983,' Mr Keating said.

I think that is something that is important. So when we consider this legislation that is primarily based on the taxation promises of the Government we have that additional aspect-at a time when we are talking about industry development-of the tremendous amount of money that wage and salary earners in Australia have been contributing to the future growth of this nation into the next century.

The accord wages proposals are subject to consideration by the Industrial Relations Commission in the forthcoming national wage case. The agreement reached between the Government and the ACTU is an important component of the Government's overall economic strategy. The accord agreements have had a significant influence on economic outcomes in Australia since 1983. They have underpinned macro-economic strategies aimed at a recovery from the 1981-82 recession and more recently at addressing the difficulties faced with our external account in the second half of the 1980s.

Without the accord, the alternative policy options available to the Government would have meant a far more restrained economy. The economic achievements of the accord, that I would just like to put on the record again, include: the reduction of unemployment in inflation from the previous double digit figures; the creation of over 1.6 million jobs in that period; and the remarkable drop of about 60 per cent in the amount of industrial disputation that has been recorded in this country. Owing to the restraint of wage and salary earners, a substantial reduction in the real unit labour costs of 10.5 per cent are now well known. Although, unfortunately, we have not had the movement that I would have liked to have seen in industrial development, nevertheless the wage and salary earners of this country have made a significant sacrifice in order that that might be possible.

The Budget deficit, of course, has been turned into a surplus, and in recent years the accord has been responsible for encouraging award restructuring, which is aimed at updating industrial awards so that they meet the competitive requirements of industry and provide workers with more secure and satisfying jobs, with opportunities for training and advancement. The award restructuring process is well under way, and most awards have been varied to incorporate changes which lead to real productivity increases.

I just want to continue by drawing attention once again, as I did with Medicare, to the Government's proven record in this area, and to the danger that the Opposition still will unsettle and destabilise the country with its continued proposals to try to base the whole of the financial or the wage negotiating situation in this country in the hands of individual enterprises. I have outlined the stability that the accord process has given to this country but what we still have, unfortunately, is the Opposition sticking to the proposal that there should be negotiations only at the enterprise level, with no overall plan or strategy or agreement in place. Of course, those enterprise proposals by their very nature have to be unequal.

As I have said here many times, the Liberal Party policy-the Opposition policy-is not to have everything fair and equal, because while the employer will have access to his employer's organisation, to the lawyers, to the economists and to the research from the State bodies and the national bodies of the organisation, what the Opposition says is that the individual 50 or 100 workers will form their own union. That is one view of it. Or, in some other way the workers will come together and be able to negotiate against the ultimate power that the employer has with all the resources of an employer's organisation. Of course, this is only a subterfuge. What the Opposition really wants to do is to take away from wage and salary earners the trade union that will advise them of the salaries and rates being paid in other places, in other enterprises, in other States, and in other cities. The trade union will give them the information that will allow them to go to the bargaining table without one hand tied behind their back.

So, unfortunately, the coalition will continue to push that policy because it has not seen that if we are to solve the many problems that exist in this country, we can only do so by a degree of cooperation. We can only get people to give away, as we have shown, the methods and the labour management relationships of decades when they know that the Government is backing the negotiations that will take place and, on many occasions, with the Government assisting with restraining and with resources in a whole range of ways.

I conclude by commending this legislation to honourable senators and point out that it is part of a consistent path this Government is maintaining. Also I warn them that on these two issues-first of all on the question of Medicare, the Opposition is hopelessly divided as usual, and secondly on industrial relations and their enterprise agreement proposals-they are out of kilter with the needs of modern Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess we should take the opportunity to debate the Government's record on tax, but I cannot avoid the pleasure of rebutting some of the statements that Senator Childs has made over the last 25 or 30 minutes. Lastly, he suggested that the Opposition is divided on the Medicare policy.
—It is good, coming from the leader of the Left faction, isn't it?

—That is the point I was going to make. I have been in the Opposition party room only since May and I have never seen a more cohesive group of people who are more determined to win government and to turn this country around and not, as honourable senators opposite would do, create equality of outcomes for individuals, but indeed to create equality of opportunity. Coming from the parliamentary Labor Party, as Senator Childs does, how could he possibly even dare to say, after the last few months since the 24 March poll that his Party has been through, that the Opposition is divided? We have seen Minister after Minister knocking other Ministers over the head, knifing them in the back, and then having a very open and public squabble about all sorts of micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.PARA: As I suggested earlier today in another discussion in relation to industry policy, if honourable senators opposite had worked out some of their priorities in the micro-economic reform area back in 1987, in what was meant to be the period of the great Hawke micro-economic reform agenda between 1987 and 1990-it is totally forgotten and was a disgrace-then perhaps this country would not be in as great a mess as it is at the moment.

Senator Childs talks about the Liberal Party wanting to unsettle and destabilise this country with its industrial relations policy and its Medicare policies. I think one would be hard pressed to find a nation more unsettled and more destabilised, with an economy that is living on the razor's edge, than Australia is at the moment. It is a sad indictment upon the gross failure of this Government in so many areas.

The other point in Senator Childs's contribution here tonight that I want to rebut relates to his discussion about Peter Shack, the honourable member for Tangney in the other place, and the health policy discussion before the 24 March election. I do not think anyone would be stupid enough to say that the discussion of the honourable member for Tangney during the election did the Opposition, as it was, any good at that time. However, in Mr Shack's defence, it is fair to say that he is a very honest man and he was prepared to come out, to make an honest contribution, and to say that something that we had hoped for before the election was unable to be delivered.

That is more than one can say about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and this Government. Before the 1987 election they said that there would be no new capital gains tax and, of course, that promise lasted about as long as most of his other promises. We also have the great promise about the fact that there would be no more children living in poverty in Australia by the year 1990, and all of us who have spent any time out of this place and around the metropolitan areas of the cities of Australia know that that is not the case.

I guess the only other promise that he has made recently-we will see whether he comes through with it-is his promise to stay on as Labor leader past the next election. I guess that if his track record of keeping promises is as good as it has been proven over the last seven years, then I sincerely doubt that he will. The conjecture is only as to whether Mr Beazley, Mr Keating or Mr Kerin is to succeed him.

We are not here to talk about that; we are here to talk about these tax Bills. I think it is fair to say that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, would have us all believe that Australia is a low taxed nation. Indeed, the Treasurer comes out on regular occasions saying that Australia is taxed at a lower rate than other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations. All I can say is that when one is out there talking to business people or talking to housewives or talking to anybody, the rhetoric of the Treasurer, in trying to convince people that they are not being taxed very much, does not go over very well because it is just not true.

I will move on to speak about some of the reality behind taxation in Australia as opposed to the rhetoric of our Treasurer. The reality of these Bills is that, of course, the tax rates are being reduced and that must always be applauded. It would be nice to see the rates reduced a lot more. I think many taxpayers would love to see the rates reduced a lot more because there are so many more taxpayers slipping into higher and higher brackets and paying more and more tax.

Back on 17 August 1986 the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, described Australia's economic circumstances as being `in a crisis as great as the crisis of war'. I suppose that quote has been used quite often around the place. Back in 1787, some time before, an American philosopher by the name of Thomas Paine said of war, `It has but one thing certain, and that is to raise taxes'. I guess that is another statement that has been quoted here, there and everywhere.

If we are waging a war, an economic war at that, I suppose we could presume to ask: Who are we fighting and what are we fighting for? I suggest that not many senators would disagree that we should be fighting to make Australia more competitive, we should be fighting to reduce our foreign debt, and we should be fighting to reduce, if not get rid of, poverty. Most of all, we should be fighting to give Australians more economic freedom because it is only with that greater economic freedom that individuals can decide for themselves the kind of life they want to lead and where they want to invest and spend their hard-earned money.

It is important to note that that freedom and that individual's right to make decisions about his future is something that governments cannot decide. I suppose the one way that governments reduce that economic freedom is through taxation. For every increased dollar that they rip out of the back pockets of taxpayers, it is one more increment of less freedom that those individuals have. So when this Government rips out a dollar from an individual's pocket and spends it on some new government program, that is one less decision that that individual is allowed to make. I think that is a crucial point whenever we are considering taxation, considering the size of government and, indeed, considering the very role of government.

Referring to my analogy to economic war-indeed, the Prime Minister's analogy-in looking at it as a war we have to ask ourselves: how have Hawke and Keating, how has this Government, done in fighting this war? I think it is fair to say that the Government is losing on a number of fronts. I think it is also fair to ask: How can one possibly win a war when the very best forces are taken and taxed out of existence, when the most lethal soldiers in the war have one arm and one leg cut off?

It reminds me of that scene from the movie Monty Python and the Holy Grail, which I am sure many people have seen, where the Black Knight meets the troops along the way and he has one arm cut off and a leg cut off and he still wants to keep fighting and there is blood spurting everywhere. The Black Knight still wants to keep on fighting and he says, `Come on, have a go'. Then he loses another arm and another leg and he is lying there bleeding to death. Finally, his head is chopped off and he is still saying, `Have a go'. I think Australian taxpayers have a lot in common with the poor old armless and headless, hapless Black Knight-only in this case it is not the Monty Python team which is chopping off arms and legs, it is this Government which is bleeding the taxpayer and the business people dry.

The problem is that the Government thinks that it is inflicting only a few economic flesh wounds. Most of us who have been out in the real world, who can actually spend a bit of time away from this place and mix with the real people out in the country or in businesses or in the supermarkets or in the delicatessens, know that Australians are suffering because they are overtaxed and this is hurting them severely.

I think it is important to understand that if Australians can actually survive the taxes and charges slugs of the State Labor governments and the gross economic mismanagement and incompetence of those governments and actually make a bit of money, that is when they start meeting the Federal fiscal fiend and the Federal Government's savage tax regime. Like the Black Knight, first Australians pay sales taxes, excises and Customs duties. Then if they make a profit after that and they actually sell their goods and interest rates do not chew up the profits they are making while the goods are sitting on the shelf, they get the privilege of paying company tax. If they are still going after that, if there is still a bit of profit left in the back pocket, they then get the privilege of paying exorbitant rates of income tax.

I suppose that just when taxpayers really have had the blood and the life and the limb sucked out of them by this voracious Government, the Government can always, if there is anything left, ensure that it taxes what taxpayers' earnings may be in the following year with provisional tax. I suppose while our poor taxpayer is lying in a pool of fiscal blood, like our Monty Pythonesque Black Knight, armless and legless, the Government can still hit him, if there is an ounce of life left in him, if there is any money left in him, with the capital gains tax. If that does not end him, what will?

I ask the Senate, and it is something that many small business people ask themselves these days: Why would one bother to fight on? I suppose it is no wonder, to honourable senators opposite, with this incredible impost imposed by Federal and State Labor governments, that thousands of small businesses have decided to give up the fight and throw in the towel and, indeed, with 128,000 more people out of work since last June, they have given up the fight, too. I suppose it is fair to say that one does not get much tax and one does not get much revenue out of unemployed people or businesses that have gone to the wall. There comes a point where taxation and the regressive rates of tax which have been imposed by this Government are counter-productive.

On the more positive side, it is fair to say that Australia is a nation of great natural wealth, we have a highly educated population, and we are very close to the rapidly growing South East Asian area. What Australia should be doing is fighting to become a major economic force in that region. To do that, we need a motivated force of men and women who are inspired by their economic self-interest to work harder than they have ever worked before. These Australians will work hard in the full knowledge that they will be rewarded for the extra effort and that they will be rewarded as individuals and that they will share the achievement of this reward as a nation.

Let us look at what this Government has done about motivating individual Australians to work harder and to produce more. The figures relating to pay as you earn tax receipts show that between 1982-83 and the estimates for 1990-91 in the Budget Papers there has been an increase in those tax receipts of about 128 per cent. If we take into account that the inflation rate during that period was about 78 per cent over that time, the real rate of increase was somewhere around 70 per cent. If we take into account all the other forms of income tax, including capital gains tax, the Medicare levy, which we have referred to earlier, and the prescribed payments scheme, in 1982-83 the figures were $22.967 billion rising to something like $54.85 billion in the current year, which is a 138 per cent increase. If we adjust that for inflation, it is an increase of 60 per cent in real terms.

I turn to tax on companies. In 1982-83 the revenue from that area was $4.768 billion and the current year estimate is revenue of $11.635 billion-again, an increase of 144.4 per cent or, inflation adjusted, around 66 per cent in real terms over that period.

During this time we have had a whole load of new forms of income tax-the withholding tax, tax on superannuation, the resources rent tax and the fringe benefits tax. The withholding tax, because it came in just prior to 1983, raised $259m in those years. Revenue from all those forms is proposed to raise about $3.36 billion in the current fiscal year. That represents an outstanding increase of 1,199.61 per cent or, if one makes an adjustment for inflation, 1,121.61 per cent-an unreal figure. But basically what we are saying is that this Government has found another $3.36 billion over the last seven and a bit years.

The amount raised from sales tax in 1982-83 was $3.49 billion. In 1990-91, the figure was $10.668 billion-an increase in excess of 205 per cent from sales tax. So we ask ourselves what this Government's real policy is in relation to consumption tax. Senator Watson has referred to this already, so I will not cover that ground. But basically in this one area of tax revenue, under this Government-even after taking into account an inflation factor of 78 per cent over that period-there has been a real increase in revenue of 127.67 per cent in seven and a bit years, which is over 16 per cent per annum. To add up all those boring statistics, total tax revenue in 1982-83 was $40.743 billion moving up to a total tax revenue of $96.921 billion-if those targets are reached-in 1990-91, an increase of 136.33 per cent, or indeed about 7.3 per cent per annum over the eight-year period in real terms. The Treasurer would have the Australian people believe that they are being taxed less and less. It is important that the people of Australia know that when the Treasurer says `less and less', what he is really saying is `more and more'.

I would now like to talk about one of the important consequences of taxing everything that moves. I think the Government has taken that tax policy a bit further and has said, `If it keeps moving, tax it a bit harder'. What this policy and regressive tax rates have done to the Australian community, both the business community and the housewife and general households, has basically been to create an economy and business decision making which are driven by the tax system. That is something we would like to avoid. In other words, the regressive tax rates and the regressive tax system, in a very real and destructive way, distort all sorts of decisions. If one is looking at investing some money, setting up a new enterprise or spending some money anywhere, one always takes tax effects into consideration.

It should not be a matter for the Government to direct, persuade or otherwise entice people on how to spend or invest their own money. One day the Government will decide that people should put their money into family homes; the next day or the next year it will decide that superannuation is perhaps a better place for people to put their money; and the next day it might decide that people should invest their money in export industries, films, the arts or whatever it thinks is the right idea. So, in other words, we have a tax system that distorts decision making. Indeed, it is a regressive tax system that makes people spend a lot of their time thinking about how they will get through this world by minimising their tax. I do not think anyone in this place would applaud that. But it is a very real situation.

Indeed, an entire industry has been set up to provide tax advice. There are financial planners and accountants specialising in tax. Larger companies have tax specialists working within them to structure their affairs to minimise tax. When taxes get so high that people have to invest so much valuable time and expertise in trying to reduce their tax, obviously that has a large impact on our ability as a nation to be competitive, entrepreneurial and to look for opportunities at a time when we really need them.

I guess it is fair to say that in a competitive world environment where the nations in the South East Asian region in particular are getting on and increasing their productivity, miles ahead of Australia, it is not hard to imagine why, when most of our good brains and professional brains are sitting up late at night in tall buildings trying to figure out how to avoid and minimise taxes and come up with new schemes; indeed, individual executives and even middle and low income earners are trying to figure out how they can squeeze the last dollar out of their tax return. With all of that ability and skill going into minimising tax, Australia is not competing very well in the South East Asian region.

I want to conclude with a few quotes on a philosophical nature about tax levels and governments taking control of people's lives and indeed the propensity of government to tax people and impose regressive tax rates which, I think it is fair to say, basically chop down tall poppies and create the view that anyone who earns a buck or does a little better than average should be taxed out of existence because that person can afford to pay. I guess that is an argument that relates back to yesterday's sales tax measures on luxury cars. I quote from a former Secretary of Treasury in the Nixon and Ford administrations, William E. Simon, in his book A Time for Truth:

Our citizens must learn that what keeps them prosperous is production and technological innovation. Their wealth emerges, not from government offices or politicians' edicts, but only from that portion of the marketplace which is free. They must also be taught to understand the relationship among collectivism, centralized planning, and poverty . . .

The Senate must understand that the more government and the more control over people's lives and the more centralised and collectivised planning, the more taxation is required and the less economic freedom individuals have. I put it to the Senate, and it is a philosophical belief that I feel strongly about, that with the Government getting bigger and bigger and taxes getting higher and higher, as I have clearly demonstrated here tonight, economic freedom is reduced significantly and Australia's ability to become competitive, and indeed the ability to allow individuals to earn more money, is severely inhibited.
I quote another extract from Simon's book:
. . . profits needed for investment must be respected as a great social blessing, not as a social evil, and that envy of the `rich' cannot be allowed to destroy a powerful economic system.

Again, I think that reinforces my philosophical belief about high and regressive rates of tax, chopping down tall poppies and taking away motivation for people to take Australia through with their own entrepreneurial flair, work and toil to earn money and reward for effort. Because if we have a government, which I think we have at the moment, that has this egalitarian view that we do not have equality of opportunity but indeed equality of outcomes, and the tax system is probably the best way to achieve that egalitarian objective, Australia will be no more than and have no chance of becoming more than the white trash of Asia. I do not want my nation to be that. I think that the taxation system is an important part of government policy which needs to embrace the philosophy that people should have that motivation and encouragement to succeed and to help Australia through its success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak for only a few minutes on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which seeks to amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986. The Bill contains technical provisions that raise various thresholds. Therefore, it is not a controversial Bill in itself and we shall be supporting it.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me, however, is that once again we have a situation in this country in which Medicare is creating tremendous hardships for the people of Australia. We all remember the lovely brochure we received from the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in the early days that contained the words `Welcome to the best health care system in the world'. In those days the levy was one per cent, and those people who were below the threshold did not pay the levy and those who were over the threshold paid the maximum. This was at a time when the patient paid 85 per cent of the doctor's schedule fee.

We now have a totally different situation, because we have a levy of 1.25 per cent. We were promised by Dr Blewett that it would not go up, but that situation did not last very long and the levy rose to the present figure. The ceiling was taken off the levy and it is now in parallel with a taxpayer's income. As to the schedule fee for doctors in private hospitals, Medicare pays only 75 per cent of any treatment. Consequently, because of all these additional costs for the average Australian who was insured, people are moving out of insurance, out of the private hospital system and into the public hospital system.
I refer to a recent headline in the Australian: `Breathing life into the health system'. The article under it reads:

Medicare is sick. It is not likely to survive without fairly radical surgery. The pathology is plain. Medicare has bled the private hospitals and stretched the public system, which cannot bear the weight.
Since Medicare was introduced in 1984, the proportion of Australians covered by private health insurance has fallen from near 70 per cent to less than 50 per cent.

Labor Ministers who can well afford not to bludge on society have Medicare and take out no insurance at all. So when one of their family or they themselves go into hospital, they take the place of a pensioner who is unable to get a bed. Let us not be misled or hide from the fact that if a Minister or one of his family want a bed, they will get it, and will get it very quickly.

People have moved from the private hospital system-a system that is becoming too costly-into the public hospital system. As the Australian article said, the system is collapsing under the weight of the patients. There are now lengthy hospital queues. They are so long that pensioners in particular are giving up and not bothering to have their hips fixed and are resorting to wheelchairs. Such people are unable to get medical surgery carried out in an appropriate fashion.

There is such a blow-out in costs that the Federal Government has decided to limit the number of beds, limit the health care, rather than keep on increasing funding. Why has that blow-out occurred? Australia has an ageing population and it follows that health costs will increase. It has a general increase in the population, and there are rising expectations that people can have anything done these days. They can have triple bypasses, hip replacements-the lot. Indeed, I myself have had a hip replacement. People can have all sorts of replacements done. Because the Prime Minister promised us the best health care, the expectation is that we can have these things, and have them for nothing, and Medicare will cover the lot. These are the expectations.

On top of that is all the new expensive technology and all the new expensive drugs. The expectation and belief in the community is that the levy covers the lot. This is far from the truth. We know only too well that the levy does not cover a third of the costs of health care in Australia. The Government pretends otherwise, and indeed it was the main campaign at the last election. It was said that the levy covered health costs and that if some people were allowed to opt out of the levy, there would not be enough money left in the pool to pay for the health of the nation. That was what the Government was putting round, and it is absolutely untrue. As I have said, the levy does not cover a third of the costs to the community.

The frustration of surgeons in Australia is unbelievable. They are trying as best they can to service the patients and to go to them. At the conference of the Royal Australian College of Surgeons last week, we heard statements suggesting that it would be a good idea for patients to sue the Government for not enabling them to enter the public hospital system. The headlines were `Call to sue on hospital wait'. I wish to read just a part of this item because I believe it is important that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is present for this debate, hear this. The article reads:
Patients on long Medicare waiting lists should sue the Federal Government, a Melbourne conference heard yesterday.

The Royal Australian College of Surgeons' state chairman, Tony Buzzard, told the conference on the crisis in public hospitals that people getting sicker while on waiting lists would be justified in going to court.
Mr Buzzard, a medical-legal consultant, also said he believed they would have a reasonable chance of winning.
`The promise of Medicare is that it will deliver access to high quality care,' he said.
Of course we all got the pamphlet from Mr Hawke telling us so. Mr Buzzard continued:
`If the Government has not honoured that commitment, it stands liable.
`Such a legal action would open the floodgates for suits against Medicare.
`I believe that patients would be quite justified in bringing an action for Medicare's failure to fulfil its public duty and provide services.'
The surgeons, frankly, do not know where to turn. The conference was told that ambulances shop around to find a place where they can get a bed for the patient. The article concludes:

`Waiting lists are a disgrace, ambulances have to shop around for a bed and patients who should be in beds are littering the casualty departments. Morale is low and frustration is high among the doctors, nurses and other staff.
`The Government is letting our hospitals decline at the community's peril.'

We all know that the Federal Government, which previously financially supported the States' hospitals fairly well, has allowed the States to continue to close more and more beds as its funding of those hospitals diminishes. The Federal Government will not give the States enough to run the hospitals properly. So we have more and more beds going by the board. In their frustration, nurses are leaving the hospitals. Because of the vicious circle, the hospitals cannot employ enough nurses, and altogether the situation is deteriorating to such an extent that I believe the system will very shortly fall apart.

The Government has seen fit to say that charging pensioners for drugs, making pensioners pay a small amount per prescription-say, $2.50-will cause them to think twice about having a drug prescribed or about collecting the drug. If the Government is serious and if the Government really believes that, why does it not also say, `We will stop bulk billing; we will stop the completely free medical service to everyone, except pensioners and the disadvantaged'?

The only reason the Government has for not doing that is a philosophical one. It will not deliberately destroy its beloved Medicare, no matter how much it is sending this country down the gurgler, no matter how much this health system is hurting Australian citizens. All the Government has to say is that those who can afford it, such as Dr Blewett, Mr Howe, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, who is sitting at the table, and I, should be insured. We should make the beds at the hospitals available for all those disadvantaged and pensioners who are on the waiting list. We should pay our insurance and, through that insurance, pay the doctors the full amount-not bulk bill so that people can go to the doctor as often as they like, as frequently as they see fit, and not have to pay a penny.

It is illogical that the Government says, on the one hand, that it will make a difference if pensioners have to pay something for their drugs but, on the other, that it will not limit the doctors' visits if bulk billing is taken away from the whole community and left just to pensioners and the disadvantaged. I have spoken about this issue on many occasions. The Government keeps turning a blind eye and a deaf ear and will continue to do so until the whole Medicare debacle collapses around it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Listening to some of the previous speakers, in particular Senator Campbell, one would think that the generally available knowledge that we are the third lowest taxed country among industrialised nations had totally bypassed them. One is also reminded, by contrast, of the statements by Mr Dick Smith, a noted entrepreneur of a somewhat different calibre from the entrepreneurs we have been hearing so much about lately. I recall Mr Smith saying that he does not retain tax avoidance experts; he is proud to be able to contribute to his country's well-being, to the infrastructure, to the education system, and to the health system that he and his family are using and that thousands and millions of Australians are using.

SPEECH.PARA: In the current climate, very often created by previous speakers on both sides of this chamber and certainly outside, this must appear as almost sacrilege, certainly as idiocy. Yet Mr Smith's statement should represent the moral fibre of our citizens and it should be the principle on which honest business is founded in this country. Without a sound government based infrastructure, without public utilities, business could not exist. It is interesting to note that, while big business did not complain when high interest rates affected small business, home buyers and farmers, in the past few months it very quickly took up the cudgels and asked for government intervention when corporate profits started to take a downward turn.

The Senate is examining the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990, which are being debated cognately. I shall deal, first of all, with the rates and provisional tax Bill. This Bill is designed to alter income tax as from 1 January 1991 to deliver the tax cuts promised in the Budget; to reduce the medical expenses rebate from 29 per cent of the excess over $1,000 unreimbursed medical expenses to 21 per cent in two years' time and in 1991 to 25 per cent; to insert, as a standing measure, the rules concerning the calculation of provisional tax for 1990-91 and subsequent years; and to broaden the provisional tax system to include salary and wage income where there is a shortfall of more than $3,000 worth of deductions from previous years.

First of all, the provisional tax provisions refer to the customary practice of creating an uplift of 10 per cent for calculating the rate of provisional tax which is to be levied. This year it is proposed to be 10 per cent; however, the Government proposes to fix a maximum level of 12 per cent which it can impose by regulation. The Australian Democrats do not accept this discretion giving the Government the power to raise a tax by a regulation. Our amendment will seek to leave the tax at a bare 10 per cent but to continue that 10 per cent for subsequent years, unless otherwise provided by Parliament.

The tax cuts which were announced during the election campaign and confirmed in the Budget will not be opposed. They benefit low and middle income earners and are thus reasonably equitable. The only point one could make is that it is rather sad that these tax cuts for low and middle income earners come in this financial year, whereas the tax cuts benefiting high income earners came in previous years. Perhaps that is an indication of the Government's priorities, too.

As part of these tax cuts, the threshold has been increased from $5,100 to $5,400. We take a particular interest in the tax threshold as it affects pensioners. We believe that the tax threshold for pensioners in this current year should be $10,000. It is still considerably short of that: currently for a single pensioner it is $9,789 effectively and for married pensioners $8,217. We encourage the Government to push towards that threshold for pensioners and beneficiaries. On our calculations, that expenditure would be approximately $160m in the current financial year. It is not in the Government's Budget provisions to introduce this, but it is something we have included in our alternative Budget. I urge the Government to look towards that as an equity measure.

There is another measure which we will introduce by way of an amendment to this Bill; that is a marginal income tax rate of 60 per cent on that part of income which is above $100,000. The motivation is quite clear-rather than taxing the people who cannot resist and do not have the capacity to generate political pressure, we suggest that the Government should tax the people who have the capacity to pay. In recent years, the trickle down theory has become the vogue and the tax rate has been compressed to a point where the low and middle income earner deserves the sympathy of Senator Campbell rather than the high income earners who currently have more disposable income than ever before in Australia. It is time that we introduced a measure of social equity into our tax system. Hence the amendment that I will seek to move, and which has now been circulated, to introduce this particular tax rate.

I should also advert to the fact that the Government seeks to introduce one further provision in this Bill which will broaden the provisional tax system to include salary and wage incomes, where in the previous year pay as you earn (PAYE) contributions have fallen short by more than $3,000. We raise no objection to that particular provision; we think it is fair and equitable and needs to be used to enforce payment of tax. However, we do note that it is an enforcement measure which is, once again, directed at PAYE earners.

Why does the Government persistently avoid attacking those people who still enjoy the privileges of tax avoidance loopholes? I refer, amongst others, to tax savings which result from the difference between the company tax rate and the rate of withholding tax payable by non-residents on interest derived. The obvious answer is to reduce the current differential which is approximately 25 per cent. As we know, the withholding tax is currently 10 per cent, although some of our reciprocal taxation agreements would allow a 15 per cent rate.

A number of countries do not have reciprocal arrangements and the withholding tax rate could be increased considerably. There are precedents across the world where this differential exists. Canada, for instance, imposes a 29 per cent rate on non-treaty country residents, whereas the rate for treaty country residents can be as low as zero depending on the treaty, of course. France imposes a 45 per cent rate on non- treaty country residents, whereas the rate for treaty country residents is dependent on particular arrangements and contracts. The United Kingdom imposes a rate of 27 per cent on non-treaty country residents, whereas the rate for treaty country residents can be as low as zero.

It seems to me that amongst these countries Australia alone persists in imposing a 10 per cent withholding tax rate thereby opening a vast loophole which it has been estimated could lose up to $1 billion in revenue in avoidance measures. In addition, the Australian Taxation Office has actually admitted recently that $100m is evaded in this particular area.

There are other tax avoidance loopholes which the Government could profitably attack rather than, once again, targeting PAYE taxpayers, such as the royalty provisions which are used to transfer profits out of Australia. We believe that the Government should completely review the taxation treatment of all royalty payments to tighten up the provisions. One of the most worrying is the trend of purportedly selling copyrights and brand names overseas and then paying licence fees to these offshore captive entities.

On the matter of luxury cars, the Government has omitted to act to limit the leasing charges of luxury cars allowed as a tax deduction, so the provisions levying a higher sales tax on luxury vehicles can very conveniently be overcome by using the leasing mechanism. So it goes on.

I now turn to the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990. Under the Constitution a separate Act which actually imposes taxation is necessary. This was introduced to prevent the Government from being able to tack another provision onto revenue Bills. The two Bills formally impose income tax and the Medicare levy respectively for the 1990-91 year and subsequent year for all taxpayers.

The Bill which imposes the Medicare levy has also raised the exemption levels for the levy, which we support. We believe that the formal annual imposition of the tax, while it is constitutionally necessary, is a waste of the time of the Parliament if it has to be done separately every year. To our mind there is no reason why the imposition of income tax and the Medicare levy cannot be enacted to apply in this and subsequent years, which will save us a lot of trouble. It will also make sure, at least in the Medicare area, that a future government, of whatever complexion, which might be of a mind to get rid of Medicare cannot do so simply by omitting to bring in the Bill imposing a Medicare levy. For these reasons, we will be moving an amendment to impose income tax and the Medicare levy on a continuing basis.

In closing my remarks I wish, again, to call on the Government to turn its mind to tax avoidance loopholes, which in our alternative budget numbered 22, are yielding possible revenue of $2.6 billion. Surely, this is a matter that the Government should address instead of creating-I am not saying that it is doing so actively-a climate where the Taxation Office is pulling back from its program of auditing and from issuing tough regulations which force our companies to disgorge some of the profits which they have avoided paying tax on in recent years during the deregulation boom and now bust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating legislation regarding income tax rates for the remainder of 1990 and the continuation of the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy for 1991. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1990 may be described as mechanical. They do, however, involve essential areas of policy where the actions of the Hawke Labor Government are failing the people of Australia. That is the area to which I would like to address my comments tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to taxation, this Government works on the principle that if it asserts what is patently untrue for long enough people will believe it. Thus we are being told by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that we are lightly taxed and that we are being generously treated by changes to the tax scales. I have just heard Senator Spindler's contribution. Naturally enough he agrees with that too. As I said in this place last night, when we are dealing with tax junkies such as the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, that should not be surprising.

Before any of us count our chickens for the 1990-91 year notice, should be taken of a statement made on 26 August by Mr Richard Buchanan of the Taxation Institute of Australia. When a promised tax cut is combined with the reality of inflation and bracket creep, a taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a 7 per cent wage increase and a 6.5 per cent inflation rate will in fact be worse off by $2.64 per week.

In a double income family with each on average earnings there will be a loss of $262 for the year or $5.28 a week. Of course, this is just a continuation of the decline in living standards that we have progressively seen over the last 7 1/2 years. A taxpayer on 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings-not what one would normally describe as a massively wealthy income-would be worse off by $4.39 a week.

Rises in oil prices over the last month, with their effect on the general economy, will make the inflation prediction conservative. I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) a question a couple of weeks ago, after the price of fuel had gone up decidedly, about what impact that would have on the Budget estimates. At that stage he said that they were flexible and that they were always an estimate. He did not really know the answer to that.

But when we debate adjustment of the tax scales, we should remember that inflation is the ally of big taxing Labor governments as it is the engine pushing more average wage earners into higher tax brackets. It is a fact of life under the Hawke Labor Government that inflation has risen, according to the consumer price index, at 7.6 per cent annually compared with an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average of 4.1 per cent.

I was concerned to hear Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats substantiate the moves that the Government has made in this area. He keeps justifying these moves, when the people whom he allegedly represents are the ones who are suffering.

So much for the crocodile tears of the Treasurer that a greater emphasis on taxation through a goods and services tax, as proposed by the coalition, would erode the value of savings. This is exactly what happens under the inflation that this Government, for all its reliance on extortionate interest rates, has never made a sustained effort to control.

The fact that the public sector is forecast to grow at 2.75 per cent in 1990-91, when the essential private sector will not grow at all and with business investment down by more than 7 per cent, reflects the continuing pressure of higher taxation on which this Hawke Labor Government relies. It is not the sign of a low taxed country that over the last seven years of Labor Government fixed capital formation in Australia has been 22 per cent lower than the average of 24 OECD countries.

Also, there is no change to the rate of Medicare levy for 1990-91. There is no change to the essential fact, glossed over, of course, by this Government, that the levy is nothing more than a tax surcharge with little relevance to the cost of health care in Australia. The Budget Papers predict that the levy in this coming financial year will raise $2.7 billion. This amounts to 21.1 per cent of the total cost of health care expenditure of $12.9 billion and 57.4 per cent of expenditure on medical benefits alone. In 1989-90 the levy raised $2 1/2 billion and amounted to 21.3 per cent of total health spending and 59.6 per cent of spending on medical benefits.

Gradually, therefore, the levy has less and less relevance to the true cost of health care and helps this Government in its constant public relations exercise that Medicare is adequately looking after Australia's health needs. Maybe it can if, in fact, we avoid becoming seriously ill and in need of elective surgery. But it certainly will not look after the people who get ill and who need to have hospitalisation.

Overall health outlays continue their inexorable upward spiral despite the cost savings adopted in the area of pharmaceuticals. Medical services will grow by 11.4 per cent and in total there will be a 2.2 per cent rise in real health spending. The Budget Papers tell us that by 1993-94 health will comprise 15.4 per cent of total outlays compared with 13.6 per cent last year. I might remind the Senate that this form of health cover-the Medicare system-was designed by Dr non-medical Blewett back in 1983 when he said that it would be a self-funding system. A self-funding system it is not; a self-funding system it has never been.

While the Government makes much of its attempts supposedly to tackle overprescribing, it does nothing to discourage the overservicing that is the inevitable product of the Medicare system. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) can boast that bulk billing has risen from 35 to 55 per cent of all Medicare services, with general practitioners services at 65 per cent. There is no disputing that the incidence of bulk billing has gone up and up and that people are going to doctors for any reason because they do not have to pay. When will we get to a system where there is more responsibility on both the provider and the patient? The 31 per cent rise in medical benefit items from 1983-84 to 1988-89 has taken place with only a slight rise in the aged population and points to the increase in demand that Medicare has generated.

The Government constantly tells us that the reason for the increased cost burden on Medicare is the development of technology and the ageing population. I take issue with that because there has been only a very slight rise in the aged population in that time. If a system is unable to cope with the developments of technology and the increased availability of that technology, the system is not an adequate one to service the people of Australia.

What does prevent a more massive blow-out of public health expenditure is the fact that 45 per cent of Australians have private health cover and 87 per cent of these people are covered for private hospitalisation. Yet, once again, it has to be stated that this Government does nothing to encourage self-provision among younger, healthier Australians whose participation is essential if private cover is to remain within the reach of ordinary Australians.

Again I must state a simple but forgotten fact that unless 45 per cent plus of Australians keep their private cover, Medicare will grind to a halt even faster. But there is absolutely and utterly no incentive for people to take out private health insurance cover. The problem is that the demand is too great in the public hospital system and there is no incentive for people to go to the private hospital system.

People who are privately insured at the moment are in fact paying three times for their health cover: they are paying this idiotic 1 1/4 per cent levy, which covers only 21 per cent of the total cost of health care; the rest of it is being picked up in general revenue, which is their second payment; and their third payment is through private health insurance. That just is not a correct mechanism to encourage more people to go into private health insurance.

Withdrawal of government support for re-insurance and for private hospital beds has created $400m in additional costs for private insurance and forced up the cost of insurance by as much as $150 annually for a family. Every family knows at the moment that it can afford less and less. When families do their budgets they know what they can cut out. They know that they have a problem with high interest rates at the moment. They look at all of the expenses that they have, they look at any private health insurance that they may have and they then assess whether they need it. If they have been healthy in the recent past, they decide that that is one of the first things that goes. Therefore, we have this declining membership of private health insurance funds.

Governments put further pressure on the non-government medical sector by using private patients as a means of financing public hospitals, while 8,000 private hospital beds lie empty. Why is it, if this system is so good, that the public hospitals actually attract the private patients? The answer is that the public hospitals get paid more by having private patients in their hospitals. Yet, as I say, there are 8,000 private hospital beds lying empty and there are many private hospitals on the verge of closure because they are unprofitable. They are not unprofitable because of bad management, as the Government would suggest; they are unprofitable because so many people are now pulling out of private health insurance owing to the disincentives created by this Government.

The new Minister for Community Services and Health appears to follow the same collectivist philosophy as his predecessor, stating on 12 September that Medicare enshrined the principle of taking from all according to means and delivering according to needs. What rot! This sentiment was contradicted by the Minister's admission that in Victoria alone 4,500 people were waiting for elective orthopaedic surgery, with an average waiting time of 3.4 months. What an admission for any Minister to have to make: that there are actually 4,500 people in Victoria waiting to get into hospital for orthopaedic surgery. Needless to say, many people would have spent far longer than the average awaiting procedures essential for their quality of life. However, as we all know, some people can jump the queue without difficulty-namely, the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Robert Hawke. Why should he be able to jump queues when other people have to wait on average 3.4 months?

One searches the Minister's speech in vain for any recognition of the contribution of the private health sector. Indeed, this Labor Government does not seem to care that private insurance in Australia has generally held to the socially responsible principle of community rating, keeping insurance within the practical reach of those who most need it, rather than those who require it least. But it is alarming that the Minister decrees that some groups are receiving `too much medical care' that they are presumably willing to pay for.

It is an essential difference between the Government and the coalition that we do not believe that governments can arbitrarily declare how much medical care the community or the individual needs. I did not realise that the Minister for Community Services and Health was actually a medical practitioner of all Australians who could decide whether they were receiving too much care. I thought that trained doctors were those best equipped to decide how much care their patients needed. Hospital queues are hardly a memorial to the superiority of a government dominated health system.

The review of Medicare announced by the Minister will be nothing more than a window dressing exercise if the Government does not recognise that each one per cent drop in private health insurance adds a further $120m to public health spending.

The review will be positively harmful if it strengthens the tendency to penalise private patients and private hospitals, which may indeed be priced out of the range of many people with private insurance. The lesson has been learned overseas that the elimination of a private hospital system and private hospital insurance, with a supposedly-I emphasise the word `supposedly'-free public system, results in massive costs. Canada is an example, with wealthier people deserting the system for the United States of America. In other Western nations with a government dominated system, private insurance and hospitals become the preserve of the rich alone. Why is it that this Government has not learned from the experience of other government dominated health systems? One can only wonder.

Earlier this year I raised at some length how Medicare in Western Australia was resulting in savage cutbacks in country public hospitals. At Geraldton, 450 kilometres from Perth, a 24-bed surgical ward was closed. When a member of the Western Australian Legislative Council, the honourable Margaret McAleer, raised this matter urgently with the Prime Minister in April, she received a letter from the Minister for Health stating that spending priorities were decided by State Governments. Six months after this urgent inquiry was made, a letter from Senator McMullan was gratuitously sent to her explaining how Medicare worked. That was not the question. But of course the Government does not care about representations from members of parliament. Senator McMullan, who happens to be in the chamber, could not care less. The Government thought, `We'll go and give Miss McAleer a lecture on Medicare'. She does not need a lecture on Medicare; she is fully aware of its pitfalls. What she sought from the Prime Minister or somebody who was capable of answering her was some information. One could expect that she was entitled to that.

Needless to say, a major point of Miss McAleer's letter was a request for tax deductions for private health insurance that would ease pressure and costs on the public system. Clearly, this Government prefers not to consider this matter. It is all too apparent that, despite a change of Minister, this Labor Government will continue to pursue a policy of downgrading the private health sector and containing costs by the rationing of services that impact hardest on elderly Australians without private cover who need hospitalisation that is essential to repair eyesight or provide the mobility without which they cannot remain in their homes or, in many cases, at work. We all know what happens when they cannot remain at work: they then have to give up work. The taxpayer then has to provide some additional payment to them in the form of welfare.
The unchanged nature of the Medicare Levy Bill is a symbol of the refusal of this Labor Government to change its approach to health care, despite the evidence here and overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to address the Senate briefly on the rural industry crisis and highlight some aspects of it that are not particularly well known. Just before I do that, I want to add to what Senator Parer has just said on the grants given by the Grants Commission to local authorities in Queensland and the new methodology that has been adopted in the last couple of years on how the money that the Commonwealth gives to the Queensland State is divided up amongst local authorities in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of concern about the way the methodology has changed in the last two years. In this last year some of the major provincial cities have been quite badly affected by the methodology and, as Senator Parer mentioned, those cities are getting together and they include such diverse or widely-spread cities as Townsville and Brisbane. The shire that I had the privilege to represent for many years has been rather adversely affected in the last two years because of this changed methodology. It is almost like a double dipping by the State Grants Commission in allocating assumed expenditure and assumed income to particular councils when they get down to work out what each particular local authority should receive. We in the Burdekin Shire and many other rural authorities have equally been disadvantaged because the methodology used or the formula used includes an assumed gross value of rural production and it also includes a component where the personal income of farming families is taken into account.

One really includes the other, but the methodology adopted by the Queensland Grants Commission includes both those components as separate identities. In the case of my shire, it has meant that we were assumed or deemed to have had a greater income than we could possibly get because the figures were added in twice. There is an ongoing concern and it is a situation that the Commonwealth Government should keep an eye on because although the Commonwealth Government is not directly involved in the way the grants are divided up within the State, it does supply the money and it should carefully monitor the way it is divided up in the State.

As the rural crisis in Australia deepens, the Liberal Party has brought to the attention of this Senate many of the real problems facing primary producers. They are problems which, to a very great degree, have been exacerbated by the Government's high interest rate policy which has in turn caused enormous fluctuations in the exchange rate. I am pleased to say that the exchange rate in the last couple of days has fallen to an extent where primary producers are now starting to breathe again in the hope that they may get better.

If we add to the Government's high interest rate policies the loss of export markets due to the Middle East crisis and serious overproduction problems in many commodities, including wool, we have a real crisis in rural industries. The wool industry and the wheat industry are two industries which have come to the attention of the Parliament and the Senate a number of times in the last few weeks. I wish to refer briefly to the rice industry which is also suffering, particularly because of high interest rates, difficulties with the value of the Australian dollar and also the Middle East crisis which has severely affected the exports of the rice industry in Australia because both Iraq and Kuwait were very large buyers of the Australian rice crop.

The rice industry in Australia has several different geographical components, the major ones of which are in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area down this way and in the Burdekin area of Queensland. I believe there is rice grown in other parts of Australia as well. The rice in Queensland was an industry which commenced within my time. I can clearly remember the rice industry starting in the Burdekin. It was established at a time when there was a recession in other rural industries. The people of this part of rural Australia got together as a community to look around for alternative crops which could be used to bolster the main crop when it was suffering bad times.

From that very early start, that very humble start, the rice industry has become quite a major component of life in the Burdekin district, with a major milling operation there which mills rice not only from the Burdekin region but also from the Mareeba area west of Cairns. Burdekin rice is renowned worldwide because it is a very superior quality long grain rice. The decentralisation which has occurred in Australia because of this new industry has meant a lot to rural parts of Australia and it has also earned very efficiently considerable export dollars over the years.

The very energetic board of the rice mill in the Burdekin, the Queensland Rice Board, has put a lot of work into creating exports for rice products overseas, particularly into Papua New Guinea, Hong Kong, Singapore and the Pacific Islands. It has become very difficult for Australia's rice exporters to market into these areas because of the value of the Australian dollar and because they are competing with crops grown overseas in areas which do not follow the same rigid and honest farming practices and trade and tariff practices that the Australian industry does.

There is difficulty in marketing into these places. Fortunately, in Queensland, exports into New Guinea are relatively cost effective because of the proximity of the market to the area of production. Rice from the Burdekin mill is exported out of the port of Townsville. It creates good business for that port and is taken straight into New Guinea, and very effectively provides for a market there.

Whilst every effort is made to market overseas in competition with cheaper foreign products, it does become rather difficult with other products coming into Australia. Australia is the only country in the world that I am aware of that does not have any restrictions on rice imports. So whilst we are restricted from exporting our rice to many other countries-I mention, for example, that if we want to sell rice in the European Economic Community in competition with rice grown in, say, Spain and Italy, we would be selling it at about $US500 per metric tonne, which is the going price, but in addition we would have to pay another $250 per metric tonne as some sort of levy to the Economic Community to be able to sell the rice to that area-we seem to allow anyone to sell rice here. Free trade is all well and good. It is a great principle to aim for, but we have to compete with other countries that play by the same rules.

One of the other problems that the rice industry has is that of quarantine restrictions being lifted on overseas rice coming in. Until the present time, the quarantine limit has been one paddy grain of rice per kilogram of white rice. With a limit of only one paddy grain, most overseas exporting countries, such as India and Thailand, could meet that standard, but the Vietnamese rice industry could not.

The Government has instituted an inquiry through the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service to see whether that quarantine limit should not be raised to five or 35 grains of paddy rice per kilogram. The Australian rice industry opposes any change to the current level of one paddy grain per kilogram. It is a level which does, according to the Australian rice industry-and I accept this-protect the Australian industry against the importation of diseases that can come in from rice originating in Thailand, India and Vietnam. But the proposal to allow that to be five paddy grains per kilogram, or even 35 grains per kilogram, which is the tolerance for seed rice, is one that would put the Australian rice industry substantially at risk.

The discussion paper put out by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service indicates that quarantine decisions must be based on sound technical grounds and that there should be no suggestion that tolerances for paddy milled rice should constitute a form of non-tariff trade barrier. But there is a real concern that if this tolerance of one paddy grain per kilogram is increased, it could put the whole Australian rice industry at some risk of serious disease infliction.

The other aspect of the Quarantine Service investigation is that there is some suggestion that it may not be looking at things evenly within Australia. There is an acceptance, and I understand some regulation, that does not allow any foreign rice, or any rice grown in other Australian areas, that has any paddy grains in it to go into the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area (MIA). I understand that the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service accepts this or, if it does not, certainly the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Fisheries does. So it keeps the MIA rice areas free from any rice which might contain paddy grains. If the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service accepts that no rice with paddy grains in it should be allowed into the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area for fear of spreading disease, that same view should also be held by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service when it considers what tolerance of paddy rice it should allow into Australia.

Australia has been very honest and open in ensuring that its quarantine decisions are made for quarantine purposes and not for non-tariff protection. But the Government must be vigilant to ensure that everybody else with whom we compete continues in the same way.

I briefly make reference to the peanut industry in Kingaroy-another industry that is not often talked about which is experiencing some real difficulties at this time in Australia's history. At the present time, the peanut industry in Kingaroy is suffering as a result of a couple of years of very severe droughts followed by a couple of years of very intensive rain at the wrong time which has just about wiped out the industry.

On top of that, a lot of peanuts are being imported from overseas sources. Twenty-five per cent of all peanuts now sold in Australia are grown in China. The peanuts that come in from China have a chemical residue content that would not be allowed if Australian peanuts were being exported overseas. Pesticide tests on Chinese peanuts have revealed benzine hexachloride levels which are 10 times higher than the residues in Australian grown peanuts.

I make reference to the Queensland Government, which has recognised the plight of peanut growers in the Kingaroy area, has seen that the industry is on its knees and has come to the aid of those growers. It is offering low interest rate loans-and I understand this was only announced today-to enable those peanut growers who are thought to be or can prove that they are viable and have a long term place in the industry to get back on their feet after these disastrous years and get their industry going again.

I do ask that the Government, when dealing with matters of quarantine and export and trade matters, bears in mind that since we do not allow any tariffs, the very honest and strict rules that we apply in Australia should apply to all countries around the world who compete with us in the trade of foodstuffs.

It should be noted and always borne in mind that Australia imports $150m worth of foodstuffs each month. That is $2 billion worth of foodstuffs per year, which is almost 10 per cent of our trading deficit. That is for food that we produce ourselves in Australia. So there is an enormous quantity of food coming into Australia from overseas sources, competing with industries which we ourselves have established over the years in this country. Those things must always be kept in mind and be very carefully considered when decisions are being made on trade and quarantine matters.
