TALK.START.PARA: —I speak tonight to one of the recommendations in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, entitled Drugs in Sport, presented to the Senate in May of this year and to which the Government has not yet responded. I am not suggesting that the Government is out of time in not doing so, but I believe one particular recommendation needs to be responded to quickly. Some of the matters that I will raise have to be dealt with, unfortunately, at some length, but I think it has to be done. The matter I raise relates to the sport of powerlifting. It is a sport which has existed in Australia since 1970. Many practitioners of that sport really make no bones about the fact that the sport went downhill as a result of the increasing use of drugs in the sport.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1985 a group of powerlifters from the then governing body, the Australian Amateur Power Lifting Federation (AAPLF), broke away and formed an alternative group called the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation (ADFPF). This organisation has operated since 1985 without any government support whatsoever.

When the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, chaired by the former Senator Black, commenced its investigation into drugs in sport, some members of the AAPLF who had been concerned about the infiltration of drugs into their sport decided to stay within that organisation and make an attempt to clean it up from within. They ultimately decided that it was a waste of time, and some with whom I have spoken told me that they got nowhere in this regard because some of the people who were managing the sport were in fact involved in the distribution of performance-enhancing drugs.

A number of members of the AAPLF gave evidence to the Senate Committee about the operation of drugs in their sport. Having failed to clean up the sport from within, they also took the decision to leave the AAPLF and join the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation. In fact, a significant number of powerlifters, disenchanted with the failure of the AAPLF to reform itself, joined the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation.

Meanwhile, some of the office-bearers of the AAPLF gave evidence to the Senate inquiry, and I shall shortly refer to the inquiry's conclusions about the two rival bodies. But at this stage I would point out that during the drugs in sport inquiry, the AAPLF disbanded and a new organisation was formed called the Australian Powerlifting Federation, merely dropping the word `Amateur'. Significantly, it comprised officebearers of the old AAPLF.

One result of the Senate inquiry was that a number of State affiliates of the old AAPLF disaffiliated, including the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales. Many members of the organisation were lost to the drug free power lifters. I am informed that the Australian Powerlifting Federation now has fewer than 100 active members, although it claims to have significantly more. The Drug Free Powerlifting Federation has about 1,200 active members either as competitors or as officials.

Some conclusions were drawn by the Senate Committee about the respective organisations which I think it is useful to refer to at this stage. Perhaps you can read it later, Mr President, but I seek leave to incorporate at this point in my speech the conclusion of the Senate Committee at paragraph 8.145 set out on pages 272 and 273 of the report.
Leave granted.
The passage read as follows-

The Committee has closely examined the activities of the AAPLF (and its subsequent forms) and the Drug Free Powerlifting Association. And the record of AAPLF in drug testing is unacceptable in the Committee's view for an organisation receiving public funds. The major grounds for the judgment are:
* Officials of the AAPLF have not presented an unambiguous opposition to drug use until quite recently.

* Some AAPLF officials do not seem to understand the proprieties to be observed for drug testing in sport. Mr Robert Orr, for example, is a competing powerlifter, but as an official Mr Orr submitted an application to be an IPF approved drug control officer. The Chief Executive of ASDA has advised:
This does not meet with the approval of ASDA and could only be seen as a clear conflict of interest. (Letter to Committee Secretary, 12 January 1990)

* Drug testing under the AAPLF has not always been credible. The Committee has indicated its conviction that drug testing for the 1988 National Championships was expected to be `fixed'. In the event, the `fix' did not eventuate and six powerlifters including the official who sent out the notice that drug testing would be conducted, were found positive.

* The Committee is not convinced that the AAPLF has demonstrated its bona fides in reacting to positive drug tests. Gael Martin, for example, was permitted to compete after testing positive at the 1988 Women's World Championships. Mr Glenn Jones told the Committee that Mrs Martin's test result was kept a secret and she was not actually banned for some six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will read out, though, recommendation 20 which follows immediately after that paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation Inc. (ADFPF) be recognised as the national sporting organisation for official recognition and public funding.

Subsequent to that, that body, the drug free powerlifters, applied to the Australian Sports Commission for funding as the nationally recognised organisation. It also sought to obtain access to facilities for its members. I am advised by that body that the Sports Commission did not acknowledge or reply to its application, and for four months it heard nothing. The Drug Free Powerlifting Federation began to form a view that the Sports Commission would not be funding the powerlifting at all. Having survived since 1985 without any government funding and though disappointed, it believed that it could live without a grant, but certainly wished to obtain access to Australian Institute of Sport facilities and coaching for its athletes. In order to pursue this access, the Federation provided to the Sports Commission its financial statements, auditors' reports and a five-year plan.

In July of this year the APLF was interviewed by two officials from the Australian Sports Commission. Those who were interviewed, I am told, felt from the outset that there was an attitude of hostility towards them. They may, of course, have been wrong. They had, though, detected a similar attitude in a telephone conversation between the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation and an ASC official in which, I understand, the official expressed the view that it was for it to run sport and that it was not to be run by a Federal parliamentary committee.

During the interview I am told that there was a fairly frank discussion about the future of powerlifting. The ASC officials apparently indicated that they were aware that the ailing Amateur Powerlifting Federation had no affiliation with New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), had effectively folded in Tasmania and the Northern Territory and only had any real membership left in Victoria. I am also advised that the ASC officials said that the APLF had submitted no documentation, had no five-year plan and had only recently been incorporated.

The tone of the conversation led the Drug Free officials to believe that funding was unlikely to be forthcoming, but the Federation's representatives repeated their wish to have access to the facilities which would be of benefit to their athletes. They were told that a decision was likely to be made by the end of September, but they heard nothing more.

I am informed that on 28 September there was a telephone hook-up between the Sports Commission and the Australian Powerlifting Federation and that the board approved the recommendation of its officials that the APLF receive funding and be recognised as the national sporting organisation representing powerlifting-that, of course, not being the group that was recommended by the Senate committee. Apparently, the APLF had by then put together a five-year plan and otherwise satisfied the Commission that it should represent powerlifting.

The explanation offered to the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation for these decisions was as follows: that the APLF has international affiliations with the International Powerlifting Federation which is related to the body which organises the World Games, and the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation's international affiliate does not have that relationship. I am told that the international affiliate of the Australian Powerlifting Federation is connected with the body which organises the World Games but that powerlifting as a sport has never appeared in the World Games. This affiliation, I suggest, is of doubtful value or significance.

It was suggested that the APLF has more members than the Drug Free powerlifters. On this point it is said that the APLF claims to have 2,000 members, but everyone would know that it is not a large sport. The claim of the APLF is rendered somewhat dubious when one examines the history of its predecessor, the AAPLF to which I referred earlier and which was exposed to the Senate inquiry as having indulged in numbers rigging. Admissions were made to the Commission to the effect that the organisation tried to get:
. . . a large percentage of people down so that we can show numbers to help with our government grants. I do not deny that at all.
Then it goes on:
I do not have the exact figures but I think that it would be appropriate to say that the figures are greatly inflated because of the school children's participation.

Perhaps I could explain the school children's participation. This evidence of the witness refers to a schools bench press competition which has been used to boost numbers. A young boy or girl is given one lift of a bar in return for the organisation using his or her name and address as a non-paying junior member. I understand that in fact the APLF has only about 100 active members, mostly in Victoria. I am informed that at a recent competition where four events were held on the same occasion to maximise participation, it was still able to muster only nine competitors.

A third matter that was advanced as a reason for the funding going to the APLF was that the APLF has affiliates in every state and the Drug Free powerlifters do not. As to this matter of affiliates, the APLF is centred in Victoria with a small membership in Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia.

The old New South Wales affiliate withdrew its affiliation during the Senate inquiry and never reaffiliated. The ACT affiliate also withdrew and its members have joined the drug free powerlifters individually. The Northern Territory affiliate of the APLF is basically defunct. The Drug Free Powerlifting Federation has affiliates in Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, New South Wales, the ACT and Tasmania and is in the process of incorporating in the Northern Territory. Negotiations are also taking place with drug free lifters in Western Australia in an attempt to establish the sport there as well. It has a membership of 1,200, with a genuine 800 training, lifting and officiating members.

Given these considerations, it is difficult to see how the Commission has concluded that the APLF is entitled to be recognised as the official body representing powerlifting and be entitled to $20,000 of taxpayers' money. I believe that we should have an explanation. It would appear that the Commission may have ignored much of the Senate Committee's findings in coming to its conclusion.

The Commission has ignored the fact that the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation's record in drug testing is second to none. It has utilised the services of the Australian sport drug administration since well before it became known. It has also privately funded tests which the administration has conducted on behalf of the Federation. This has been an onerous financial burden, but has been considered by the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation to be vital to the purpose of the Federation and to the value of its reputation.

The Federation has had six positive tests in its entire history, the last five in the last 12 months all registered by former members of the old AAPLF who were accepted by the drug free powerlifters in accordance with the requirements of the Senate inquiry that it open up its membership to persons from those associations. That is referred to in the report. One person who tested positive received a lifetime ban for the use of and trafficking in anabolic steroids and the others, who were using prohibited substances, received three-year bans.

The recent 1990 Australian Open Championships saw the drug agency conduct 23 drug tests, with no refusals, and all were clean. Contrast this with the APLF, the now national representative organisation, whose 1990 national titles were somewhat disrupted when one State team which arrived to discover that random tests would be conducted decided to withdraw its participation, and when there were a number of other refusals and four positive tests. I am at a loss to understand the basis for the Sports Commission decision.

The Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation says that it has detected an element of resentment in its dealings with the Commission. It is my view-and I put it to the Senate-that we should be given an explanation as to what has gone on and how it is that the money has been given in the fashion in which it has.

I also refer to the fact that two months ago an official of the drug free powerlifters was informed by a person involved with the Australian blind sports competition, which includes powerlifting, that the blind sports organisers had been told by the Australian Sports Commission that they should not use the Drug Free Federation to officiate at the blind sports.

We are entitled to know why the Commission appears to be proceeding in a manner so different from the recommendations of the Senate Committee. If there is good reason to do so, I believe that the Government ought to respond to that report to the Senate before any decision is made to support one or the other outside the one that is recommended and give money for that purpose. I fail to see why the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation has been denied government support, having applied recently as a result of the Senate Committee's findings. As I said, the Government has not responded to the findings of the Senate Committee and I am really surprised that funding has been determined without that having been done. Why one and not the other? I think we are entitled to know and I believe that if funding has not yet been paid over it should not be, at least until we have been given a full account of what has gone on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support very strongly the remarks made by Senator Reid. When I first became aware of the fact that a $20,000 grant was to be made to what is basically simply the old organisation under a slightly revamped structure, I put out some media releases asking exactly the same question as Senator Reid has asked.
—It did not get a run.

—It got a very good run, thank you. It is kind of Senator Faulkner to mention it. It got enough runs for the Australian Sports Commission to contact me to try to explain why it had totally ignored-arrogantly, I put to it-the decision of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. If Senator Faulkner wants to make any more interjections, I invite him to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem as I see it is really centred around the fact that the Government, knowing of the existence of very strong recommendations in the bipartisan report, Drugs in Sport, of the Black inquiry, had the arrogance to pretend that those recommendations did not exist when it made this announcement, with no justification and no explanation for ignoring that report. I might remind you, Mr President, that the chairman of the Committee was a Labor senator in this place. I might tell the Government that I have spoken to ex-Senator Black on this matter and naturally he was interested-I suppose that would be the polite word-to note that his strong recommendation was totally ignored by the Government. I do not know what internal factional fights within the Labor Party are involved in this sort of matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get into that can of worms.

—Exactly. If one tries to get into that can of worms, who knows where it would lead? But we keep on hearing from the other side how various matters took place on this side which resulted in one honourable senator being on the bottom of the ticket. I do not know whether any honourable senator opposite wants to make any black remarks or give any black looks on that score.
—Like Senator Puplick's look.

—I notice from that interjection that the word `black' is not raised in that context on the other side of the chamber. How curious! What a selective memory! However, I think it is worth noting that this arrogant approach-and it was the Minister who made the announcement-to a Senate committee's findings is totally unacceptable.
—You must be joking.

—Is it not arrogant? I am overjoyed to hear the interjection. It is apparently not arrogant for a Minister-provided it is a Labor Minister-to ignore totally the strongest possible recommendations about funding this body without any explanation or justification whatsoever. I am glad that is on the record from the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that after I had complained about this behaviour and the decision, I was contacted-and I try to maintain these informal contacts with Government bodies-by the Australian Institute of Sport, quite properly, and we had a discussion about this matter. As a result of that discussion I understand that the Minister has referred the matter-this is how serious it is; I know Senator Reid will be interested to know this-back to the Australian Sports Commission. As a result of the media coverage-of which the alert, intelligent honourable senators opposite apparently are totally unaware when they interject-the matter has been referred back to the Australian Sports Commission, which is, of course, looking at it again.

Whatever the merits of this matter, on the face of it there is a clear burden of evidence indicating that the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation should have received the grant. Despite all the other suggestions that, because it is not `national' and not affiliated with an international body-which to my knowledge has little standing anyway-it should not get the grant, I believe there is a clear weight of evidence that if the grant were to go to anyone, it should have gone to the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation.

My simple view on this matter is: why not test both these bodies in a very simple way- it is not a drug test, it is a finance test-see how they behave, and reward good behaviour? I think that is a far more sensible approach. I would be inclined to take the view that perhaps the funding could be deferred for a while. On the face of it at the moment the Drug Free Powerlifting Federation has a far superior record, and I would expect that record to be maintained.

The key issue remains that it is arrogant and defensive for any government totally to ignore the strong findings of a Senate committee without explanation and without feeling that it has any sort of obligation to this chamber to explain why it should act in such an arrogant way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time Senator Richardson gave an answer to a question asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen with respect to family allowance and the possibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) reviewing the assets test that the Government foreshadowed during the Budget in response to, amongst other things, the strong protests made by the National Farmers Federation, by the people on this side of the chamber and also by many ordinary Australians at rural crisis meetings throughout Australia over the last month.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take a few minutes to go over those assets tests and the importance of the Government changing its mind on those matters. I have said all along that if the Government does something right I want to be the first one to give it a bouquet. I have not exactly rushed down to Interflora, but I am hopeful that the assets test that the Government wants to introduce for family allowance will be a net asset level of $300,000, for the isolated children's allowance a net asset level of $200,000, and for Austudy a net asset level of $200,000, which is reduced by $200,000 from the current level of $400,000.

The problem with these reductions is that many students who come from provincial Australia, many students whose parents are involved in primary industry who have properties and so on, will be severely disadvantaged. In particular, I single out those students who are currently receiving tertiary education, are reliant on Austudy, and who may, as a result of any change in the assets test, be forced to leave their tertiary education halfway through their course.

Hopefully Senator Collins would be as disturbed as I am at the prospect of these young Australians undergoing a university education losing their places and perhaps losing two years or more of invested study because the Government has reduced the assets test. That is why I am sure Senator Collins will be one of those people on that side of the chamber who will hopefully be pulling very hard at the coat-tails of the Prime Minister and saying, `Please review this decision because we don't believe it is in the best interests of the people in rural Australia'.

This is very important because although the distance education schools do a very good job, they can only go so far. I have travelled around Queensland and visited distance education centres in Queensland. They try very hard, but one gets to a point-past about Grade 6 or Grade 7-where it is difficult to provide the intensive specialised education that is now demanded of those leaving high schools through the mechanism of the distance education centres and it is necessary to send those children away. In country areas that is not considered some sort of privilege, it is just a necessity. Local high schools do not exist in many areas, and where they do exist they do not offer a wide range of choices when it comes to subjects.

Let us make it very clear: the assets tests levels that are proposed are so low that anybody with a farm would have to have at least that level of net assets or the farm would not be viable. Therefore, if the Government goes ahead with changing these assets tests, the consequence will be that those people will lose any chance of getting the family allowance, the isolated children's allowance or Austudy. I think that would be a very severe blow to those people because they are battling as it is. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen said today, in spite of the fact that they may have $200,000 or $300,000 in net assets, they do not necessarily have an income. Many of them will have negative incomes; they will be digging into their savings just to get by over this year and next year.

I am very concerned for those young people right across rural Australia. I would like to take the opportunity to add my voice to the many thousands of voices across Australia and, on behalf of all the young people of rural Australia, I beg the Government to change its mind on this matter and not implement the lower assets tests. If it does that I promise Senator Collins that I will rush down to Interflora and buy him a bouquet.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.36 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 21 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: In relation to a review (tabled) by a consultant to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, Dr Ian Nisbet, of the National Health and Medical Research Council's (NH&RC) Committee on Toxicity's assessments of the toxicity of the organochlorine pesticides aldrin, dieldrin, heptachlor and chlordane between 1985 and 1988-

(1) Is Dr Nisbet's statement that the NH&RC incorrectly assessed the composition of heptachlor and chlordane correct; if so, does the Minister accept that the NH&RC's incorrect assessment of the chemical's composition led the NH&RC to underestimate their toxicity; if not why not. (Please provide references.)

(2) Is Dr Nisbet correct in stating that, in its assessment of the literature on chlordane and heptachlor, the NH&RC neglected to cite, and/or refer, and/or accept the following scientific and peer-reviewed papers: (a) Epstein 1976, and (b) Reuber 1987, on each of the occasions recorded by Dr Nisbet on page 3 of his submission; if so, for each paper, will the Minister explain why the NH&RC decided to ignore or reject these papers on each of the occasions recorded by Dr Nisbet.

(3) Is Dr Nisbet correct in stating that, in its assessment of the literature on chlordane and heptachlor, the NH&RC failed to cite and discuss the following studies: (a) Cabral et al (quoted in Epstein 1976); a study of heptachlor in infant rats which, according to Epstein, is positive for endocrine and renal tumours; (b) Becker and Sell (Cancer Res 39:3491, 1979); reported that technical chlordane was carcinogenic in C57Bl mice; (this study is important because it was in a strain with low spontaneous incidence of liver tumours); (c) Williams and Numoto (Carcinogenesis 5:1689: Toxicol Pathol 13:325, 1985); reported that technical chlordane and technical heptachlor were tumour promoters in a two-stage bioassay in B6C3F1 mice; (d) Cerey et al (Mut Res 21:26, 1973); reports dominant lethal effects and chromosome abnormalities in rats dosed with heptachlor; (e) Welch et al (Toxicol Appl. Pharmacol. 19:234, 1971); report effects on hormone metabolism; (f) Shain et al (Toxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 40:115, 1977); report effects on hormone metabolism; (g) Seifert (Bull. Env. Path. Toxicol. 42:707, 1989); report teratogenic effects of technical heptachlor and technical chlordane in chickens; (h) Spyker-Cranmer et al (J. Env. Path. Toxicol. 2:357, 1978); reported postnatal mortality following exposure of female mice to technical chlordane at 8 mg/kd-d; (i) Cranmer et al (Toxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 68:204, 1984); and (j) Spyker-Cranmer et al (62:402, 1982); and Spyker-Cranmer et al and Cranmer in 1977 report to USEPA; reported postnatal effects on behaviour, ecnocrine function, immune function and corticosteroid levels following exposure of female mice to technical chlordane at 0.16 mg/kd-d; and (k) Barnett et al (Toxicol. Letters 25:173 and 22, 1985); reported other immunoteratological effects of technical chlordane in mice; if so, for each one of the studies, will the Minister explain why the NH&RC failed to cite and discuss them.

(4) Is Dr Nisbet correct in claiming that, in its assessment of the literature on chlordane and heptachlor, the NH&RC accepted at face value, without critical review, the reported conclusions of most studies on reproductive developmental toxicity, even when the reported conclusions are inconsistent with the data.

(5) Is Dr Nisbet correct when he states that the NH&RC either failed to conduct or inadequately conducted statistical analyses on any of the reproductive/developmental toxicity studies cited on page 5 of Dr Nisbet's report.
(6) Will the Minister confirm that up to 1 per cent of the known human mutagen and carcinogen propylene oxide is incorporated into both technical chlordane and technical heptachlor; if not, why not.

(7) Is Dr Nisbet correct in claiming that the NH&RC failed to mention that up to 1 per cent of the known human mutagen and carcinogen propylene oxide is incorporated into both technical chlordane and technical heptachlor.

(8) Is Dr Nisbet correct in claiming that NH&RC failed to consider: (a) that most measured indoor human exposure to the cyclodienes underestimates total exposure as it fails to measure the more volatile components of the compounds; (b) that many of the toxicity animal studies have been conducted on single components of the chemicals; and (c) that studies conducted by administering technical chlordane to animal-feed are biased towards effects of the less volatile components, because the more volatile components volatise from the feed during preparation; if not, why not. (Please provide references.)

(9) Is Dr Nisbet correct in claiming that, in its assessment of the literature on chlordane and heptachlor, on all but one occasion the NH&RC failed to consider that: (a) reported indoor measurements usually underestimate total exposure; and (b) that available studies reflect only part of the toxicity of the mixtures because they refer only to their less volatile components; if not, why not.

(10) Will the Minister confirm that Dr Nisbet is correct in claiming that Khasawinah and Grutsch's statement (Regulatory Toxicol. Pharmacol. 10:95, 1989) that there was no evidence of a dose response in the RIASBT rat study with chlordane is in blatant contradiction to the facts they [Khasawinah and Grutsch] report.

(11) Has the Committee on Toxicity of the NH&RC itself reviewed the Research Institute for Animal Science in Biochemistry and Toxicology's study `Thirty-month chronic toxicity and tumorigenicity test in rats with chlordane'; if not, why not.

(12) Has the NH&RC established acceptable levels of exposure, that is, Admissible Daily Intakes (ADIs) for: (a) aldrin; (b) dieldrin; (c) chlordane and (d) heptachlor; if so, what are the ADIs and what is the: (a) no adverse effect level; and (b) lowest observed level, on the basis of which the NH&RC has established ADIs for aldrin, dieldrin, heptachlor and chlordane; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (12) The papers upon which the relevant NH&RC committees have based their recommendations on chlordane and heptachlor have been released to interested parties under the Freedom of Information Act and I have arranged for copies of them to be passed to Senator Vallentine.

Clearly there is a difference of view between Dr Nisbet and the NH&RC committees in relation to interpretation of a number of scientific studies. The position taken by the NH&RC committees is supported by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). A different view has apparently been taken by the US authorities.

The substance of these differences is discussed in the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council `Health, Politics, Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products' pages 61-65, which I commend to the honourable Senator.

The NH&RC has commissioned a further review of the cyclodiene pesticides which include chlordane and heptachlor. The Working Party undertaking the review is to report to the Council in November 1990 and a report is expected to be subsequently released for public comment.

It should be borne in mind that severe restrictions have been recommended on the use of chlordane and heptachlor in Australia, including a prohibition on the use of these pesticides in the indoor living areas of domestic dwellings and habitable buildings and in outdoor living areas, as well as in home gardens where food is produced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amounts did Telecom and Australia Post pay in rates and municipal charges to local governments in 1989.
(2) What are the amounts expected for 1990.
(3) Which other government business enterprises have been exposed to liability for local government rates and charges.
(4) What is the amount of revenue involved for local government for 1990-91 and for 1991.
(5) Which government business enterprises are still exempt from local government rates and charges and what is the timing for the removal of these exemptions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom and Australia Post estimate that they paid a total of $l9.1 million in rates and municipal charges to local government in 1989-90.
(2) Telecom and Australia Post estimate that they will pay a total of $20 million in local government charges in 1990-91.
(3) The following Government Business Enterprises, apart from Telecom and Australia Post, are subject to all local government taxes and charges:

Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd, Australian Airlines, Australian National Line, Aussat, Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, Health Insurance Commission, Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, Overseas Telecommunications Corporation, Qantas Airways, Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government, during the 1989-90 financial year, commission any study to analyse the economic impact of major naval shipbuilding projects in progress in Australia; if so, when is the report expected to be available; if not, does the Government intend to commission any such study in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The construction contracts for both the Collins class submarines and the ANZAC frigates include detailed provisions to ensure high Australian content.

The Department of Defence, in consultation with other Departments, has established sophisticated procedures to monitor the progress of the contracts, including these provisions. As part of these procedures, the contractors are to report regularly on progress under the contracts, and the Government is monitoring the situation, including achievement of Australian content.
In its response to the McKinnon report, the Government agreed that a study be undertaken of the economic impact of these projects, including the effectiveness of technology transfer to industry.

The arrangements outlined above provide adequate monitoring of the direct effects. The longer-term indirect effects will emerge more slowly and it is considered that an appropriate time to commence this study would be following the launch of the first ships. Some preliminary work is going on to develop a methodology for that study.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce: Industrial Research Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What additional resources are being provided during the 1990-1991 financial year for the Strategic Industrial Research Program of the department to enable it to encourage greater interaction between marine industry and researchers.
(2) On what activities will these additional resources be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the McKinnon review of Australian marine industries and as part of its Science and Technology Statement of May 1989, the Government allocated $3.9 million over five year period commencing 1989-90.

These funds will provide for an expenditure of around $800,000 per annum for initiatives to encourage greater collaboration between marine industries and research institutions in developing marine based products and services.

My department has now established a Marine Industries Section which is part of the Strategic Industrial Research Branch. Strategies to encourage the development of Australian marine industries are being formulated on a collaborative basis with industry, the marine science community and other Government agencies.

The Consultative Group on Marine Industries, Science and Technology (CMIST) has also been established. It provides a forum where, for the first time, interested parties from industry, the research community and Government can come together to discuss key issues affecting the marine sector. More importantly I expect CMIST will provide a forum where opportunities for partnerships and other close links may be forged between marine industries and marine science and technology.
Since its establishment earlier this year, CMIST has met twice. The first meeting, in February, attracted approximately fifty participants; the second, around seventy.

Six voluntary Working Groups were established at CMIST 1 to report on key issues including marine industries development strategy, training, innovation, and information needs. Although only in existence for a short time, CMIST has attracted a high level of support. I expect industry representation will continue to strengthen at future meetings.

In addition to CMIST, an annual conference entitled `Oceans Australia' was inaugurated in May this year. In future years, the Conference, in contrast to CMIST, will provide a forum for review of technical advancements and progress achieved in industry development.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government asked the Australian Research Council to identify elements of marine science and technology for funding emphasis in higher education; if so, what were the Australian Research Council's recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has not asked the Australian Research Council to identify elements of marine science and technology for funding emphasis in higher education.

Following the establishment of the Australian Research Council in 1988, the former Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme, established in 1979 to enhance Australia's efforts in marine sciences and technologies, was absorbed as a priority area of the Councils research program. In 1989 the Council considered that research in marine sciences and technologies had developed to the point that it no longer required overall identification as a priority area. Nonetheless, applications were specifically encouraged in the following areas of Marine Science and Technology:
- biotechnology including aquaculture
- coastal and off-shore engineering
- marine geoscience including physical oceanography

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 11= September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the increased price of oil and the impending increase in the price of airline tickets, has there been a drop in the number of international tourists to Australia.
(2) Which country provides the greatest percentage of people visiting Australia.
(3) What action, if any, does the Government intend taking to maintain the number of international tourists coming to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 13 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a Mr Philip Edwin Busst formerly employed by Australian Airlines as a security officer over a period of years; if so, for how many years.
(2) Was his employment determined sometime on or around 18 May 1987.
(3) Was the matter taken to the Arbitration Commission on appeal and was there a finding that Mr Busst had been denied natural justice and that he should be reinstated; if no, what was the finding.
(4) What action did Australian Airlines take in relation to the findings of the Arbitration Commission on this matter.
(5) Was Mr Busst reinstated.
(6) Did Australian Airlines negotiate with Mr Busst directly or with a trade union.
(7) What has been the outcome of the whole affair.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Philip Edwin Busst was employed by Australian Airlines (TAA) as a security officer at Sydney Airport between 11 November 1974 and 17 June 1987.
(2) Mr Busst's employment was terminated on 17 June 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to an incident in Sydney on 27= November 1988 in which Joseph Tokic, a 16-year-old Australian, was shot by a Yugoslav security guard from within the compound of the Yugoslav Consulate-General, has the Yugoslav Government since apologised either to the Australian Government or to the victim or his family.
(2) Has any compensation been paid to the victim or his family.
(3) What are the present gun laws as they apply to foreign missions in Australia, and how are they policed.
(4) What has been the subsequent history of the security guard who fired the shot.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) This matter is subject to private negotiations and possibly litigation and any enquiry should be directed to Mr Tokic or his legal representatives.

(3) The gun laws applying to diplomatic missions and consular posts in Australia are those that apply to Australian citizens. The Customs Act covers the importation of weapons into Australia and the Australian Customs Service polices that. The laws of the State or Territory where the mission or post is situated cover the possession and licensing of weapons, and State and Territory police forces and the Australian Federal Police are responsible for policing those laws. As I announced on 2 July, the Government has placed tight additional restrictions on the possession, carriage and use of firearms in the diplomatic and consular community. This has been done under the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations. In consulation with the Australian Federal Police, my Department will approve the very few weapons that are to be permitted, under rigid control. State and Federal Police will report any significant abuse of those restrictions. I will deal with any such report on the basis of the Government's instruction that consideration is to be given to taking the most serious steps available to us under international law.
(4) The individual concerned was expelled from Australia along with other members of the Consulate-General and the Australian Government has no further information on him.
